PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase of violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA independent senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This Act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Burns (from 13 citizens) and Parer (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Queensland: Disaster Relief Funds
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:

We are concerned that the National Party in Queensland is diverting money given by the Federal Government to the Queensland Government to alleviate natural disasters; that it might not be finding its way to its intended targets; and that it is being diverted to the coffers of the National Party itself or otherwise to expansion projects promoted by members or supporters of the National Party.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray the Federal Government be asked to legislate for an audit of account from the Queensland Government for every dollar or cent provided by the Federal Government for any type of relief operation in Queensland.

DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1989STATES GRANTS (TECHNICAL AND FURTHER EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1989STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1989STUDENT ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 April and 24 May, on motions by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of Bills provides funding in line with government policies for schools, technical and further education and higher education. Specifically, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1989 amends the 1988 principal Act to provide an additional $36.6m in appropriations for schools in 1989, bringing total funding for 1989 to $1,982m. That amounts to almost $2 billion for schools this year. The Bill, in effect, increases Commonwealth funding to take account of price increases and for this year only makes adjustments in Australian Capital Territory (ACT) school funding to take account of the advent of self-government in the Territory. The second Bill, the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1989, also increases appropriations to reflect cost movements and will provide funding to the ACT from 1 July. Supplementation amounting to $9.5m is provided by the Bill. The third Bill, the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1989, also supplements funding for higher education, taking into account additional costs. The Bill also takes into account the new structure for the overseas student program and the new arrangements in the Australian Capital Territory for education following self-government in the Australian Capital Territory. The Bill provides an additional $24m this year, $20m in 1990 and $2m in 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: These three Bills provide supplementary funds in the usual manner in which we consider this kind of supplementation at this time of the year. On behalf of the Opposition and in consonance with my colleagues in the House of Representatives, I shall move the following amendment in relation to these Bills:
At end of motion add: ``, but the Senate:
(a) condemns the Government for its policies on schools, TAFE and higher education; and
(b) calls on the Government to adopt policies that will facilitate the true advancement of education in Australia''

The fourth Bill dealt with cognately in this debate is the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1989. This measure will not be opposed by the Opposition. First, it provides that wording in legislation with regard to the new vocabulary for higher education be brought up to date. Secondly, it relaxes reliance on administrative procedures, in so far as they have up to this point required direct ministerial decision. This flexibility is sensible and is supported by the Opposition. Thirdly, it makes for more flexible appeal procedures under Austudy with regard to student assistance. Again, there are sensible reasons for this flexibility, and the Opposition supports this aspect of the Bill.

My caution about the Bill relates to the attempt to introduce a simplification of the Austudy Act to enable a proposed set of simplified regulations to be implemented. The student assistance legislation has been with us in this form since 1973. Over that 16-year period most interested bodies around Australia have come to understand the student assistance regulations. I do not believe that it is an urgent priority to try some rationalisation or simplification, because such innovation may, in fact, complicate the matter. In any event, within a year or so, the Opposition will be in government and we will undertake a comprehensive review of Austudy arrangements. The appropriate time for those changes to be made would be then. So I do not encourage the change that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) indicated in his second reading speech is to be undertaken at this time to simplify the regulations for student assistance.
In respect of the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1989, I shall move:
At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) its inability to appreciate the special needs for assistance of students from rural areas; and
(b) the turmoil caused by its policies on, and administration of, assistance of students in higher education institutions''.

Honourable senators will know that July marks the two-year anniversary of this lacklustre, fizzling-out Labor Government. It also marks the second year in the office of Minister for Employment, Education and Training of the present Minister, Mr John Dawkins. This package of Bills provides an opportunity for the Senate to review the impact that this Western Australian member of the House of Representatives has had on education during the last two years. It has been a dramatic two years in which the Minister has done great damage to education in this country, all in the name of reform. John Dawkins has identified some real problems in education, particularly higher education and, to a lesser extent, schools. Largely, he has left schools on the back burner.

The Minister did not have to go far to find out what the problems were. The coalition spelt out the widely canvassed problems in black and white in our education policies in the run-up to the last election. I give credit to Mr Dawkins for reading our policies and discovering the need for change. He discovered the need for objectives such as a dramatic increase in the number of students studying in our universities and colleges. Under former Minister Susan Ryan, we had plateaued entirely in higher education and there was very little growth. There was the increasing problem of unmet demand. A second objective he has discovered from reading our policies is the need to abolish the restrictive binary funding system which denied research funding to colleges of advanced education and institutes of technology. Another objective he has picked up from us is the need to restructure the system of academic tenure along the lines of a Senate inquiry into tenure, to make it sounder, more flexible, more accountable, and generally more bona fide.

Another objective Mr Dawkins picked up was the need to have a better skilled and better educated work force. Do honourable senators remember the day I suggested that to relate education in schools to future employment was some sacrilege against the goals of the progressive educators? Increasingly we have gained public acceptance, even among educationalists themselves, for the idea that the principal outcome for any school leaver is the lifetime of work, and that his schoolings ought, not indirectly but directly, to relate to his being a skilled, educated participant in the work force. This is for his own fulfilment and for the betterment of Australia. Again, this is clearly underlined by the acceptance of this objective by Minister Dawkins.

A fifth objective that I believe is picked up from our policy statement is the need for improved standards in our school system. As I have said, these are all objectives which Mr Dawkins has borrowed heavily from the Liberal and National parties. However, that is only half the solution to gaining some of these objectives. The other half is to work out a practical way of achieving those objectives. That is the half that Mr Dawkins has got wrong. Unfortunately, the methods he has adopted will not provide solutions. He is heavy handed and centralist in the methods he has adopted. The only relief from these muddled methods will be the election of a Liberal-National Party government to get not only the objectives right but also the methods right to achieve those objectives.

Let us consider higher education in a little more detail. Mr Dawkins has acknowledged the need for reform in higher education, but he has gone about revolutionising the system and bringing it under his own control through highly centralised, highly bureaucratic and highly authoritarian legislation. These reforms have been forced through Parliament without adequate scrutiny, without adequate debate and without adequate justification. Late last year, in December, as the whole nation will remember, the House of Representatives was recalled for one day, principally to deal with the education Bills which had been rushed through the House of Representatives weeks before after only two hours of debate. Anyone who reads that pathetic debate will see that the legislation did not come under any careful scrutiny whatever which was expressly the intent of Minister Dawkins. It was only here in the Senate-I see Senator Macklin sitting across the chamber-that the Opposition gave careful scrutiny to the legislation. Debate spread over three days which led to significant amendments being made which clearly flagged for this Parliament and for the Australian public the alternative approach that ought to be adopted and which ultimately can be adopted only with a change of government.

These very important education Bills, the outcome of Mr Dawkins's first year of decision making as Minister, were guillotined in the House of Representatives, pushed through-let no-one here deny it-in just 2 1/2 hours. The Government allowed 2 1/2 hours for scrutinising Bills introducing major educational reforms and providing some $18 billion-let me repeat that, $18 billion-for education in this country over the next three or four years. We also saw how much attention Mr Dawkins paid to the views and comments of those involved in education when he took his Green Paper around Australia inviting comment. The public will know that when a government is embarking upon some major areas of reform, it will publish a document called a Green Paper, an options paper. Mr Dawkins published a Green Paper, but there was no consultation before that publication. The idea was that there would be some response from all the interested bodies around Australia and then the Government's decisions would be published in a White Paper about nine months later.

It was hardly surprising to find that despite the barrage of protest and the genuinely constructive comment offered to Mr Dawkins from many quarters, his higher education Green Paper conveniently became the actual White Paper. Can anyone in this chamber point to any significant change between the White Paper and the Green Paper? This centralist, heavy-handed Minister just ploughed on thinking he had got it all right. He gave the Government's decisions in the middle of last year, without any major change from those that he had, with his own limited consultation, determined in the Green Paper some nine months earlier. There was hardly a change. The document was practically xeroxed and given a new cover-the Government just changed the paint. So much for consultation, so much for listening to those involved in the academic community, such as researchers, teachers, students and administrators. As a result we have a higher education reform program with major defects, particularly because of the Minister's obsession with forced amalgamation, centralised decision making and bureaucratic control.

I now refer to the unified national system. The Dawkins reform package is well under way, but the greatest damage is yet to be done. It will occur once all institutions have been brought into the so-called unified national system. It sounds pretty horrific, does it not? This system will take decision making in higher education out of the hands of the institutions and place it into the hands of the bureaucrats. P. P. McGuinness wrote in the Australian Financial Review in July last year that Mr Dawkins wanted to turn the higher education system into a gigantic bureaucratic shemozzle designed to suppress originality of research and initiative. Under the unified system universities and colleges have to submit a profile, a set of objectives, a plan. There is nothing wrong with having a plan or a set of objectives, but let it be one that is initiated by the institution-the university or the college of advanced education. Let those organisations be responsible for the objectives which are tailored to the needs of those whom they serve. Do not let this profile be thrust upon them by backdoor negotiations by a centralist Minister in Canberra. As long as their plans conform to the wishes of Canberra, the universities will receive full funding. But if they do not have a profile which has been negotiated in the backrooms and which is acceptable to this centralist Minister, let it be understood that they will not get the full funding-they will not get the money. The institutions have no bargaining power. The Opposition fears that it will be Canberra, not the institutions who know, which determines the face of higher education in this country.

The traditional academic autonomy of our institutions is under serious threat. I make this very serious charge: it is the Opposition's firm view that after more than a century of enlightened development in higher education in this country, the present arrangements by the Minister place traditional academic authority under serious threat. Success in attracting research funds will be as much a product of selling an institutional profile in Canberra as of excellence in research. More than that, whilst I welcome and support the formation of the Australian Research Council, the ARC, I believe that it is too centralised and too interfering with the autonomy of peer groups of researchers around this country. The clawback of research moneys from institutions is a mistake which the Government still has not corrected.

The coalition has placed much emphasis on the need for institutional autonomy. We believe in freeing up the system in order to let it expand. I have said on a number of occasions that the person I respect most, who has contributed most to education in this country over the last 20 years, is Professor Peter Karmel. He has had more impact on our higher education system and on our schools than any other Australian. The advice that he gave to successive governments was worthy, sensible and enlightened. The Karmel period, from 1973 to the mid-1980s, is over. That rationalisation, that achievement of standards, that injection of additional resources, even the degree of amalgamation that took place in that time, have been achieved. In order to get the best objectives for education in this country we need to see that the Karmel period is over. We need to give increased freedom and encourage a genuine sharing of objectives with the institutions, to give them an initiative, an opportunity for creativity. We have the standard, the foundation, the rationalised base. To go further in that direction is an error. That is why we condemn centralisation, rationalisation, amalgamation, bureaucratisation. There will be a clear change with the election of a Liberal-National Party government. We will stop those processes. We will gain the objectives which Dawkins has picked up from us through increasing the freedom of our higher education institutions and giving them the ability to initiate.

As my time is rapidly coming to a close I will need to consider amalgamation more briefly than I had intended. The amalgamation question is an area of enormous contrast between the Government and the Opposition. We will support amalgamation only where there is a clear educational advantage in doing so. Where there is not a clear educational advantage that is mutually agreed by the amalgamating institutions, or the institutions proposed for amalgamation, we will oppose the amalgamation. It has already been made clear that here, in this city, Dawkins wants three institutions-the Canberra Institute of the Arts, the Canberra College of Advanced Education and the Australian National University-to be the new ANU. This Opposition is opposed to that. Why is bigger better? What is the educational advantage in that proposed amalgamation? There is none. Invite any senator here in this chamber to show where there would be an educational advantage. The costs would be greater and there would be inherent difficulties caused by the different locations of the campuses.

It is now very clear that that amalgamation proposal is dead because this Opposition and the Australian Democrats have opposed that legislation. This is an indication of the Opposition's approach to any other amalgamation that is being discussed in any of the Territories or the States. If an institute can publicly give a reason to support its involvement in amalgamation and define in a credible way the educational advantages that would flow from that change, then by all means let the amalgamation proceed. If that does not happen then the coalition, both in opposition and in government, will oppose any such amalgamation. Let institutions be clearly warned that should they forsake, in some cases, a whole century of autonomy as well as objectives and profiles for the sake of some millions of dollars in the short term, the Opposition does not guarantee to continue that situation should it be elected to government in the near future.

The graduate tax has stirred up more opposition to Government in educational circles than has any other measure. Madam Acting Deputy President, you understand this matter. Without wanting to embarrass you, I know that there are many in your Party who are not at all convinced that the Dawkins decision to go ahead with the graduate tax was a good one. The Liberal and National parties will abolish the graduate tax after the next election. We will ensure that the too onerous user-pays burden placed on the students of Australia by the Dawkins decision will be lifted. The contribution from students will be diminished to one-third of what it is now. Instead of a graduate tax of $1,800, we will have a direct student fee of $600. But, for one-quarter of all the higher education students in Australia, even that fee will be abolished. One-quarter of the students in higher education institutions will be admitted completely free. The awarding of those free places will be based partly on academic grounds and partly on financial grounds. Those students in greatest need can be assured that under a Liberal-National Party government there will be no contribution required of them under the user-pays principle. The onerous burden of $1,800 a year that has been laid on three-quarters of Australian students by this Labor Government will be reduced to one-third-$600.

Under a coalition government institutions will be free to chart their own futures, negotiate pay and conditions with academic staff, devise their own curricula and research programs, and compete with each other for students and funds. Universities and colleges will be freed from Labor's centralist reforms through the abolition of Labor's unified national system, forced amalgamations, compulsory contract funding and graduate tax. The National Board for Employment, Education and Training will be made independent of government. I will refer to schools and technical and further education (TAFE) institutions in the committee stage. I do not omit reference to those areas because they lack priority. Speeches and published policies of members of the Opposition make it very clear that we regard as important the urgent need for innovation in and betterment of schools and TAFEs.

In summary, the coalition's education policy provides for choice, excellence and individual responsibility. In contrast, Labor's education policy stands for standardisation, centralisation and mediocrity. We seek to reward initiative but Labor cuts everyone down to the same low standard. The coalition looks for sound foundations in all fields of education and a concentration on mastering basic educational skills. The coalition recognises that parents have priority in determining the education of their children. Families need to be asked what they want, rather than what the educators want, for their children. I seek leave to move the two amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have operated for a long time in the education area. I suppose one of the hazards of that occupation is that one has to listen to more florid speeches than in any other area. The education area is full of articles, books and speeches which all suggest that things should be improved. One would rarely want to disagree with such sentiments. However, I think the more important and pressing task is to delineate precisely how that will be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are debating the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1989, the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1989, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1989 and the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1989. The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill seeks, amongst other things, that at least some funding will be provided through the Australian Capital Territory Government. This highlights sharply the Government's intent to bring about forced amalgamations of higher education institutions, not only in this Territory but also in the States. This legislation attempts to do a number of things. It is very similar to the Fraser Government's ill-fated attempts. I do not think it has its target clearly in view; nor does it provide a detailed analysis of its aims to enable those aims to be achieved.

Undoubtedly, one problem that exercises many people's minds is the so-called proliferation of courses in Australian institutions. The proliferation of courses has arisen not only because of a number of geographical factors but also because of economic factors. The geographical factors include the vast distances involved and the demands of the separate States to have within State borders educational offerings of a comprehensive kind. Another problem is that of economics. As is the case in so many other areas, the economic issue ought to be paid a lot more attention than it has been. I think it has led the Government into the rather silly and absurd operations that it is attempting around Australia at the moment. If the vast bulk of those types of amalgamations go ahead, nothing would have been gained.

That is probably no better illustrated than in my own State of Queensland, where the suggestion now is to break up the Brisbane College of Advanced Education (CAE), which was the result of amalgamations of previous colleges under the Fraser Government. The absurdity of the context does not seem to have struck anybody. We are now about to divide something that a few years ago was considered to be essential to be put together. At that stage, the various independent campuses and colleges around Brisbane were amalgamated into one. Additional funds were provided over the following years to assist that to come about. In other words, there were not any economic gains made. But now, after a passage of years, those various campuses are finally working together as a single institution, as happens with time in almost any circumstance. Now that everything has settled down, it is proposed to break it all up again.

For what reason? One of the reasons given is that the Mount Gravatt campus of the Brisbane CAE has a certain proximity to Griffith University, and it does. It is divided by a six-lane highway, but this does not seem to faze anybody. It is in the same general area and, therefore, must be seen to be somehow or other contiguous not only in geographical proximity but also in educational intent. That is absolutely absurd. Nobody has bothered arguing the second reason. No arguments in this whole amalgamation debate around Australia have been premised on educational grounds; they have all been arm-waving with regard to administrative efficiency which, in most cases, has never been demonstrated.

Another example from Queensland is the intent to amalgamate the Queensland Conservatorium of Music with the Queensland University, which currently has a very high quality music school but which tends more towards the theoretical. The Conservatorium is, of course, a practical based and performance based school. People say, `Look at the very small size of the Queensland Conservatorium of Music'. Indeed, it has just over 400 students. They say, `This could not possibly be administratively efficient'. The difficulty with that particular argument is that it takes no cognisance of the educational intent of that institution which, as I say, is a performance based music school.

The major music schools around the world-for example, the Juliard School of Music, the Berlin School and the Royal School of Music-all have about 400 students. The bell does not seem to have dropped on anybody in particular that the top performance music schools around the world all have about the same number of students, which is a little over 400. I wonder why that is. Has anybody bothered asking? Has anybody sought to find out? The answer is very plain when one investigates the structures of those schools. There is a range of music performances. The relationship between staff and students in almost all those colleges around the world is 2 to 1. The schools are performance based. One has to have a number of specialities in each area of music. The total number of staff required, plus an increment for administration comes to a little under 200. That means that such a school can have a little over 400 pupils.

That is a simple exercise to have done, but no-one seems to have done it. No-one seems at all interested in doing it. Yet the Queensland Conservatorium of Music invariably performs the best of any music school in this country in every competition that takes place. But, no, that is not good enough. Quality is not good enough. Achievement is not good enough. Administrative efficiency must come first. But again, no administrative efficiency has been demonstrated; it is merely posited.

If one looks in general across the board at the difficulties that we are having in Australia with regard, as I say, to possibly a proliferation of courses, one might ask the question `How could we deal with this particular problem in a constructive, efficient and effective manner?'. I think there is a way to do it but unfortunately it does not recommend itself, obviously, to anybody within the Department of Employment, Education and Training-and certainly it does not seem to recommend itself to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). That way is to look towards the notion of quality as the driving force rather than administration. I would suggest a simple way in which that could come about. Honourable senators in the chamber have probably heard it before but I am going to repeat it, nevertheless. That is that one looks at matters not from the point of view of the institution or the staff; one looks at the students.

I take Sydney as probably a prime example of the difficulty that we have in Australia. The Sydney institutions are basically locked up to students who live in Sydney. People who live in Adelaide or Townsville cannot afford to go there unless they happen to have a favourite aunt who is willing to give them a bedroom and who happens to live within striking distance of the university. The cost of accommodation in Sydney is absolutely prohibitive; the cost of transport in Sydney likewise. So Sydney institutions are taken out. Canberra institutions are taken out; and so we go on progressively around the country, so that, by and large, most of our institutions are locked up for those people who happen to live in the capital cities where they are placed.

How do we change that? Instead of this wild business of running around amalgamating the people who administer these organisations, we should be providing reasonably cheap, good standard student accommodation. We should come at the problem from the other end. That accommodation should be both on and off campus; it should include single, multiple and family accommodation. Any moneys spent there would be recouped because they would be an investment in that all of the students would be paying rent. When those institutional establishments are vacant for periods over the holidays and so on, they could provide the universities with a very good grounding for bringing in external students, for conferences or for other types of activities and people one wished to have on campus at the time. In other words, these forms of accommodation would be good money spinners. They would provide that if people were interested in studying, for example, criminal law and they decided that the best place to do that would be at Sydney University, they would apply to go to Sydney University and the university would then be able, if it accepted them into a place there, to provide them with access to reasonable accommodation. Likewise, if people wanted to do marine biology, they would apply to James Cook University and, if accepted, would be provided with reasonably priced accommodation suitable for their needs.

What would happen as a result of that little exercise-not immediately, but in time-is that pressure would start to build up on specialists. The pressure would be on the quality of the particular institution and we would find some departments in some faculties in institutions around Australia going to the wall because they could not attract students. That is the way that things ought to be done. That is the way that various departments-and faculties, even-should be taken out of the systems. It should be done not by bureaucrats who know absolutely nothing about the situation in Perth, Darwin or anywhere else waving their arms here in Canberra, but by the students voting with their feet to choose a quality of education somewhere else in the country. The pressure would be constantly towards quality.

Most people do not seem to actually understand the operation of institutions-that staff do not attract students terribly much; it is the other way around. Top quality students tend to attract staff. Staff are interested in working with good research students, good performers and people who are undertaking second and higher degrees. With those students available staff are able to push through their own research projects more expeditiously and to greater effect. In other words, various institutions around the country would start to be able to attract top quality staff as well. And so the thing would roll. But it would roll on the issue of quality; it would not roll on the issue of administrative fiat.

One would have thought that, when looking at what the previous Government did in this exercise, the Government would have actually learnt some lessons. But no lessons have been learnt; the exercise is being perpetrated all over again. At the end of the exercise we will have fewer institutions. Can anybody assert where we will get better quality teaching and research? Nobody has been able to assert that; not only that, but we will not even get extra places.

What are these illusory benefits? We have not even been able to demonstrate them in saving dollars on administration. As I indicated, under the previous Government those amalgamated institutions cost more, not less, to run. A multi-campus institution costs more to run than a single campus institution. The odd thing about all of this is that the people who are funding and fuelling this policy exercise do not seem to have actually looked at business recently. They do not seem to have any understanding that the major conglomerates around the world and the major multinationals that exist in Australia are breaking themselves up into smaller units. They have ceased to believe, as obviously someone in the Education Department still believes, that big is better and beautiful. Major organisations are now looking for pure levels of administration, more openness and accountability. One does not get that by massing people; one gets it by breaking the groups up. Hence, one finds that the major companies around the world have fewer people administering them now because they have been broken down into smaller groups than was previously the case. That does not seem to have dawned on anybody. However, that is being taught in the very institutions that are now being forced to amalgamate and become larger. Does anybody ever listen to what people know and have found out about administration and organisations? Where did this 8,000 figure come from? It is another figure that popped out of the air.

TALK.START.PARA: —Totally arbitrary.

—The Government said that 8,000 is a nice figure, and it pulled it out of the air. The method is similar to that used by the previous Government when it found a shopping list floating around somewhere for a totally different purpose and actually used it for the amalgamation exercise. I have already illustrated where there is a connection between numbers and educational purpose. Perhaps the Minister when he replies at the second reading stage might like to posit some arguments about the 8,000 figure because I have not heard one argument on this yet. Why not 7,000? Why not 9,000? They are nice figures as well. They tip off the tongue as easily as 8,000. We need to have some reasons given when these types of things occur; none has been given. We need to look at the latest operational and administrative theories and the way that they have been implemented in business so that we can see where efficiencies are. That is not being done in this exercise either.

SPEECH.PARA: We have an essentially mindless exercise perpetrated yet again by somebody who obviously failed last time. There are no benefits for the community, for the students, and certainly no benefits for the institutions themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially Queensland.

—The Queensland case is one of the sillier examples. There are also some rather silly ones operating around the country. There are reasons for amalgamation and rationalisation but those reasons are educational and quality reasons; they are not administrative. Administration will follow quality: it cannot lead it. It is always the belief, I suppose, of those who operate in this atmosphere in Canberra that by waving one's arms around here, somehow or other things will get better elsewhere. Unfortunately, it has not occurred in the past. It will not occur in the future. We are just in for another bout of wasting people's time, consuming vast quantities of resources, with people worrying about what is happening, with the productivity at the other end being zero, if it is not already negative. People's lives, research and institutional arrangements have been massively disrupted in the interim.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), where there are two institutions, is particularly silly. The obvious way to go is to have the Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE) become a Canberra university under the control of the ACT Government. I am sorry that that matter did not turn up in the legislation. Signadou College was brought in under the ACT but the CCAE was not. It should be under the control of the Territory Government. The Australian National University (ANU) should remain a national university with national goals.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition agrees with both those points.

—It is obvious. If we did not have two institutions in Canberra we probably would not establish two, because of the cost. But we have two fine institutions. The ACT Government, like every other State and Territory government in Australia, needs to involve itself in the tertiary sector. It is involved in the primary and technical and further education (TAFE) sectors. It needs to be involved in the tertiary sector as well. That would give a rounding of the educational policy, it would give direction to educational policy and it would give thrust to educational policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The ACT Administration has set up a committee which is looking at this issue. Despite the fact that it has no administrative control over the CCAE at the moment, it has already seen the need to look at this issue in the interests of the citizens of Canberra. The CCAE most definitely should be a university: it should be the Canberra university, dedicated to the interests and the needs of the citizens of Canberra. The ANU should be funded as a national university and propelled towards its original intention, which has been missed, in large part at least, for some time: that is, to be concerned with national concerns, national objectives and national problems.

The other items that we are dealing with today are the further funding for student assistance, some changes to the Austudy proposals to make them simpler-they could not get more complex-and additional funding for TAFE. With regard to higher education funding, it is emerging from studies being conducted that significant damage is being done to certain sectors, particularly the mature age sector. It has been pointed to previously and has now appeared. I believe that the other sectors that I have already pointed to, part time students and women, will also be affected and will show up in the studies in due course. The Opposition's support for the Government in imposing fees has gone a long way towards setting the damage in train. I indicate that I will move an amendment to the Opposition's amendment in the following terms:
At end of proposed amendment, add the following new paragraph:
``and (c) further condemns the Government and the Opposition for combining to pass these Bills, thereby disadvantaging women, part-time, migrant, mature age and low-income tertiary students''.

TALK.START.PARA: —In government we will abolish the tax.

—The fees legislation having been passed and the damage started, Senator Teague now says that the Opposition will abolish that legislation. It would have been better had the Opposition not started the damage, left things as they were and implemented its policy-whatever it might be-when in government.

SPEECH.PARA: The fascinating point about the funding of students is that, as revealed in the vice-chancellors' recent document with regard to chances lost, some 13,000 to 20,000 would-be students are still floating around without places. The number of students missing out in the community is still the same. Not only are students missing out, but the country is also missing out. I presume that it does not have to be argued and it is generally accepted that the country misses out every time a student who has the ability and would be accepted is not offered a place. We also find other disturbing figures with regard to our higher education students. Rather than the growth we were looking for, we have, in fact, a decline. The exercise in which the Government has engaged has not attracted very many people to move into that area. The Government has spent a lot of time wandering around the community saying how marvellous it is that it has been able to increase the numbers of students staying on at school. That in itself is a nice cynical little exercise. Having promoted the value of staying on at school and having held out the advantages that are undoubtedly there in further education, we then manage to dash the hopes of students who have worked on and worked hard by not providing them with a place in a tertiary institution. For a long time that sort of cynicism has been built into education policies. That may be fine for politicians and may provide a little bit of rhetoric on the campaign trail, but the real concern must be for families who have been unable to get their children into tertiary institutions.

It is a pity that we have not been able to keep pace with the growth of population in terms of the numbers in our tertiary institutions. We have not been able to get spectacular growth, which is what we should be looking for, in our higher education area. That is obviously what is needed if the plans of Senator Button and the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) are to come to fruition in the tertiary industry sector-our computer areas, our brain industries and our sunrise industries. If they are supposed to be developed, upon whom are they supposed to be developed if it is not upon the citizens of this country who have been able to undertake primary, second and higher degrees? At the end of the day, that is where the failure lies. It is a failure to conceive the place that education should have in the priority listings and to provide sufficient funds for that.

When the Government introduced these fees, it said that this strategy would solve the sorts of problems we were facing. Of course, it will not and cannot solve those problems. They can be solved only in one way: not by a maintenance of one per cent, which the Government has been able to achieve, but by an increase in that amount. There should be a concerted, long term exercise of direct funding to the institutions for both educational research purposes and to enable them to build accommodation close to their campuses, if not on their campuses, in order to provide that type of facility to many students. At the end of the day, despite the fact that the fees are most unwelcome and are inhibiting educational opportunity, the real costs in higher education are simply in living, eating, accommodation and transport. We have not addressed those matters. These matters could be addressed not at a vast cost to the community, but at a vast gain. The provision of low cost, good quality student accommodation would not be a cost to the community, but an investment. It would also take the pressure off Austudy where significant increases are being demanded. If good quality, low cost student accommodation were available, then Austudy would not have constant pressure on it.

Finally, I remind the Government that my Party supported it on a whole range of taxing initiatives that it undertook particularly in the two very lucrative areas, as it turned out, of the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. We did so because we believed that resources should be made available for items such as this. Unfortunately that has not occurred. The Government has taken the money and run, as it were. It has not seen that the top priority for Australia at the moment is in providing access to our educational institutions at each level and in a way which is commensurate with the other types of economic goals that Australia has set itself. This is the odd area out, the one which is lagging behind and going nowhere. All we are getting is vast amounts of energy, vast amounts of time and very little information dedicated to a task of amalgamations that, at the end of the day, will produce absolutely nothing for the furtherance of true education for Australia's citizens. I move:
At end of proposed amendment, add the following new paragraph:
``and (c) further condemns the Government and the Opposition for combining to pass these bills, thereby disadvantaging women, part-time, migrant, mature age and low-income tertiary students''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the major point that has been made about the impact of Government policy on higher education in the last few years, I wish briefly to re-state, as has been stated on a number of occasions, that the Government's objective has been-and we have been successful in it-to facilitate a higher growth rate in higher education. In the Budget last year funding was provided to support a major expansion of higher education in the system over the 1989-91 triennium. We are talking about an increase in real terms in the vicinity of $870m. The facilitation of growth in this area is something which not only the Government believes in, but was also consistent with the objectives of Senator Teague's report in this particular area.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to respond briefly to the point about the effect of government policy on a range of areas encompassing women-part time, migrant, mature age and low income tertiary students. It should be recognised that over the period of this Government there have been major advances in making positions available for those groups of people within the education sector. For instance, in the area of higher education generally we are now looking at about a 50 per cent participation rate by women in the area of technical and further education as opposed to one-third, or 33 per cent when this Government took office.

Generally, I do not think the Government needs to enter a major debate in defence of these Bills as that has already been done on a number of occasions. The basic principle has been to facilitate and to improve the participation rate and to facilitate higher growth in the tertiary sector. As a final point, it should be recognised that in the Government's November 1988 funding report we said that about 49,000 additional places would be provided by 1991 in the higher education area. Having said that, I think that we can now proceed either to a vote or to the next stage of the legislation.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Macklin's to Senator Teague's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Teague's in respect of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1989, the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1989 and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1989) agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Teague's in respect of the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1989) agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I foreshadowed in my speech during the second reading debate, during the committee stage I wish to refer to schools and to one particular matter which is encompassed in the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1989. To date the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has made much of his proposal to standardise school education across Australia. He rightly points to the differences in practices, qualifications and standards between the States and Territories. In June last year, the Minister announced a national strategy for schools which attempts to strengthen the capacity of schools to meet Australia's social and economic needs. It involves moves towards establishing a common curriculum and an emphasis on literacy, numeracy and analytical skills. It involves coordination of assessment methods so that secondary school leaving qualifications are adequately recognised in all States and Territories.

SPEECH.PARA: This initiative of Mr Dawkins is long overdue and-surprise, surprise-mirrors the policies already announced by the coalition at the last election. However, schools and parents must be cautious that the Minister does not force non-government schools into the kind of `cooperation' he is now forcing on our universities and colleges. The contrast between the Opposition's approach to schools policy and the Government's approach is the same contrast that I earlier outlined with regard to higher education policy. Australians must ensure that educational choice is preserved and that the proposed reforms do not bring schools into a single low level standard dictated by Canberra. Whatever other developments are foreshadowed in the schools area, we want more than consult- ation-we want local initiative.

The alarm bells have already begun to ring. For example, non-government schools have had to fight hard to gain any input into Government policy, despite the fact that almost 30 per cent of Australian children attend non-government schools. Let me make it clear that the coalition supports moves to coordinate assessment methods and places a much stronger emphasis on the matter of basic skills in a core curriculum. When in government the coalition will establish a national schools monitoring program to promote sound educational practices and reward excellence. An independent investigation will also be launched into the quality of teacher training.

We have seen evidence of the Minister's concern for standards and standardisation but we have seen nothing of his commitment. There is nothing in this Bill to show any kind of commitment at all by this Labor Government to the dual system of education that operates in our schools. He has no interest whatsoever other than to impede Australia's non-government schools. Thirty per cent of Australian children attend non-government schools. At least another 20 per cent of Australian parents wish that they could send their children to non-government schools. But this Government has done nothing but impede that opportunity for Australian families.

The Minister's most significant failure in school education concerns not what he has done or plans to do but his failure to correct the damaging policies of his predecessor, Senator Susan Ryan, who was the Minister for five years. The Minister has failed to abolish the intrusive `accountability' provisions for non-government schools and the restrictive `new schools' policy which deliberately sets out to restrict the development of new non-government schools. In contrast with Labor's continuing attempts to stifle non-government schools, the Liberal and National parties' policies will increase recurrent grants to all non-government schools. I repeat: in a matter of months, when in government, the Liberal and National parties will increase recurrent grants to all non-government schools. There will be no decrease with respect to government schools. Mr Chairman, perhaps I need to explain again very briefly how that is a responsible policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before you develop the policy too far, Senator Teague, I remind you that we are now at the committee stage. Your remarks would be more appropriate in a second reading debate. You should not develop too far your remarks in regard to the policy area.

—Thank you for your advice, Mr Chairman. I will stick to that. I conclude my committee stage remarks on this point: what I have just outlined on behalf of the Opposition is responsible. When any student moves from enrolment in a government school to enrolment in a non-government school, the taxpayers' average contribution to the recurrent cost of that enrolment goes from 100 per cent to 50 per cent. Every time a family decides to move a child from a government school to a non-government school the taxpayer saves money. It is one of those happy situations where the Government and the taxpayers win. That is why there is a very sharp difference between the present Labor Government, that is failing in the area of schools, and the Liberal and National parties in respect of the policy I have touched upon. With regard to the Bills that are before us, I wanted to make it entirely clear to the Committee that we will take a quite different approach in the schools area. I am sure that the Committee would have wanted to have known all of those things.

—I have some questions to ask the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus). Firstly, I refer to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1989. The Signadou College of Education has now been placed under the responsibility of the Australian Capital Territory. Can the Minister indicate what discussions the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has had with his counterpart in the Australian Capital Territory for that move to occur or was it a matter of fiat on behalf of the Commonwealth? Secondly, if discussions did take place, was anything said at that time or at other times with regard to the position of the Canberra College of Advanced Education?

—At this stage I cannot give Senator Macklin any details. The advisers are not acutely aware of any detailed discussions that have taken place. I shall take this question on notice, see what discussions the Minister has had and then get back to the honourable senator.

—I thank the Minister. Clause 4 (b) of the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1989 proposes new definitions, amongst which is a definition for `full-time student'. I do not know whether the advisers were present the last time we had a discussion about what a full time student was. Perhaps they might be able to enlighten us this time. It seems that a full time student now means a student who, under the regulations, is to be treated as a full time student. That is almost as illuminating as the last definition. Can the Minister tell us precisely how a full time student is defined under the regulations?
—I am advised that a full time student will be a person who, under the regulations, is committed to undergoing three-quarters of a full time workload.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, we have the same problem with that definition as we had last time. Basically the story then went like this: a full time student is one who takes a full time course. To find out what a full time course is, one has to ask the institutions. We rang around the institutions and we were told that we had to ask the Department of Education. We rang the Department of Education which said that we needed to speak to the institutions. I gave up at that point. Subsequently, I was told that a full time student is one who is defined as a full time student. I happen to be interested in this because the ability of a student to get Austudy hinges on this definition. By and large, it is very important to determine who is a full time student. It is not quite as easy to do this as a lot of people seem to imagine. The complexities of who ends up being a full time student are sometimes quite horrific. I know that Senator Patterson would be only too well aware of this as she was involved for a long time in trying to determine these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Given the history of this matter, fairly obviously the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), on the advice of his Department, has now felt the need to change this piece of legislation. Can the Minister indicate what that advice was and why the definition which he clung to like death the last time we went down this track is now to be changed? There has to be a reason why we are changing the legislation. Perhaps somebody might know.

TALK.START.PARA: —There does not have to be a reason.

—We found out last Friday that there does not have to be a reason. Perhaps this might be another one of those matters. While the Minister is finding out that answer, I have another question with regard to clause 4 (f) which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A person who, although employed by the Commonwealth, performs services for the Commonwealth shall be taken, for the purposes of this Act, to be included within the definition of `employee' . . .

I am not quite sure what `performs services for the Commonwealth' actually means. It could mean anything. It could mean a lot of things; it generally does. Presumably some problems have arisen with regard to the proposed omission of subsection (3) and the proposed substitution of the new subsection. Could the Minister give us an example of a particular person who, although not employed, is performing services and who now comes under the definition of `employee'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to Senator Macklin's first question, I ask him to compare the definition of `full time student' in clause 4 (b) to the existing definition. The substantive change has been to delete from the definition reference to `class of students'. Essentially when assessing whether someone is a full time student, the Department makes the assessment on the basis of whether that person is doing three- quarters of a full time workload which in turn is based on the workload needed to complete a course in the minimum time. The assessment is also made on the basis of the individual institution's handbook of courses that applies to a particular student. The only difference between what is in the Bill and what is in the Act is the omission of the expression `class of student'; so we are looking at an individualisation of that assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of Senator Macklin's second point about who is in the service of the Commonwealth, the change essentially clarifies the word `employee'. The example one would be looking for under the Bill is a consultant who acts for the department. Such a consultant would come under the proposed definition whereas that person probably would not have come under the definition in the existing law.
Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motions
Debate resumed from 8 March and 26 May, on motions by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Boswell) proposed:

That the proposed amendments to Sections 3, 3a, 4, 5, 6, 12 and 36a of the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974, contained in clauses 55 to 61 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in October 1989, with particular reference to the following matters:
(a) effects of the change from the existing system;
(b) the present established services and the effectiveness of the delivery of those services for the benefit of clients;
(c) the effectiveness of the proposed new guidelines under the Act;
(d) whether the delivery of services under the Act will be more beneficial to clients;
(e) the cost of change from existing services to the new services;
(f) the need for choice by individuals as to the type of accommodation that is best for their particular purposes;
(g) whether there is a limitation of choice under the new guidelines as opposed to the existing guidelines;

(h) the consequences of the relative degree for incapacity for intellectually disabled people, including the desirability of housing these people in existing-type accommodation, as opposed to the new type proposed;
(i) difference in capital cost and current funding between the existing and proposed systems;
(k) the optimal degree of care that may be maintained under the new proposals, suitable to the degree of incapacity;
(l) the benefits or the disadvantages to clients in exposing them to a change of lifestyle if the new guidelines were to be introduced;
(m) necessity for the contract in the changeover; and
(n) a comparative assessment of the advantages and disadvantages of the existing and proposed guidelines.
Motion (by Senator Puplick) proposed:
(1) That a select committee, to be known as the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, be appointed to inquire into and report upon:
(a) the meaning of clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, (hereinafter referred to as ``the Bill'');
(b) the implications of clause 10 of the Bill for the medical profession in general, general practitioners in particular, and various categories of patients;
(c) whether the Senate should approve of clause 10 of the Bill, or whether the clause should be amended, and if so, in what respects it should be amended; and
(d) the effectiveness of the current health insurance industry structure, and in particular-
(i) the ability of Hospital Medicare to meet its two main objectives, namely, accessibility and equity, and the type of restructuring which may be necessary to assist in this regard,
(ii) the role of the private sector in providing hospital care and whether the current health insurance industry structure supports that role,
(iii) the relevance of community rating in a system which has Hospital Medicare as an alternative to health insurance,
(iv) whether the Federal Government has a role in supporting a health insurance industry based on community rating and now it can provide such support,
(v) what kinds and levels of benefits should be provided by health insurance organisations and the extent to which benefits should cover hospital costs,

(vi) the level of contribution rates required to be set by funds having regard to their own administrative costs, benefits payable and the willingness of people to contribute to private insurance funds,
(vii) the rules governing benefit payments and portability of fund membership,

(viii) the expenses incurred by funds in administration and management, including the payment of benefits and the level of reserves needed to ensure the funds' ability to meet their liabilities to contributors,
(ix) the investment policies, overall management, administration and financial operations of funds in relation to their reserves and other contribution moneys,
(x) the extent of effective contributor representation in the administration and policy making of the funds,
(xi) current recruiting activities employed by the funds and the extent and form of competition between them that is desirable, and
(xii) whether the interests of contributors would be better served if there were a greater or lesser number of registered organisations.
(2) That the Committee consist of six members, to be nominated as follows:
(a) three to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) two to be nominated by the leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(3) That the Committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) that the Chairman of the Committee be a Government Senator appointed by and from the members of the Committee.

(5) That the Chairman of the committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee, who is a non-Government Senator, to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That the quorum of the Committee be three members.

(8) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and that the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(9) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(10) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That the Committee report to the Senate on or before the first sitting day in September 1989.

(13) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may provide the report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy-President, and, in that event:
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate;
(b) the publication of the report is authorised by this Resolution;
(c) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report; and
(d) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a package of legislation-the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, which is the major Bill, the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill 1989 and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Bill 1988. The Senate also has before it motions regarding the establishment of a new Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Insurance and the reference of a particular matter to an existing Senate standing committee. In relation to the health aspects of this legislation, the Senate has before it a Bill which constitutes the next step to patch up this ramshackle, shambling and discredited health system of Medicare, predicated as it is not on the need to deliver quality health care at affordable costs but rather on this Government's ideological prejudices to sustain Medicare and to sustain it at all costs, in the face of all evidence that what it in fact requires is radical surgery. Above all, this legislation is a desperate, bankrupt attempt to provide a bandaid solution to the health care and cost crisis, and to take Medicare off the political agenda until after the next election. Let me tell this Government that that stratagem will not work. Only radical surgery will work. Only a complete overhaul of the service and costing elements of our health care system will work. In fact, only a change of government will work.

SPEECH.PARA: There are six key elements in relation to health matters to be dealt with in this legislation. The first is to amend the Australian Institute of Health Act 1987 to strengthen the confidentiality provisions of that Act. The second is to establish a new vocational register for general practitioners and to provide a system of differential rebates to be paid for their medical services. The third is to fix up the Government's own errors in the provision of Medicare rebates for pathology services. The fourth, under section 17 of this Bill, is to prohibit certain medical insurance contracts being established. The fifth is to provide a new system for paying fees for day care services. Finally, the sixth is to increase payments in the health insurance system as far as the provision of assistance to the health reinsurance pool is concerned.

Let me indicate at this stage the Opposition's general approach to each of those questions. We support the amendments dealing with the Australian Institute of Health. We oppose the amendments relating to the establishment of a vocational register and we have moved for the establishment of a Senate select committee to investigate this matter further. At the committee stage we will move an amendment to clause 10 to prevent that system from coming into operation until such time as the Senate has considered this matter again after the committee has reported. We support that section of the legislation which relates to pathology services. We do not oppose that part of the legislation which relates to the prohibition on the writing of certain insurance contracts. We simply draw attention to this Government's continued interference with insurance arrangements made by individuals to provide for coverage of their own personal health care requirements. We oppose that part of the legislation which relates to the provision of day care services. We oppose that section of the legislation which relates to the reinsurance arrangements. We will not, however, vote against it; we will allow it to be passed by the Senate but will move to refer it to the proposed Senate Select Committee for its consideration of matters relating to the wider question of health care in general and health insurance in particular.

The legislation that deals with the Australian Institute of Health provides for an increase in the confidentiality provisions as far as they govern the Australian Institute of Health. We support that. This Government has a most pathetic and lamentable record as far as the protection of the confidentiality of medical information in the hands of the government is concerned. We have seen repeatedly, deliberate leaks from the Health Insurance Commission designed to embarrass doctors, and even designed to put on the public record details of the individual incomes of doctors. We have seen instances in which information in the hands of Medicare, of the Health Insurance Commission, has been made public. Enrolment files with lists of personal identification information have been made public; claimants' history files have been made public; and providers' files have been made public. At no stage has the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) been prepared to undertake the necessary prosecutions which should have followed those particular breaches.

Those of us who served on the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card will remember the Australian Institute of Health coming before that Committee in order to secure for itself access to the information on the proposed Australia Card. The Government's submission, the Green Paper, dated 6 February 1986, lists the details of the proposed uses regarding the Australia Card that the Australian Institute of Health wanted to have in terms of access to information on the record. For example, if one looks at the submission made to the Joint Select Committee in evidence on 25 February 1986 one sees that the officers came before the Committee to tell it that they needed access to this information to compile and keep up to date something which was quaintly called the `national death index'. We believe that the Australian Institute of Health has a significant role to play in the provision of statistical information about Australia's health. When the first biennial report of the Australian Institute of Health was tabled I spoke in the Senate and drew attention to the fact that the report was, in my view, somewhat politicised and partisan. I was critical of that. For those reasons, we are particularly pleased to see attempts now being made to strengthen that Institute's confidentiality provisions.

The second issue to which I wish to refer briefly is the Government's attempt to correct its own errors in relation to the provision of Medicare rebates for pathology services. The Minister, in his second reading speech, goes through a detailed recitation of the way in which pathology fees have been established, the work of the Pathology Services Advisory Committee and now to be replaced and the promulgation of new tables for the payment of rebates. When we debated this matter late last year the Opposition moved for certain pathology rebate tables to be disallowed. We thought the basis upon which the Government was proceeding was faulty. The Australian Democrats originally supported us in that particular endeavour. They then changed their minds and the Senate did not disallow the necessary regulations. As a result the matter was taken to court and a hearing was commenced and indeed concluded before His Honour Mr Justice Gummow in the Federal Court of Australia in December 1988. His Honour, in his judgment on that particular occasion, was quite scathing both of the immediate operations of the Pathology Services Advisory Committee and of its advisers. For example, he said-as we had claimed in the debate-that the claim which was being made by the Government that there would only be an overall reduction of 5 to 8 per cent in incomes for pathology practices was, in His Honour's words `markedly to overstate what had taken place' in terms of the calculations that had allegedly been made to establish that figure. We said that at the time. The Government of course abused us roundly. It said that we did not know what we were talking about. It said that it had expert advice and that 5 to 8 per cent was of course correct. But as soon as the Government got into court, a judge of the Federal Court nailed it to the wall for the deceptive way in which it dealt with the Senate on that occasion. His Honour, later on in his judgment, made this point about the operation of the Committee, saying:
. . . it failed to perform its functions in accordance with the principles determined by the Minister . . .

As a result of that failure the pathology table was struck down. We reverted to an earlier, somewhat unsatisfactory, pathology table. These amendments from the Government to correct an error that it made, which we told it it had made, which it denied having made and which it was exposed as having made by the Federal Court of Australia, are now welcome.

We then come to day care services. The Opposition has no in-principle objection to the provision for arrangements to be entered into to take account of new surgical and treatment techniques which facilitate day only hospital treatment and encourage greater use of these techniques. Nevertheless, we do not believe that the Minister for Community Services and Health has consulted adequately with the relevant people in the medical community in order to be secure in the introduction of this system, which is dealt with in clauses 20 to 22 of the legislation. Indeed, speaking in the House of Representatives on 30 May, the Minister for Community Services and Health, while indicating that the proposal had been taken to the Australian Health Ministers Conference, said:
It is true that we have not consulted with the National Day Surgery Advisory Committee . . .

That Committee, which is a committee of the Royal Australian College of Surgeons, should have been consulted. Its agreement should have been sought before proceeding with this particular part of the legislation. There is a report in the Medical Letter No. 690 of 6 April 1989 stating that the Royal Australian College of Surgeons has objected, in principle, to a proposal by the Department of Community Services and Health to change the eligibility requirements for benefits for day surgery endoscopy procedures. If one looks at the November 1987, fairly thin four-page report on discretionary surgery by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs-we are told it could not actually get any information from the Department on these very matters-one sees once again that some significant issues are raised there about consultation and cooperation. We do not believe that this part of the legislation should be enacted without that proper consultation, particularly with the surgeons who, after all, will be the ones primarily interested in questions of rebates dealing with day care surgery and procedures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty per cent endoscopy.

—My learned colleague behind me draws attention to that particular matter which also effects the interests of physicians. He, a well known expert with a device I think called a sigmoidoscope, will undoubtedly have something to say about that in due course. As I said earlier, this legislation interferes in the contracts between individuals and the providers of health insurance arrangements. In fact, clause 17 of the legislation provides for the prohibition of certain insurance contracts which individuals might want to take out which, in the view of the Opposition, constitutes an improper interference in the way in which people are entitled to determine exactly what they want provided in their own health care services. As I said in my earlier remarks, we do not oppose that section of the legislation; we simply draw attention to our in-principle objection to this whole attitude.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to reinsurance. I propose to deal with reinsurance, differential fees for general practitioner services and the establishment of the vocational register in far greater detail when we come to the committee stages of this legislation. Therefore, I shall touch only briefly on the issues at this stage of the second reading debate. The reinsurance arrangements proposed in this legislation are in fact simply bandaid arrangements to prop up the discredited and disreputable Medicare system. The Government's proposal will do nothing to achieve long term improvements in the private health insurance system. It will do nothing to protect the insured aged from further increases in their contribution rates. In fact, it is more likely to worsen the system by driving good risks out of the private insurance system. Indeed, one knows that for approximately every one per cent drop in those privately insured there is an additional cost to Medicare-that is to the Government or rather to the taxpayer-of between $80m and $90m. That stands in sharp contrast to the fact that this legislation is proposing a one-off, totally inadequate subsidy to the reinsurance pool of some $20m.

The Government has behaved in the most shameful fashion as far as this part of the legislation is concerned. It, together with its allies in a certain section of the health insurance industry, has attempted to frighten, to scare and to worry the aged in our community by claiming that failure to pass this legislation in precisely the form in which the Government wants it passed would result in higher costs to the elderly. No government has so pathetic a record as the Hawke Labor Government of attempting to use the fears and concerns of elderly Australians for its own cheap, grubby and disreputable political purposes. Nowhere has this been more evident, nowhere has this been more stark, than in its attempts to frighten the elderly on the one issue about which they are most properly concerned; namely, the provision of long term health care arrangements for themselves.
