It is for that reason that we propose to ensure that there is a proper examination of these health insurance issues by the reference to the Senate Select Committee for which I have already moved.

The Government has attempted to band- aid this problem by providing for a subsidy to the reinsurance pool of some $20m. Nothing could be more pathetic than this Government's record in terms of the Commonwealth contribution to the Health Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund. The amounts contributed to that pool from 1976-77 to 1988-89 were as follows: in 1978, 1979 and 1980 a sum of $50m each year; in 1981, $125m; in 1982 and 1983, $100m each year; in 1984 and 1985, $20m each year; in 1986, $5m; and in 1987, 1988 and 1989, it was a meagre $1m each year. That is the record of this discredited and disreputable Government as far as reinsurance arrangements are concerned. Now, all of a sudden, for no legitimate purpose other than to bandaid the rotten Medicare system beyond the time of the next Federal election, $20m has been found to go into the reinsurance pool. The Hawke Government's record in each of the last three years of only $1m a year and $5m in the year before that, when at the peak in 1981 under the last Liberal Government the reinsurance pool was being assisted to the sum of $125m, indicates the degree to which this Labor Government has no real concern about the long term viability and stability of private health insurance arrangements in this country.

I come finally to the question of general practitioners, the vocational register and the establishment of a system of differential rebates. Despite the enormous amount of mail that has been coming in on this subject, there has also been a very clear expression within the wider community of general practitioners of what this actually amounts to-a cosy, closed shop deal done between the Government and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, which has written to all of its members asking them to write to senators demanding that they support this legislation. Yet from general practitioners we receive correspondence that says, for example:

I have been asked by letter from The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners to write to N.S.W. Senators seeking their support for early passage of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. I wish, however, to voice my opposition to the cosy relationship that the college and the government have formed. I hope the legislation fails.
Another one writes:

Although the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners was involved in negotiations for the package, the members of the College-of which I am one-were not consulted before its acceptance by the leadership. I believe most working doctors will find the new system confusing, contributing to problems with patients and Medicare.
Another writes:

I am absolutely disgusted that, despite a clear majority vote by College members to the contrary about 3 months ago, the College Council has entered into an `Agreement' with Dr Blewett without further consulting members at an Extra Ordinary General Meeting, or by plebiscite.
I have a great number of such letters. A report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 27 May states:

Last Monday 1,500 medical registrars, medical students and women doctors in Melbourne backed the AMA's opposition to the accord and declared themselves `absolutely disgusted' by the college's actions.

What has this Government done about any of these matters? The Opposition has for some time been pressing the Government on the necessity to ensure that there is a proper level of support for continuing medical education. My colleague Senator Peter Baume will undoubtedly be touching on this matter. I well remember speaking supportively in this chamber some time ago on the Doherty report-Australian Medical Education and Workforce into the 21st Century-all 700-odd pages of it. It was brought down in April 1988, but has not yet been responded to by this Government with any degree of adequacy. For a whole 12 months it had before it a report on continuing medical education, and absolutely nothing has been done or said about it and no commitment made. Yet the Government comes in here making noises about its preferred scheme for continuing medical education, the thimble and pea trick of increased rebates around the place. Of course, it does not tell the general practitioners or this Parliament about some of the hooks that go into all of this. When have we heard the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health in this place, the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), come clean on the question of what is to be done by a body called the Independent Peer Review Organisation (IPRO)? Here we are to have yet another statutory body set up by this Government, being secretly negotiated at the moment. It is going to have the oversight of this particular part of the legislation. It will be able to conduct selective professional audits. General practitioners who enrol on the vocational register will have to put themselves under the control of the Independent Peer Review Organisation. According to the operating principles:
The IPRO will have access to data necessary for the efficient implementation of its processes.

I am aware of no organisation in this country which has a better track record than the Department of Community Services and Health in gestapo-like operations, using every possible intrusive procedure, linked with every attempt to leak when politically necessary. The Minister's advisers can smile and giggle all they like, but people in the medical profession and people in the wider community know full well about the intrusive nature, the interference, the lack of security and the total politicisation of personal data to the advantage of the Government and the Health Insurance Commission whenever and wherever they see the political mileage in so doing. Here we have yet another body, this Independent Peer Review Organisation, with 25 or so operating principles, but nobody has been telling the Senate what they are. The Minister has not been telling the Parliament or the public what they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the doctors.
—As my colleague Senator Sheil says, or the doctors. The operating principles state:

SPEECH.PARA: Practitioners and auditors may exchange billing and clinical information. The audit report will remain confidential to the practitioner and the IPRO.

Well, I will be a Dutchman if that actually occurs, given the track record of the Community Services and Health Department and the Health Insurance Commission in maintaining confidentiality. Another principle states:
Information received by auditors at audit will not be available for civil action.
What civil action? This is not spelt out. Presumably, for people who are rorting the health insurance system there will be penalties attached. Another principle states:
The IPRO will be required to notify the relevant authority in instances of suspected fraud or suspected professional negligence or incompetence.

So it will not just monitor the financial standards, the differential rebates; the body will deal with professional negligence or incompetence. Since when was there an agreement accepted by the bulk of general practitioners for yet another organisation to monitor things such as professional standards and levels of competence? I hope that when we reach the committee stage the Minister will have some pretty good answers about the Independent Peer Review Organisation. He will need some pretty good answers if he expects to get the legislation through this chamber.

The legislation has been criticised, quite properly, for the extent to which it will disadvantage particular groups. It will disadvantage women doctors, women and children who particularly seek to be the patients of women doctors, people resident in country areas, university students and those seeking to enter the medical profession in the years ahead, and the terminally ill. I propose to turn to each of those in due course. Madam Acting Deputy President, undoubtedly you would be interested in the extent to which this scheme flies in the very face of the Government's own policies which it announced at the national women's health policy release in March 1989, because it discriminates against women practising medicine as general practitioners in a way to which I will come in some considerable detail during the committee stage of the Bill.

A number of matters are involved in this very complicated piece of legislation. We have moved that clause 10 of the Bill, which deals with general practitioners, be referred to the proposed select committee and we have moved a more extensive reference which would allow the same committee to examine the general nature of private health insurance and reinsurance arrangements. My colleague Senator Boswell will take steps to seek a reference to a standing committee of the disability service provisions of this complex piece of legislation. As we indicated the other day, we will be seeking to bring about a situation in which the Department of Community Services and Health will be required to provide a 008 number service for people who are located some distance from the nearest regional offices of the Depart- ment.

As I said when I began my speech, there will be a very complicated debate at the committee stage. However, a fundamental principle is involved here and it is this: this piece of legislation represents a feeble attempt to take Medicare and the question of health insurance off the political agenda until after the next general election. That will not work because the system is so manifestly in need of radical surgery-something that is exposed daily. It will not work, quite simply, because the system is incapable of being reformed by the piecemeal tinkering which this Bill represents and which the Minister is attempting to achieve. During this debate and in the course of the committee's inquiry, we intend to make that point abundantly clear so that the people of Australia will have it drawn to their attention that this Government is interested not in their health but simply in the politics of survival. That strategy simply will not work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of my colleague Senator Puplick, who has addressed the health aspects of the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Bill and the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. I wish to direct my comments first to the community services part of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. The Bill is part of a staged development of altered care for our frail aged. Basically, it sets out to proceed to needs-based planning with regard to applications for additional hostel care. It proposes to turn away from the submission model of previous years. This concept has been in vogue for the last 18 months.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposals in the Bill are part of a 10-year plan that the Government implemented in 1986. The 10-year plan has eight stages. Basically, we are looking at the fifth stage of that plan. The Opposition approved the direction taken by the Government in the amendments to the original legislation. In the 1986-87 Budget, the Government made a commitment to begin the process of redistributing resources for the care of aged people from nursing homes to alternative, less institutional forms of residential care, and community care services.

Cemented in the Bill is a Government proposal to provide 60 hostel places for every 1,000 frail aged persons. At the same time, nursing home bed availability will be reduced. Forty nursing home beds will be available for every 1,000 frail aged persons. Under the Government's new funding arrangements for hostels and nursing homes, and categorisation of patients, this is bound to lead to a reduction in the quality of care that is able to be provided. Under the new fee arrangements, known as CAM-care aggregated module-covering the cost of employing specified standard levels of nursing and personal care staff, there will be a cutback in funding and an inevitable reduction in the quality of care for the elderly. All sectors of the industry-private, public and voluntary-are concerned about the effect on patients as well as nursing staff.

The industry is also concerned about the report I'm Still an Individual, which, far from seeking to maintain the rights of our aged, threatens their quality of life by attacking the voluntary and private sectors which are charged with the delivery of providing the service and that quality. The report recommended sweeping reforms to protect the rights of older people in nursing homes and hostels. It found that abuses `were commonly entrenched in the daily routines of almost all homes and hostels'. The Opposition refutes that report. At seminars held around the country, that was proved to be the exception rather than the rule. I understand that the final report has been submitted to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and will be distributed to nursing homes and hostels shortly. The industry has demanded that there be time for consultation before any of the recommendations in the report are implemented. I hope that the Minister will not act as hastily as he did last time in making the report public before the industry has had a chance to consider it.

During the committee stage of the Bill in the House of Representatives my colleague Mr Braithwaite proposed an amendment relating to the quota of financially disadvantaged residents that hostels have to take under the legislation, under threat of losing their recurrent subsidies. That is something that has caused great concern to church groups throughout Australia. The precedent for the Minister to be able to set conditions relating to recurrent subsidies goes back to earlier community services legislation of 1987-the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act. Certain amendments were made to the Act which gave the Minister fairly wide discretion in administering general provisions within the Act. One of the aspects of the 1987 amendments was the introduction under section 10f of general conditions of recurrent grants. Following subsections allow the Minister to introduce these provisions.

At the time the Opposition agreed with those general provisions because they seemed to be in keeping with what the Opposition had in mind by way of reforms for the aged and frail aged. The amendment gave the Minister wide powers-but with very little accountability at the end. The Government has said that in order for a hostel to continue to receive recurrent subsidies, it must have a 20 per cent quota of financially disadvantaged residents. Hostel owners had to sign an agreement to that effect by 10 January 1989, under threat of losing their subsidies. I can see no reason why people who have saved for their old age must have those savings amortised across people who have made no such provisions. That is totally wrong, and we will move an amendment to that effect at the committee stage.

Many of the hostels involved, particularly those built by the churches-the Uniting Church has many such hostels-were funded by residents, by people borrowing money and committing themselves to repaying the capital. This very often involved their own churches, thus relieving the Government of the responsibility of paying the capital moneys to build the facility. Members of these organisations went out and raised money through residents-through people borrowing to get into these places-on the understanding that recurrent funding would be available for the operation of that facility. This was supposed to be a good deal for the Commonwealth, whereby the Commonwealth was relieved of the responsibility of finding the capital funds which it did not have. The facilities were being built and people were being provided with accommodation off their own bat.

The Government is now introducing arrangements which retrospectively alter the existing arrangements between individuals, who have put up their own capital and who have borrowed money to go into these places, and the Commonwealth. There was a not unreasonable expectation that recurrent funding would continue to be available where people had met the capital cost from their own resources. These arrangements were not for wealthy people. Hostels that were built under this resident funded arrangement were essentially for middle income, or near poor people who were perhaps selling their own houses, or liquidating whatever capital they could, to get themselves into places in which they would be able to provide for themselves in the frailty of their old age. The ones who were comfortably off, who could sell their houses and have money left over, were not interested in these types of hostel arrangements. It is wrong for the Government to seek to rewrite an agreement retrospectively.

Some of the hostels concerned, because of their group situation, have been able to aggregate their financially disadvantaged places and spread them around, but this was not something that was offered by the Minister. The industry sought aggregation on certain terms. The Minister responded with a letter in which he laid down three conditions under which aggregation could take place but these conditions could not, in all fairness, be fulfilled. One of the conditions of the financially disadvantaged placement is that residents would have to come from the immediate region. Under aggregation, people might have to move from one region to another. For example, if the Uniting Church hostel at Ryde has a 40 per cent figure, it wants to be able to offset the extra 20 per cent at another hostel, to make up the 20 per cent financially disadvantaged component there. This would mean that people would not have to be moved to a strange area, possibly away from their families, friends and local surroundings. This aspect needs to be clarified and the Opposition will move an amendment to clarify it. We see no financial disadvantage in aggregation to the Government. It will not mean more financing, it will just mean that the philosophy of a 20 per cent quota for the disadvantaged cannot, in some areas, be fulfilled.

I understand that following the debate on this Bill in the House of Representatives the Uniting Church was given an assurance from the Department of Community Services and Health that the quota of 20 per cent of financially disadvantaged persons could be achieved across all its hostels. This will give relief to the resident funded hostels where it is impossible to achieve the 20 per cent figure in the short term. We feel that the matter should be clarified once and for all, and that the principle should be established within the law. Therefore, we will pursue these amendments during the committee stage of the Bill.

I now turn to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. There are two areas of the Bill that I will cover in this debate, the first relating to nursing homes. Clauses 24 to 26 of the Bill propose amendments to the National Health Act 1953 to introduce provisions to prevent abuse of the resident classification system. Under current arrangements, nursing home proprietors are able to abuse the resident classification system by providing information leading to the classification of residents at unjustifiable levels, thereby obtaining excess benefits.

In connection with nursing homes and hostels, I have already mentioned funding and quality care. The message that we are receiving from those who direct assessments in the homes is that the assessment system is being changed. Whereas patients were assessed according to their need for quality of care, they are now assessed according to a ratio of funding which means that, in most cases, quality of care is no longer available. This is because nursing homes which must provide that care can no longer afford to do so. In general, these amendments to the National Health Act are acceptable to the Opposition, but we question some aspects of them. A situation of overclassification will be the result of one of two things: either ignorance of how it should be done properly, which means that people should be educated; or, persistent upgrading to obtain a benefit, which is what this part of the Bill seeks to correct. On the question of appeals, we do not believe that a decision of the secretary can be appealed fairly to the Minister. Therefore, we suggest as an option after the Minister's decision, referral to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. We shall also move an amendment in the third reading stage of the Bill.

Part 5 of the Bill is very important; it covers clauses 54 to 61. It proposes amendments to facilitate the phased transfer of all nursing homes for disabled persons from the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 to the Disability Services Act 1986 by June 1992. These changes were foreshadowed by the Minister in the Department's special bulletin entitled Transfer of Nursing Homes for Disabled Persons to the Disability Services Program issued in May 1988. This document outlined the process to be followed in bringing nursing homes for disabled persons under the legislative coverage of the Disability Services Act 1986. There are 65 nursing homes involved, although only 45 are attached to the nursing home sector. Seven of these 45 have signed contracts, leaving 38 to sign. We will oppose the amendments to part 5 of the Bill for the very good reason that the message we are getting from these 38 nursing homes is that they have no faith that the guidelines will do anything to assist them in the transition stage.

Many organisations have contacted my colleague Mr Braithwaite to voice their concern about the lack of flexibility under the Disability Services Act in regard to residential accommodation and other services for the disabled. They would like to be assured that services currently approved, and providing the necessary standards, will be allowed to continue in their own modem and be funded as previously. There are also reservations about the discretion of the Minister after 1992 on approvals and on admission criteria.

The Queensland Spastic Welfare League has indicated to the Opposition that there must be flexibility. The League wants it to be understood that a large number of people have disabilities that are so extensive that they would not be able to cope in smaller, cluster-type accommodation, or hostel accommodation. There is not the flexibility under the Disability Services Act for people to be able to draw on different sorts of accommodation. People at the League are also worried about the future of therapy centres. They say that the present thrust of the bureaucrats is to have these centres transferred to State governments because the State governments consider them to be health related, which is definitely not the case.

The North Queensland Society for Crippled Children is also worried about the total lack of flexibility under the Disability Services Act. That Society points out that what is appropriate for some people with a disability-physical or intellectual-is certainly not appropriate for others. Some people do not want to move from group homes out into the community, and they do not want another parent. According to the Society, some older people are getting very worried what will happen. Families are worried. They have security in knowing that their children are being cared for, and are content that these homes are caring for their disabled children. Mrs Martin, one of the directors of the North Queensland Society for Crippled Children, expressed concern about the nurses. Nurses are looking for other jobs; they see no future in their positions and are taking advantage of other courses. The Society is also worried about the effects that the proposed changes are already having on nursing staff. As I have said, many nurses are out now looking for other jobs.

The Queensland Bush Children's health scheme members would prefer not to move to the Disability Services Act because of the Act's inflexibility. The scheme's director said, `We do not know which way to turn, or which way we are going'. These people are very concerned. If they do not sign a contract they will not be funded and, if they sign a contract, they do not know what will happen to them. This is causing concern. They are caught between the devil and the deep blue sea. If they do not sign a contract their funds will be cut and, in many cases, they are quite sure that some of their patients will not be equipped to go into these different types of community homes.

Today I received a letter from a Bundaberg parents action group voicing concern about the dismantling of sheltered workshops and activity therapy centres; about elderly parents' fears for the future care of their disadvantaged sons and daughters; and about the frustration felt by service providers at the inflexible approach of the Department of Community Services and Health in the implementation of this legislation. These messages are constantly coming into our offices.

The Opposition has made it clear on numerous occasions that the Disability Services Act is not being administered properly and that the Minister is out of touch in respect of it. We believe that the Minister has isolated himself from the criticism of this legislation that is being levelled from a number of areas. The Minister has stepped away from it and left it to his Department to handle. It is premature and inappropriate for us to support this legislation which would effectively cut off from 1992 one source of funding to nursing homes that cater for, in particular, the severely intellectually disabled. In the committee stage I will be seeking to move a motion to refer this section of the legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

There is a lot of discontent in the community. I have received a letter from the Crowle nursing home. The people in that nursing home have been almost bribed by the Department to sign a contract. Perhaps the word `bribed' is too strong a term; they have certainly been put under the hammer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Coerced.

—Coerced, put under the hammer, forced; whatever you would like. The chief executive officer of Crowle nursing home has been told that, if he signs, the nursing home will have as much time as it likes to come up with a transitional plan. In the meantime the nursing home is guaranteed grants at least equal to last year's grants plus the consumer price index increase. Crowle nursing home has been told that there is a general shortage of funds and it was implied that, if it did not sign the contract, it was going to suffer. It was told that the formula, as per the Department's bulletin, would be strictly enforced and, in areas where the nursing home had not spent to its budget level, it would be stuck with that level in future years. This is very serious for Crowle nursing home. At present it is about $80,000 under in wages as it cannot fill certain positions.

SPEECH.PARA: This home feels that it is being coerced-and these are not my words-into signing a contract when it really does not have any faith in the Disability Services Act. It is caught. If it does not sign the contract it will not get any funding and if it does sign the contract it knows that it will not work. It is very apprehensive about the way the legislation will work. Therefore, I believe it is vitally important that this legislation go before a Senate committee to be examined so that everyone in the community services area can put their point of view and the Senate can reach a bipartisan conclusion. I hope that the Government will respond by supporting this reference to a Senate committee. It is important to give these people who look after our disabled-physically and intellectually disabled-some avenue to voice their concerns about how the legislation will or will not work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we are debating the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill 1989 and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Bill 1988. The principal piece of legislation incorporates seven Bills which amend various Acts of this Parliament. It is difficult to deal with this legislation because of the way in which it has been presented. But there are two sections in particular which have caused a great deal of concern to general practitioners and the private health insurance area, and it is those two sections with which I will be dealing most extensively. Both of them are particularly complex matters because they involve the assessment of detailed and esoteric data which is difficult to assess. A lot more time is required to collect figures and make assessments and, for that reason, we will be supporting the reference of both these matters to a Senate select committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Dealing sequentially with those matters, the first matter is the creation of a register for general practitioners and the circumstances that surround the creation of that register. I remind the Senate that doctors graduate after six years of university work and become registered after a further year of hospital work. It is a very long course and covers a wide range of subjects. If I might say so, it is a good general education but there is certainly insufficient training in that course-either in the university part of the course or in the hospital year-to train somebody to work as a general practitioner. Let me tell the Senate of my experience back in the 1950s when I did a medical course in Adelaide. I suppose that 50 per cent of the time of general practitioners is occupied with dealing with family related problems. We had only a dozen lectures in what was called psychological medicine, and those lectures covered everything from the most serious psychological disability through to the sorts of emotional traumas that beset families all the time-totally inadequate training for dealing with that part of a general practice which occupies about 50 per cent of a general practitioner's time. It was certainly disconcerting to go, as I did, from completing those six university years and my residency in Royal Adelaide Hospital to sitting across the desk from patients for the first time dealing with the sorts of problems that I felt I was ill-equipped to deal with following the training course that I had been given.

Of course, most doctors go into general practice. They learn on the job. They probably make a few mistakes initially, but I do not doubt that the majority of them become excellent general practitioners. Of course, that is recognised in the legislation which the Government is proposing because the register will contain the names of those doctors who have had a sufficient period as general practitioners and they will be recognised for the purposes of the register. But one of the consequences of this inadequacy of training is that general practice has been looked down upon by the academics in the universities. Certainly in my three years of clinical training, much of the training was done by specialists-we had no contact with general practitioners at all-or by those who taught for the hospital year. People going through that hospital year are taught largely by specialists. For that reason there is extremely little contact with general practitioners and with the sort of work that general practitioners have to deal with.

There has been very extensive lobbying on this Bill, particularly from organisations like the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and the Doctors Reform Society. Both of those bodies have pointed out that, in order to address this lack of status and lack of initial quality of general practitioners, they have been attempting for some years to get more appropriate training introduced within both the university years and the compulsory hospital year. They have been remarkably unsuccessful, in that apparently there is a perception by academics in the university or lack of academic rigour in general practice and a perception of lack of relevance by doctors who are themselves specialists and who are responsible for much of the training within the compulsory hospital year. Having spoken to a number of medical colleagues and having been lobbied very extensively on this matter over recent weeks, I understand that the quality of medical education still leaves a great deal to be desired with respect to education appropriate for general practice.

The Government's move is a serious attempt to raise the status of general practitioners in the eyes of the community and in the eyes of fellow practitioners, specialists and academics working in universities. It is also a serious attempt to raise the quality of general practice and to give recognition of that through the establishment of a register, the requirement for continuing medical education to remain on that register and the payment of a higher fee to those doctors whose names are on the register. It seems to me that the intention of this legislation is entirely laudable. It may well be the only way to go. By a rather ironic feedback mechanism, it may indeed bring about those very things that the College, the Doctors Reform Society and other organisations have been unable to achieve by other means. Once the status of general practice is recognised, once general practitioners are involved in continuing education, it may be that those doctors that are on the register will gain in status in the eyes of other doctors and that there will be a greater willingness to introduce general practice education back into the six university years and the compulsory post-graduate hospital year.

But this move by the Government has very seriously divided the medical profession. It is difficult to find any action by this Government in recent months which has so galvanised a group of people as the intention to set up this register. I must say that initially the majority of letters and phone calls I was receiving were totally opposed to this legislation-they were running at a ratio of about 10:1 against the legislation. There was a period about a fortnight ago when the numbers swung marginally the other way and the majority of those who were lobbying me were in favour of the legislation. But more recently, the numbers have swung back again very strongly against this legislation. Honourable senators will recall that last week I submitted a petition from 1,644 doctors from Victoria alone who were all opposed to this legislation. Even if the majority of those doctors misunderstood the legislation and its intention and could be persuaded that it was in their interests, I do not think it is appropriate for the Government to proceed at this time with legislation which clearly a large number of doctors either do not understand or do not want. There needs to be the interposition of a period of review by a committee so that those matters which perhaps have been unjustifiably misunderstood can be dealt with and fears allayed. Those matters which do have substance can be properly dealt with and brought before a committee. Perhaps this may lead to modification of the legislation.

The Australian Democrats, therefore, support the reference of this matter to a committee. We have slightly modified Senator Puplick's proposal to establish a Senate select committee to consider a reference relating to general practitioners and report by the first sitting day in August by asking the committee also to consider private insurance proposals, with which I will be dealing in a minute, and to report on that reference by the first sitting day in March next year.

Out of the lobbying which has gone on, one can already identify a number of matters which need to be addressed by that committee. Without foreshadowing how the committee may deal with these matters, I think it is worth while mentioning them because they have some substance. There is a need to give consideration to what body would be appropriate to accredit general practitioners. It may be that, in the lobbying that has gone on, there has been an element of politicking between the College and the Australian Medical Association. But let us leave that aside and accept that, particularly in medicine, groups of specialist practitioners have in the past set up colleges and gained accreditation and higher fees. As a general principle I believe that a body which provides accreditation which results in a higher fee being chargeable should, as far as possible, be independent of the professional in-group which benefits from that accreditation. I think that is something that needs to be addressed.

The terms by which a general practitioner shall get accreditation and remain accredited also need close scrutiny. There is a great deal of concern that, in some respects, the terms are quite excessive, particularly in relation to those people who may, for various reasons, fall below the requirement and then seek to go back on to the register later on. I also draw attention to something that is a bit of an oxymoron-that is, subspecialities of general practice. Several examples of this have been brought to my attention: for instance, those practitioners who choose to see mainly patients with sexually transmitted diseases. Family planning may be another one. If the proportion of patients they see gets to the point where the majority of their practice is occupied in that subspeciality then they may cease to be general practitioners for the purposes of the register and may only be able to attract a fee at a lower rate. That would seem to be unfair. The quality of the service that those practitioners are providing to their patients is at least as good as, and maybe even better than, that which they were providing when they were fully within general practice.
Finally, attention has been draw to the lack of any appeal mechanism in relation to the removal of a name from the register.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Ray, left Australia on Saturday on official Government business overseas. He will be absent from Question Time for the remainder of this period of sittings. During his absence Senator Ray will be attending the Geneva International Conference on Indo-Chinese Refugees. Any questions in relation to Senator Ray's portfolio, or those he represents, should be directed to Senator Richardson. Senator Richardson will also be the Manager of Government Business in the Senate for the same period.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, concerns the continuing crisis in China and the publicly expressed concern today about the safety of Australian diplomats, journalists and other citizens in that country. Has the Government reviewed the strength of its diplomatic response to the crisis in China? In particular, will it, as suggested last week by the Opposition, recall its ambassador for consultations-action which has now been taken by the Government of Canada? Is the Government now prepared to go further than the informal consultation with other countries to which the Minister referred on Friday and initiate concerted international pressure in an attempt to persuade the Chinese Government to abandon its policy of brutal repression and revenge? Finally, will the Minister table in the Senate the text of the letter of protest apparently sent by the Prime Minister to the Chinese Government?

—In response to the last part of the question in which I was asked to table the text of the letter, I do not have the letter; so at this stage I certainly cannot table it. I will see whether the Prime Minister is willing to have it tabled at some future time. In regard to the ambassador, I think Senator Hill's question acknowledged that the Canadian example did not represent a breaking of diplomatic relations but just a recalling of its ambassador for consultations, which in itself is a pretty serious diplomatic move. With regard to Australia's position, at this stage the Government has decided to leave our ambassador and some essential staff in Beijing in order to ensure that Australia retains an effective presence with which to monitor developments and convey our views to the Chinese Government. The recall of the ambassador would remove the most experienced Australian diplomat from Beijing and weaken the skeleton staff which is to remain. But the situation in China, although it seems to have clarified to some extent over the last few days, is still fairly fluid. At this stage the Government's judgment is that it is best to leave the ambassador in place.

—I ask a supplementary question. Am I to interpret the Minister's answer as indicating that the Government of Australia therefore has decided to take no further or additional diplomatic or other means to persuade the Chinese Government to take a more humane course of action? In particular, why will the Government not do as was mentioned in the question, to which the Minister has not responded-that is, go further than informal consultation with other countries and initiate concerted action through international means with our friends and allies to try to pressure China to abandon, as I said, its policy of brutal repression and revenge?

—To the best of my knowledge there is no change to the answer that I gave last Friday to the question of multilateral protest or other actions against China. If there has been any change to that, I will let Senator Hill know.

—Has the Minister for Resources seen claims that there is a high level of Government tax on the oil industry in Australia? How does this affect Australia's ranking on retail petrol prices among Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen those claims, I saw them again at the weekend. Esso Australia Ltd yet again has commenced an advertising campaign to try to persuade the Australian people that it ought to have a reduction in tax on its production out of Bass Strait. The Government has announced that it has commenced a review of Bass Strait excise, and that that review will culminate in any legislative change, if that is necessary, to take effect from 1 July 1990. We will shortly produce a discussion paper on excise and resource rent tax on crude oil production in Australia. In relation to the general advertising campaign that is once again hitting the news stands, this Government is reviewing the matter and the review will be comprehensive. Esso will have a chance to put its views to the review. After that comprehensive review there will be a decision and, if necessary, alteration.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the question Senator Devereux has asked me, I have before me a table of OECD nations showing the cost in Australian cents per litre of petrol purchased at the bowser. Italy charges 127c per litre. Australia, according to this list, charges 51c per litre and has the third lowest prices in the list. The only other countries in which petrol is cheaper are Canada at 48c and the United States of America at 39c. Every other OECD country charges higher retail prices per litre for petroleum than Australia; indeed, the major countries are listed in the upper end of that table. In terms of the tax take that the governments of the OECD countries extract from petroleum prices, 24c is taken from the 51c in Australia, but if we go to the top of the table, of the 127c extracted in Italy, 99c comprises tax. Once again, according to this table, Australia is the third lowest of any OECD country with regard to tax take. I table this document for the information of honourable senators. It dispels the allegation that there is a high tax rate in Australia in terms of petroleum retail prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance in what I might say is his unusual capacity as Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Government giving sympathetic consideration to an application by a consular officer of the Chinese Government to remain in Australia? Is the Government in a position to say whether it will grant any form of refuge to the officer, named in the media as Ms Dong Qi? If so, what status will she be given? If the Government is not yet in a position to say, and given the fact that Ms Dong is said to have left the Sydney Consulate four days ago, why is the Government taking so long to come to what would seem to be a rather simple decision?

—In response to the first part of the question concerning my unusual capacity as Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in Question Time, if I could follow the example set by a very modest former Labor politician, I am sure I will be the best Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in Question Time that there has ever been. As for the substance of the question, I can confirm that a Chinese official has been allowed to stay in Australia and that the request is being considered by the Government.
—Has been allowed to stay in Australia?
—No, has asked to stay in Australia and that the request is being considered by the Government.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Even for Senator Walsh, I would have to say that that response is less than wholly satisfactory. Taking up his response, my first question was: is the Government giving the request sympathetic consideration? Secondly, is the Government in a position to say? I take it from the Minister's response that the answer to that part of the question is no, it is not yet in a position to say. And thirdly, given that and given that the officer in question is said to have left the Sydney consulate four days ago, why is the Government taking so long to come to what would seem to be a rather simple decision?
—Are you trying to help this person or not?
—The answer to that interjection is that of course I am trying to help this person. The question I am asking is: why is the Government not helping?

—I am not sure that the facts of this case are as simple as Senator Stone seems to assume that they are. Senator Richardson has just had a word with me too. I am not sure, administratively, that this does not fall within the immigration portfolio rather than the foreign affairs portfolio. I am not trying to run away from the question. Among other things, so Senator Richardson tells me, for questions of confidentiality the Government does not wish to say any more at this stage about this issue. I do not believe that there is a well-established precedent anyway of instant decision making by governments on similar requests in the past.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Further to the letter I wrote to the Attorney last week proposing a change in thinking about domestic violence, in particular my suggestion that violent men be removed from the home to a hostel under a restraining injunction and provided with assistance to manage their violence, can the Minister say what is the Government's reaction to this? Can he say whether it will be raised for consideration by the State and Federal Attorneys-General?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Crowley has written to the Attorney-General putting forward a rather novel aid, that is, removing the person perpetrating violence from a household rather than removing the women and children who are sometimes the victims of violence by placing them in shelters with all the consequent disruption to schooling and the need for quite expensive support to be provided to a whole family which may move out of a violent household situation. Senator Crowley's suggestion, as I have read it in the press anyway, is that by removing the male perpetrator of the violence to a hostel or some such shelter, allowing the husband still to engage in employment, is a piece of lateral thinking and a novel approach which ought to be followed up. I have not had a chance yet to discuss this with the Attorney-General. But the Government has shared Senator Crowley's concern for the human and financial suffering faced by those who are victims of domestic violence. Indeed, it introduced legislation in this very territory, the Australian Capital Territory, as Senator Reid would know, based on a report to the Australian Law Reform Commission which enables victims to obtain an injunction in these circumstances. That injunctive relief is obviously an important protective device.

ANSWER.PARA: The introduction of domestic violence legislation and the provision of alternative accommodation for those who are subject to an injunction is, of course, primarily a State matter. In so far as the Australian Capital Territory legislation is available as a model for the States and the Northern Territory to look to, it will serve a nationwide purpose. Nevertheless, I understand the Attorney-General will be writing to his colleagues on the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General to draw to their attention Senator Crowley's particularly innovative proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I presume the Minister is aware of resolutions of the New South Wales Australian Labor Party State Conference over the weekend which called for: a tax surcharge on luxury imports; restrictions on foreign borrowings by the private sector and the abolition of negative gearing on those borrowings; a better deal for home buyers through some tax deductability on home loans; and an incentive to save through consumer price index indexation of savings for tax purposes. Does the Government agree that these actions, which the Australian Democrats have been pushing for several years, are essential to address the current account deficit and the interest rate crisis? Can the Minister indicate whether the Government will act on any or all of these measures and, if so, when? If it does not intend to act on any or all of these measures, what will the Government do to address the severe economic problems which now face Australia and, in particular, lower and middle income Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen press reports of motions carried at the New South Wales State Conference. I do not know whether they are entirely adequate or accurate reports. For at least some of the items I would say that their view of the world is simplistic.
—Unlike the Australian Democrats.

—Yes, as Senator Stone says, unlike the Australian Democrats. As for such specific things as raising taxes on luxury goods-Budget matters-I have consistently refused to confirm or deny reports of this nature. I will continue to do so for what I would have thought is the fairly obvious reason, that if I start either confirming or denying the latest rumour which some journalist is peddling my refusal to confirm or deny the next rumour which some other or the same journalist peddles will be interpreted as a confirmation of the rumour. I do not intend to depart from that practice.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I will say that if the Government was considering increasing sales tax on luxury goods I am sure that the Australian Democrats would be able to find some invalid pensioner who drinks Moet and cannot afford the additional sales tax which somebody might propose we should put on it. If the Democrats could not find such an invalid pensioner I am sure some of the populists who run television and talk back shows would be able to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Leaving aside the Minister's usual rhetoric that he comes up with when he does not know the answers to questions, I ask him why he thinks these suggestions are more simplistic than, for example, cutting company tax by 20 per cent when some companies are not paying any at all? Why does the Minister prefer to have a system continue where there are such inequities that people who invest in real estate can get a tax deduction but people who borrow for their own home cannot? Many of the other things that are listed in this press report would go some way to alleviating the burden on low and middle income earners and placing it on the wealthy where it belongs.

—I am aware of the Democrats' rhetoric for higher taxation on the wealthy so long as the wealthy remain an abstract group. But I am more equally aware of the Democrats' timidity at imposing taxes which can be specified to hit a particular group of the wealthy. I have been asked why I said it is simplistic. I have only read the press reports, so I do not know the full text of the motions which were carried. However, let me take, for example, taxation deductability for interest paid on housing mortgages. If that were to be applied across the board it would clearly provide an additional incentive for investment. There are, and have been for many decades of course, very substantial incentives for expenditure in owner occupied housing. If the interest payments on housing mortgages were to be allowed as a tax deduction, that would provide a very major incentive for further expenditure on owner occupied housing which must have the effect of leading at least some capital investment away from the tradable goods sector. It would also, of course, knock a very substantial hole in government revenue which would have to be covered by expenditure reductions elsewhere, increased taxes somewhere else or a blow-out of the Budget deficit; or if one would like to put it in modern terms-the sort of terms which nobody in Australia would have ever expected to be relevant to the underlying reality until very recently-a reduction in the Budget surplus.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA: NUCLEAR WEAPONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: Given the situation in China, is the Minister concerned that China is the third largest nuclear weapons state in the world, with an estimated 1,300 nuclear weapons at the disposal of the military and party leadership and an expanding nuclear navy? Does the Government know where the chain of command for nuclear weapons lies in China at the moment, which is of particular concern with a party leadership which has shown that it will not stop at mowing down its own people in the capital city in front of the world's media?

—I am getting a variety of questions today. This one is from Senator Vallentine, the peacenik who joined the Country Party during the Vietnam war. I do not know whether China has 1,300 nuclear weapons at its disposal, nor am I able to answer the question about the chain of command for nuclear weapons in China. As far as the general chain of command in China is concerned, it appears that senior leader Deng Xiaoping, President Yan Shangkun and Premier Li Peng are in dominant positions in the party and state leadership.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I thought I would ask my question while the Minister's mind was on China. Is the Minister aware that Amnesty International has documented 1,500 executions in the People's Republic of China since 1983, including an incident in northern China in September of that year, when 45 people were dragged to wooden stakes and shot in the head by police at close range? Is the Minister aware of the physical and religious repression of the people of Tibet by the Government of China over those same years? On how many occasions since 1983, when and with what result has the Australian Government protested to the Government of China about the gross violations of human rights and political freedoms which have occurred in that country on a regular basis? Will the Minister arrange for the tabling in the Senate of a schedule and summary of such action as well as copies of any formal notes or letters of protest?

—I am not sure whether I noted down all of those questions. I do not know how many executions since 1983 Amnesty International believes it has confirmed-although the nice round figure of 1,500 suggests it is an approximation and not a precise measurement, and I guess is recognised by Amnesty International as such. I do not approve of capital punishment under any circumstances. I suspect that Senator Chaney shares that view. I note that it is not a view that is shared by the new Liberal Party Leader in Victoria-not that I am suggesting that he supports summary execution. I have been asked how many protests the Government has lodged since 1983 about actual or alleged breaches of human rights in China. I do not know. I will try to find out. The last part of the question extends that by asking whether I will table the schedule. I will refer that to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and/or the Prime Minister.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH-EASTERN FORESTS OF NEW SOUTH WALES: LOGGING

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources whether there has been any progress in resolving the dispute over logging in the south-eastern forests of New South Wales. Has the Minister received a reply yet to his request for a meeting with the New South Wales Minister for Natural Resources to try to bring about a resolution of the dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to the first part of the question is that no progress has been made. The answer to the second part of the question as to whether I have received a reply from the Minister for Natural Resources is yes, I have. I wrote to the Minister for Natural Resources on 6 June. In view of comments attributed to Nick Greiner, Premier of New South Wales, that he would direct his Minister to reopen talks with the Commonwealth on this matter, I wrote to Minister Causley inviting him to come to Canberra during last week or this week to have further discussions with me on the compromise proposal the Commonwealth has put forward to settle the issue. I received a letter in reply from Minister Causley, which I will shortly table, which acknowledges my correspondence and in an argumentative way seeks to take me to task for comments that I have made, although it is not specifically worded that way. It is a peculiar letter. It ends with this declaration:

ANSWER.PARA: I am concerned at the apparent misinterpretation of the current position between us. I would appreciate clarification before agreeing to further discussions.

I received that letter during the afternoon of Friday last and instantly faxed a reply to Minister Causley saying that if there were matters of confusion between us then the most sensible thing was to meet as soon as possible to settle those differences, particularly the dispute about the south-east forests. I am still awaiting a reply from him to the invitation to meet this week to settle the proposal, though I do not criticise him for this because yesterday was a public holiday in New South Wales.

This issue is now showing signs of becoming a sterile paper war between Minister Causley and me. If that emerged it would be regrettable. On 18 May I met Minister Causley and put a well-documented, well-researched and thoroughly authorised proposal to him about how we could settle the south-east forests dispute. On 30 May he replied saying in part that he had not studied all of the factors but, nonetheless, that he was not disposed to agree. After the Nick Greiner statement on 6 June I wrote to Minister Causley and I have now received further correspondence. The letter he wrote to which I have just referred and which I will now table raises a debating point which, in the context of this dispute, throws an interesting light on how Minister Causley seems to be handling the matter. It is a silly and stupid proposition that he has raised.

The argument between us is this: he says that there are not sufficient resources to enable us to conduct a 12-month biological study of the area. I have said to him that, according to calculations based on New South Wales Forestry Commission figures, there are sufficient resources; and, if he disagrees with my allegation and we find as the 12-month study nears completion there are inadequate resources, I will vary the proposal to guarantee that I deliver the proposition I have put to the sawmillers and to the industry in the south-east and will make additional resources available.

Minister Causley still says that there are not sufficient resources. I have then said that if he still discounts that proposition the State of New South Wales and the Commonwealth of Australia should form a joint monitoring group to assess whether the yield from each of the compartments cut, as we proceed through the study, matches our figures or whether there is need for early correction of our figures. He has not answered that proposition, nor has he answered the proposition that I have put as to how we make the figures good if I am in fact wrong. I believe that on all of the figures supplied I am not wrong and that Minister Causley has not answered any of the reasonable proposals I have put in order to break the deadlock on the issue. He now writes in a silly, stupid way that there needs to be further interchange of correspondence between us before he will agree even to meet to discuss a resolution.

I conclude by saying that I have addressed meetings of shop stewards from sawmills and rank and file workers from the Harris-Daishowa woodchip operation at Eden. They have endorsed the proposal subject to guarantees of job security for the 12 months of the study. I have spoken to the Bega and Bombala shire councils and to the Eden Chamber of Commerce. There is a strong view, shared by conservationists as well as industry and community figures, that there should be a quick settlement of this issue. I find it annoying and childish in the extreme that Minister Causley still holds off from even coming to meet the Commonwealth and pursuing any formula that we might be able to devise between us to settle this issue. I table the letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to the fact that, despite the Treasurer's assurance that the Government's superannuation changes would not diminish anyone's personal benefit by one cent, it is now acknowledged that up to 75,000 Queensland public servants face significant cuts in their superannuation benefit. Is he aware that the maximum lump sum benefit of approximately 200,000 Victorian and up to 26,000 Western Australian public servants whose superannuation benefits exceed reasonable benefit limits as currently prescribed and will start reducing the longer they serve after July 1990, will also be affected? In view of the Minister's assertion that only a handful of people will be disadvantaged and the fact that the figure is now 300,000, what will his Government do about it? I also refer the Minister to the comment attributed to him in Friday's Courier-Mail that the extent of reasonable benefits limits is not the subject of any superannuation Bills before the Senate. Is he aware that part 9, section 270, of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, currently before the Senate, is the operative section which applies the Government's proposed tax regime to State superannuation schemes, the taxation rate being dependent on whether funds are complying or non-complying? If so, does he maintain that the extent of reasonable benefits limits is not the subject of any superannuation Bills currently before the Senate?
—I point out to Senator Walsh that part of that question is anticipating debate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr President. For the record, I observe that Senator Puplick has not taken a point of order on those grounds as he is so fond of doing when questions come from this side of the House. I will have Senator Boswell's specific reference to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) checked. I was told on Friday that the reasonable benefits limits, or RBLs, are completely unrelated to the superannuation package which is before the Senate now. They may or may not be related to some other legislation which is before the Senate; I am not sure. The sheet of paper which Senator Boswell was good enough to give me on Friday afternoon contained a number of figures, some of which he has repeated in his question. I think the Treasurer's office would now have sent it to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) for an assessment. From my quick reading of them, the alleged losses were hypothetical losses based on an assumption that certain people would remain in government employment for a long period-I am not sure whether it is 10 or 20 years-additional to their existing service, or something like that. I expect that before too long the Treasurer will get and pass on to me an assessment from the ISC about that.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the overlap, if any, between the section which Senator Boswell cited-I did not have time to write it down fully-and RBLs, I will have that checked, but the advice that I received, admittedly quickly, on Friday afternoon was that the superannuation package, of I think five Bills in total, was not functionally related to the RBL question although the RBL is part of the Government's entire superannuation policy, as it should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware of recent calls for the Government's expenditure on pensions and benefits to be reduced through improved targeting? Does the term `improved targeting' usually mean tighter income testing? If the income test on the age pension were tightened, what effect would this have on the effective tax rate on aged people's superannuation moneys?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of calls from members of the Opposition, and especially from the new shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, for improved-that is, tighter-targeting of welfare benefits. The answer to the last part of the question in which I am asked what effect tighter targeting would have on aged people who had some superannuation income, is that it would depend on the extent to which the targeting was `improved', as Dr Hewson put it, or, in reality, tightened. If, for example, the withdrawal rate of the pension were to be 100 per cent-that is, if at some point for each dollar of non-pension income the pension payable were to be reduced by an equal amount-the effective marginal tax rate for somebody in receipt of superannuation payments would be 100 per cent. There is a considerable gap between the income test which applies now and the 100 per cent figure, which is the tightest bit of targeting that we could get in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not imagine that even Dr Hewson is contemplating a one for one withdrawal of pension entitlements because of superannuation income, but he is clearly contemplating something tighter than presently applies. I wonder how that ties in with the alleged concern of the Opposition for aged people in receipt of or expecting to be in receipt of superannuation benefits, and how it thinks that that will provide a saving incentive of the type that it is always talking about.

It is also a well known fact that, far from pursuing a policy of improved targeting-that is, tighter targeting-the last time the present Leader of the Opposition contested a Federal election his policy so far as age pensions were concerned was to have no targeting at all; that is, to abolish the assets test so that everybody could escape the target, so that everybody could become an invisible target by transforming income, through some devious means, into assets if he had not already done so. It would be nice to know whether the Opposition stands for tighter targeting a la Hewson, or no targeting at all, as Mr Peacock proposed the last time that he was Leader of the Opposition.

I refer to a comment that Dr Hewson made prior to being the shadow Treasurer and, indeed, prior to being a member of the House of Representatives. In the Business Review Weekly of October 1986, he wrote that the Opposition would have no credibility until it spelled out the details of its taxation policy. Likewise, it will have no credibility until it spells out the details of its expenditure policies and, in particular, with reference to this question, whether it stands for tighter targeting or no targeting at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I ask: Has the Government considered its position with regard to the naval bombardment and air to ground firing range on the Beecroft Peninsula, Jervis Bay? Were the recent firing exercises in fact organised at Jervis Bay partly to reduce the much greater expense of conducting them at Shoalwater Bay in Queensland and partly for the benefit of the New Zealand Air Force to keep it operationally efficient following its withdrawal from ANZUS exercises? Are live bombardment and air to ground firings essential if the Defence Force is to maintain operational efficiency? Does the Defence Force have any other suitable firing ranges in the south-eastern Australian area? Is it a fact that no environmental or Aboriginal objections were made to the Jervis Bay range when it was established nearly 40 years ago, or for many years afterwards? Does the Minister believe that strong objections would not be raised if a new range were attempted to be established anywhere else in the south-eastern Australian area? Finally, will the Government take decisive action to ensure that such exercises, which are essential to the maintenance of Defence Force efficiency and morale, are not similarly disrupted in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope I got down all those questions; I was doing my best. The honourable senator asks for some of the reasons why the Beecroft Peninsula range was chosen in the first place. He suggests that it was partly because it was easier for the New Zealand Air Force and partly for expense reasons at Shoalwater Bay. I think both of those reasons, in part, are true. I think I mentioned in the Senate the other day that there are only two ranges on the whole of the east coast, let alone the south-east coast-Shoalwater Bay in Queensland and the Beecroft Peninsula at Jervis Bay. Given that there are only two ranges on the whole of the coast, one wonders how easy it would be to establish another one if one were to do away with the range on the Beecroft Peninsula.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hamer also asked whether the ranges were essential. I do not think any defence force can maintain its capability without a practice range and exercises of the kind that should have been held last week. Over the last couple of weeks I have been trying to find out what objections have ever been raised in respect of the range at Jervis Bay. When the range was first commissioned in the early 1950s certainly no objections were raised. Objections regarding the Jervis Bay area generally have been a much more recent phenomenon. I have now found out, at least, where the suggestion that the firing last week might have interfered with 200 Aboriginal sacred sites has come from. Two hundred sacred sites were identified in a report written in 1986. However, those sites were all around Jervis Bay. They were certainly not all on the Beecroft Peninsula. In terms of what I said last week I can confirm that we are aware of only 25 of them on the peninsula and only one in the impact area of the range.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are essentially archeological sites.
—That is correct. As Senator Chaney says, they are essentially archeological sites. They are not places where Aboriginals now live.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator McLean interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not hear that interjection. The honourable senator is a long way away. He will probably get further away as time goes by. I was also asked by Senator Hamer whether we would try to establish any other range. I would have thought that to be a pointless exercise. Objections wherever we tried to do it would be enormous. Given that this range has been used for 50 years, I cannot imagine that we could find a better place.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Vallentine interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It was used only two weeks before the current fiasco erupted. I wonder where Senator Vallentine's objections were then. Where were anyone's objections when naval ships were shelling at them? I do not accept what Senator Vallentine says at all.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I was asked by Senator Hamer whether the Government would take decisive action to ensure that such exercises can be held in future without disruption. I have not been down to inspect the area, but from what I have seen of it in maps and pictures and from the discussions I have had with officers of the Department of Defence, whilst a fence covers one part of it, there is a great area where it is not too difficult to enter the range. Obviously, given the expense that the Defence Force has to go through to set up operations of the kind that took place last week, we cannot afford to have them continually disrupted in the way they were last week. So the Department is looking at new ways to ensure that the sort of reasonable, proper exercise that was to be held last week can be held in future without interruption.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance bored with calls by the Opposition leadership and senior economic shadow Ministers to tighten fiscal policy? Will the Government be responding to the Opposition and tightening fiscal policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am bored with the calls to tighten fiscal policy--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. At the risk of the Minister boring us, could I suggest that the second part of the question is in order and the first part is irrelevant and a waste of the Senate's time.
—Yes, the Minister should answer the second part of the question only.

—Fiscal policy has been tightened by this Government since 1986 by a full five percentage points of gross domestic product (GDP), which nobody, I suggest, in 1986 would have predicted. Certainly I would not have predicted it. I doubt whether anybody else would have predicted it, and certainly not anyone who was aware of what was entailed in such a tightening of fiscal policy; that is, a Budget surplus in this year of around 2 per cent of gross domestic product, when, with the exception of 1987-88, Australia had not recorded a Budget surplus in all the 35 years or so that such relevant statistics had been kept. In addition, fiscal policy was tightened further at the Premiers Conference. As a result, the public sector borrowing requirement, which is expected to be zero in this year, will fall to about minus one per cent of GDP next year.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the Opposition's calls for further tightening of fiscal policy but I am also aware that none of its proposed measures to tighten fiscal policy is specific. They are accompanied by calls for increased expenditure on roads and defence and calls for a watering down of the assets test and so on. I draw the attention of the Senate to a very good commentary published in last Friday's Sydney Morning Herald written by Milton Cockburn:

It shouldn't really be expecting too much of Peacock to give a ballpark figure of the sort of 1989/90 deficit he would shoot for in the August Budget if he became Prime Minister tomorrow. The Government has already pledged, after allowing for the tax cuts, to budget for a surplus of at least $5.5 billion next year . . . If $5.5 billion is the Government's target-one which is likely to be overtaken by the time it delivers the Budget in August-what does Peacock mean by a `tightening' of fiscal policy? A $6 billion surplus? $7 billion? More? Until Peacock spells it out, one is entitled to question his credibility . . .
To which I need only add a comment by Dr Hewson when he was a respectable columnist. In November 1986 he wrote:
Having begun to declare its tax policies, the Opposition's credibility on tax will continue to be questioned until it specifies all the details.
Likewise, it should specify the detail of its outlays policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Can the Minister advise whether the Government intends to endorse and support the comprehensive plan of action to clear Vietnamese refugees who are presently held in refugee camps? What will be the Australian contribution in terms of the numbers of refugees we will take? Will these refugees be accepted as part of existing immigration programs or will they be in addition to the current refugee intake? Does the plan to clear the camps envisage the involuntary repatriation of some refugees and, if so, does the Government endorse this?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I should begin by saying that I am not sure whether I will ever be the best Minister representing the Minister for immigration. I do not know the answers to Senator Reid's questions. I shall endeavour to find out answers and will probably give them tomorrow.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government received any endorsement from unexpected sources of the policy settings and economic outcomes underlying the 1 July personal income tax cuts? What is the nature of this endorsement and from where did it come? Is there a need for any further action implied by the endorsement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Maguire will remember that last Friday I was asked a question similar to this, as a result of which I quoted from an article in the Adelaide Advertiser which reported Senator Stone's comments about whether it was responsible or under what conditions it would be responsible to give tax cuts. I contrasted the views expressed in that article with Senator Stone's action on Thursday of last week in moving a second reading amendment which said that the Government should have given tax cuts much earlier.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone subsequently made a personal explanation in which he read into the record further comments that he had made in September of last year reported in the same issue of the Advertiser, and he said:
What you can't have in our present economic situation is a situation in which, all of a sudden, Australians are told they can have a significant jump in their real standard of living.

There will be great difficulty in the Government giving anything like the kind of tax cuts which they have been building up expectations for while maintaining any form of responsibility towards the outlook for Australia . . .
Senator Stone said Australians should not expect large tax cuts next July `unless between now and then, which I don't expect to see, there is a major change in our national productivity performance'.

That is the key sentence. That is an original quote from Senator Stone.
