This legislation will mean an increase in the massive queues at public hospitals while private hospitals close, and those that do survive will be priced beyond the range of ordinary Australians. This deceptive Bill, when examined, shows that the Hawke Labor Government is no friend at all of the medical profession or the private health sector. We urgently need the select committee of inquiry that will look at the real issues concerning health that the Government, quite deliberately and consistently, seeks to evade. Foremost among these issues must be the ability of hospital Medicare to meet its basic objectives. We need to establish what support needs to be provided to the private health sector if community rating is to remain a reality. The only option we have is for the whole subject to be looked at in great detail by a Senate select committee which, at the end of the day, once the subject has been sensibly and thoroughly assessed, can make a balanced decision-not a decision based on a piece of legislation which contains no information and no facts about what we should be voting for. That should be a source of major concern. I hope that general practitioners and health insurance funds understand the ability they will have to communicate their concerns to the select committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to only one item in the package of Bills-the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill, the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Bill-that we are discussing tonight, and that is the reinsurance arrangements that are proposed by the Government. The Government, in terms of its propaganda war on this issue, had undoubtedly won. It has won because the Opposition, which initially indicated it would oppose this legislation, will now support it. I still believe that people are entitled to a clear view of what is going on in this reinsurance exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has won, in terms of its propaganda, on the basis of saying that what it is about in these reinsurance rearrangements is, allegedly, supporting the community rating proposals. It is not doing anything of the sort. I intend to show that what it is about could very well end up in the destruction of that community rating proposition. The formula that is used to allocate reinsurance claims is based on the number of policyholders, not on the premiums paid. Of course, that impacts particularly heavily on the price of low cost insurance products, which are, not surprisingly when one is paying for them from one's own back pocket, most popular among low risk groups in the community. What the Government is now proposing, amongst other things, is to change this concept of reinsurance away from the chronically ill towards the aged. By a sleight of hand the Government, in equating the two, says that the chronically ill are aged, and the aged are chronically ill. Of course, they are nothing of the sort. We have a totally new concept, and that is the aged. In addition, the costs of other patients in hospital for longer than 14 days will be included.

Approximately 70 per cent of current contributors to the schemes will benefit as a result of these changes. Therefore, 30 per cent will be disadvantaged. Seventy per cent will be advantaged inasmuch as the contribution rates they have to pay will probably stabilise for a short period. Certainly those contribution rates will not fall. However, the 30 per cent of contributors who are being disadvantaged will have their rates increased. Let us be clear about the fact that 70 per cent of contributors will benefit only because their rates will not rise-they will merely stabilise-and 30 per cent of contributors will not benefit from this exercise because they will be paying more. That 30 per cent of contributors will be disadvantaged to a large extent. In fact, the larger funds will milk some $18m from 300,000 contributors. If that is not bad enough, those 300,000 contributors-basically, the 8 per cent who belong to the smaller funds-already massively subsidise the larger funds and the other 70 per cent of contributors. That 8 per cent of private contributors contribute nearly 50 per cent of the present cost sharing arrangement. The Government is now proposing that that 8 per cent should pay not only 50 per cent but more than 50 per cent.

Which funds will be milch cows for the Government? The employee based funds. Let us examine some of those funds. The New South Wales Government Employees Health Fund, which gets no subsidy of any kind and operates on overheads of $59 per member per year, is one of the smaller funds that will be milked; it will have its fees raised by the Government. The Hospitals Contribution Fund of Australia, which charges 33 per cent more and has overheads of $111 per member per year, will benefit. In other words, inefficient funds will get more and efficient funds will have to pay for it. Not only new funds are involved. Indeed, one of the oldest funds in Australia, the 100-year-old Tramways Benefit Society in Victoria, has overheads of $63 per member per year, while the Hospital Benefits Association Ltd in Victoria has overheads of $113 per member per year.

Obviously, funds that have been operating inefficiently will now be subsidised to continue to operate inefficiently. Thank you very much: officers can be paid their large salaries, the funds can be housed in large headquarters, they can have bad share portfolios; yet the Government will subsidise them, with the money coming from the pockets of the small, efficient funds with low overheads that have put their money back into products for their contributors.

Those large funds that we are talking about that are now running around the place crying poor have been quite happy to take subscriptions for the last 20 years from these people that they now wish to offload. They have had the use of those people's funds for the last 20 years and now they are saying, `We don't want to look after them any more; they are now aged, or they are spending more than 14 days in hospital. We will offload them and we want other people to pay for them'. This gives a whole new meaning to the take and run exercise-and that is what it is. But it is even worse than that because many of these larger funds that have an interest in private hospitals will now get 100 per cent of all hospital costs for every person over the age of 65. The Government has not required those funds in any way to change or lower their premiums. The Government has not required anything of those funds. So a fund that owns a private hospital can recover its own hospital fees from other funds and also take a return from the hospital. That is a lovely little exercise in which the Government is now engaging.

The funds to which 30 per cent of contributors belong-that 30 per cent of contributors who will suffer-will find that they will be deserted by many of their contributors as they raise their rates to pay for the subsidised funds. Those 300,000 contributors have 450,000 dependants. Oddly enough, by and large, the funds that have been set up by employee groups, and often by unions, have low overheads and are efficient. They do not have glossy headquarters but they run an efficient, lean exercise. Undoubtedly, as the smaller funds raise their contributions they will lose contributors. That has happened everywhere in the private insurance industry to date. The overall effect will be that fewer people will be insured.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what the Government is seeking.

—I think the exercise will be a very odd one. The young and the healthy will not pay the higher contribution rates and they will move out of the funds. Since December 1983, the percentage of people with private health insurance has fallen from 61.5 per cent to 46.2 per cent. That means there will be fewer people insured and fewer to contribute to the reinsurance pool. Of course, the Government has recognised that what it is doing will lead to fewer people being insured and smaller amounts of money going into the reinsurance pool. The Government, knowing that it has an election on its hands, has agreed to put $20m into the reinsurance pool. For how long? Wait for it-for 18 months, because it is having an election in the next 12 months. So all it is doing is putting $20m into the reinsurance pool for the next 18 months. That is the time frame that has been put on it. It is so transparent that those people who actually fall for it would really have to have rocks in their heads. The Government, in a bandaid approach, is buying its way through, and just past, the next election, and what happens after that would be of absolutely no interest to it if it has been re-elected. It has not shown any interest whatsoever in private insurance cover.
—On the contrary; the Government wants to diminish it.

—The Government wants to diminish it. There will be an increase in cover for those people aged 65 and a reduction in cover for the low risk groups. Of course, this will lead to an increase in average claim rates, as the young and healthy move out. There will be extra demand because all people over the age of 65 are now being categorised as chronically ill. So we will have an increase in average claim rates for the industry as a whole and a subsequent upward pressure on premiums. The only way in which the private sector can deal with the extra demand and increased costs is to increase the money coming in. The only money coming into these funds is by way of premiums. So in 18 months time-if the Government is lucky this probably will not pick up until just after the next election-the aged will be paying more as a result of these changes; fewer people will be privately insured; there will be more demand on public places; and a number of the small employee based funds that have been made into milch cows for this exercise will be out of business. All of that will occur just after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is engaging in a very cynical exercise of manipulating the electorate and, in particular, those groups that represent people aged over 65 within our community who, unfortunately, fell for this hook, line and sinker. They will be the ones who will be paying more because we are driving to the wall the small, efficient union based and employee based funds. That is what this exercise is about. The Government would not be involved in that or at all interested in taking on those funds-because, as I say, most of them have been set up by unions-unless there was a quid in it for the Government. The quid in it for the Government is very easy. It will have a patched up arrangement going through to the next election. It will not have a large public fund collapse on its hands in Victoria. That is what this is about. Let us be very clear about that. It does not want any of those funds collapsing around its ears. It wants to limp through to just after the next election. If they all collapsed then, the Government could not care less, because the next election after that will not be for another three years.

The odd situation is that those 20 employee based funds are run by boards elected by their members either directly or through their trade unions. They have low administrative costs compared to the funds which will have to be propped up. They will be keeping their members, as they do, after retirement. Some of these funds, unlike the public funds that the Government is now going to have to subsidise, have actually been reducing the premiums for their elderly contributors as an incentive for them to stay with the funds. The administrative record of these funds is second to none, unlike some of the other funds that have gone into extraordinarily useless advertising. They have had enormous losses on the stock markets. One has only to be invited to see them in their plush headquarters to know that a lot of the money is going elsewhere.

If the Government had reallocated to reinsurance the $200m that was there when the Government introduced the new arrangements, that would have been a healthy fund to assist those who are chronically ill. Under those circumstances, their contribution rates could very well have dropped by as much as $3 a week. It has been reliably estimated that 5 per cent more Australians would have taken out private insurance and that the Government would have saved $350m in hospital costs, an overall gain of $150m. If it had encouraged people to take out private insurance by leaving the $200m in there, the Government could have made $150m on the exercise.

Let us be clear what the Government is doing with regard to this matter. This particular piece of legislation, which unfortunately the Opposition has now said it is going to support, in this context, is simply legalised theft from a number of small private, efficiently run organisations. That legalised theft will be used to prop up failing funds simply in order to get the Government out of a hole until the next election. Legalised theft is no better than illegal theft. The end does not justify the means. I certainly will not be voting for legalised theft when it comes to this particular measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the time constraints we have in this debate, so I will limit my remarks to those parts of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill dealing with the fee arrangements of general practitioners (GPs) and amendments to the Nursing Homes Assistance Act. The Australian Medical Association (AMA) and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) originally suggested a new content based fee system in September 1988 for introduction on 1 November 1988. The main difference between the proposed new content based fees and the old time based fees was that the new fees were to be defined by the complexity of what the doctor did during the consultation, not the time taken for the consultation. While this proposal was rejected by the Government, it did offer to both the AMA and the RACGP the opportunity to discuss changes to general practitioners' fees. The RACGP accepted that offer; the AMA did not.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we should place on record just what the agenda of the AMA is. The main aim of the AMA is to create dissatisfaction with Medicare by creating a large difference between GPs' fees and Medicare rebates. The AMA proposed general practitioners' fees of $25, as contrasted with the schedule fee of $18.60 and the Medicare rebate of $15.85. The AMA, which refused point blank to be involved in negotiations with the Government, has now attacked the agreement and recommendations that the joint working party, comprising representatives of the Government and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, has produced. Having refused to participate in the process of the working party, the AMA is now trying to defeat the legislation here in the Senate.

The AMA's actions have antagonised not only general practitioners but also its own members. Let us take Dr Eric Fisher as an example. For 40 years a member of the British Medical Association and then the AMA, he was the general practitioners' craft representative on the Federal council of the AMA. In his letter of resignation dated 24 May 1989 from both the AMA and its Federal council, he said:

My position as craft representative in which I have endeavoured to promote unity in general practice has become untenable. I have rarely been consulted about general practice matters. The position is purely a cosmetic one. I cannot in all conscience hold such a false position.

Repeated press releases concerning general practitioners have been issued without any consultation with the craft representative. Some of these press releases are clearly calculated to divide general practice.
He went on to say:
The AMA must give up this obsession with attacking the Royal College of General Practitioners and instead spend its energies on behalf of all general practitioners.
He said:

I do not believe it has the capability. It lost the opportunity to become a constructive organisation by varying the recommendations of the Cotton Report. It appears to have learnt very little from that exercise. I would dearly have loved to see a resurgent AMA. I believe it will get absolutely nowhere by trying to dominate the profession rather than working for it. Its political ineptitude is being hidden behind the so called ``new look'' in which nothing has really changed.

What an indictment of the AMA. The AMA is now dominated by a small and conservative group-in fact, a rump-whose main goal is the destruction of Medicare. Not only do we have the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners supporting the Government on this legislation, and the AMA alienating and antagonising its general practitioner members, but the Doctors Reform Society has also been brought into the debate. The Doctors Reform Society, not surprisingly, has condemned the AMA for opposing the negotiated fee changes for general practice. In a recent press release, Dr Robert Marr of the Doctors Reform Society said:
The resignation of Dr Fisher validates a recent survey of all GPs throughout Australia that showed 78% of GPs did not think the AMA was doing a good job representing GPs.
The AMA represents less than 50% of GPs but even 55% of AMA member GPs who responded to the survey were dissatisfied with the AMA.

Dr Marr said that the Doctors Reform Society calls on the Liberal Party's health spokesman Mr Peter Shack and the Australian Democrats' health spokesman Senator John Coulter to support GP fee changes in Parliament.

This morning I listened with interest to Senator Puplick's tirade. He described the negotiations between the Government and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners as a cosy, closed shop deal. Senator Puplick also claimed that the Government had not acted on the recommendations of the Doherty report-the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and Medical Workforce. It became clear from Senator Puplick's contribution that he had not read the Doherty report. He was probably just too busy defending the vested interests of a small group of conservative specialists whom the Liberal Party and the Opposition have always represented. There seems to be no care for the consumers, the patients or for the vast majority of general practitioners in Australia. There seems to be no concern for recommendations 8 (i) to 8 (vi) of the Doherty report, which call for general practitioners to undertake vocational training. The report says on page 289:
General practice has a key role in medical practice and education, as a discipline in medical care which required a distinct style of practice and point of view.
Appropriate vocational training is highly desirable and should be available to all entrants to general practice.

I commend the report to Senator Puplick and suggest that he read it. There is no doubt that the majority of general practitioners support this legislation. I believe that the legislation is in the best interests of health care in this country, the best interests of GPs and certainly the best interests of patients.

I would also like to draw attention to a report that has been written for the New South Wales Council for Intellectual Disability by Ms Karen McLoughlin. The report relates to the accommodation of young people with intellectual disabilities in private nursing homes in New South Wales. Ms McLoughlin describes them as a `particularly neglected and hidden group', as the report outlines. The report gives three examples of people with disabilities who live in nursing homes in New South Wales. I would like to outline them here.

Example number one is Shirley. Shirley has a severe intellectual disability. She has been raised in Sydney in a succession of special purpose nursing homes catering for children with special needs. When she was two years old Shirley's application for nursing home benefits was approved by Commonwealth medical officers (CMOs). Now she is 19-too old for the children's home. Yet the piece of paper which had been rubber stamped when she was two is still valid. Shirley was able to be placed in a local geriatric nursing home without any further contact with the CMOs. In this home there is a group of other young men and women who have also graduated from the children's home and a larger group of non-disabled elderly men and women. A registered nurse is on duty 24 hours a day but it is not always possible to monitor the interactions between the residents. Some programs have been attempted with the younger residents but the staff have no special training and feel that their divided energies disadvantage both groups.

Example number two is Ken, who is 30 years old and has a severe intellectual disability. He had lived with his parents in a country town all his life. Three years ago Ken's mother died and his elderly father was unable to care for him. Ken's case was referred to the CMOs and he was approved for nursing home benefits. As there were no special purpose nursing homes in his local area Ken now lives in a geriatric nursing home. No other people with an intellectual disability live in the nursing home and there are no staff qualified to provide the special programs that Ken needs.

The third example is Margaret. Margaret is 40 years old and had a severe intellectual disability and epilepsy. When Margaret had some recurrent bouts of illness a few years back, her elderly aunt could no longer care for her at home. Margaret was approved for nursing home benefits and admitted to a large geriatric home near her aunt's home in Sydney. Now she has completely recovered from her illness but her aunt does not feel that she could cope with caring for Margaret at home again.

I believe that the plight of these people must be addressed. Can anyone argue that these people would not be better off away from nursing homes if they are capable of independent living outside? The Disability Services Act places great emphasis on appropriate consumer outcomes-access to independent living skills and a range of other services which add immeasurably to the quality of life of people with disabilities. For that reason I support very strongly the legislation that is before the Senate today.

I was disappointed in Senator Boswell's earlier comments that he believed that the amendments before the Senate would provide less flexibility for disabled people in nursing homes. I believe that the exact opposite is true: the Government's amendments will provide more flexibility. Many people with disabilities do not require the type of nursing care that is given in nursing homes. Many people could be accommodated in less restrictive environments. The proposed amendments will give disabled people more opportunities. With support, some people who currently live in nursing homes can live in the outside community. The Disability Services Act allows for disabled people to be treated as individuals. It means that people with disabilities have a choice. New services will encourage disabled people who can cope to leave inappropriate and artificial environments. They can choose more appropriate community based accommodation. Ongoing assistance and training will be provided for disabled people who are able to leave nursing homes for a better or more appropriate home. The Disability Services Act is supported by disabled people and service providers. I hope that the Senate can see fit to do the same.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate this evening is debating cognately the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill 1989 and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Bill 1988. I wish to restrict my remarks to two amendments to this package of legislation. In the first case I wish to address my remarks to the Australian Democrats' amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill and speak to the motion. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: but the Senate is of the opinion that women who choose to give birth at home are disadvantaged because of their ineligibility for medicare rebates for the services of a midwife, and the Government should take urgent action to remedy this unfairness.

Homebirth is an alternative that a growing number of women are choosing. In Western Australia, in particular, women are choosing the alternative of the homebirth rather than a hospital birth. But this means engaging the services of a midwife. If a woman has a general practitioner or a specialist to assist her to give birth, she can claim a Medicare rebate. But if a qualified midwife assists in the homebirth, she is not eligible for a Medicare rebate. It is indeed unfortunate that doctors, for the most part, do not choose to assist women in homebirth. I know that there are exceptions but they are very much in the minority.

In assisting a homebirth, a qualified midwife will be present for some hours during labour, as well as providing antenatal and postnatal support which, of course, can be complementary to any care also given by a general practitioner or a specialist. Because there is no Medicare rebate, midwives tend to charge minimal fees for a homebirth. I have even heard that they have charged virtually no fees at all. Nonetheless, the result of this situation is a case of discrimination against women who cannot afford to have a homebirth.

I point out to the Senate that an increasing number of women are recognising the advantages of a homebirth. For a woman to give birth in her own home in familiar surroundings far away from a hospital atmosphere results in a more relaxed situation. Indeed it is now recognised that the woman herself can be better off in such circumstances. Of course, so can the newborn baby. Homebirth is not for everyone but some women want this. Other women feel more secure in a hospital situation.

As far as possible the woman concerned, if she is to have a homebirth, must expect a relatively uncomplicated birth. Of course, should this not eventuate and should it be deemed necessary for the woman to be transferred to hospital, a midwife can always arrange this. As the majority of births are what one could categorise as normal and, indeed, as they are more likely to be normal if unnecessary medical intervention does not occur, there is no reason why a woman who chooses a homebirth should not be allowed to have it.

I also point out that in Western Australia midwives have access to hospitals. In fact, if the woman is to be transferred to a hospital the midwife can assist at the hospital. With conscientious prenatal care most complications or difficulties that are likely to arise are, in this day and age, predictable. Women greatly appreciate the special personal support which can be given by a midwife. A lot of women do not see themselves as sick patients. They recognise that hospital treatment may be necessary but for normal child birth a lot of women do not regard it as necessary. Rather, they see themselves as taking part in a natural and beautiful process which can be uncomfortable, even painful. It can make a woman feel particularly vulnerable. Therefore, that is all the more reason for women to require the sympathetic support that they can have from a midwife.

A qualified midwife has more than enough qualifications and knowledge of gynaecology and obstetrics to be able to assist a woman in the birth process. If things go wrong-and unfortunately they can go wrong at times-then most women would appreciate being able to be in a hospital and surrounded by the latest equipment. If this happens in Western Australia, the woman can still have her midwife with her as in Western Australia midwives have delivery rights in hospitals.

It has been pointed out to me that Western Australia would be a good State in which to have a pilot scheme involving an increased use of midwives. I would like to draw the Senate's attention to a task force which is currently reviewing obstetric, neonatal and gynaecological services in Western Australia. The aims of the task force are to assess the quality of care currently being provided; to determine whether resources are being used effectively; to consider the needs of groups requiring special attention, such as adolescents, Aboriginal people, women from non-English speaking backgrounds, the disabled and those who are economically disadvantaged or who reside in isolated areas; and to investigate the possibility of alternative types of services which will allow for increased consumer choice. That is what I am talking about: the ability of women to choose a homebirth if this is what they want.

The terms of reference and objectives of the task force include investigation of the current hospital obstetric practices, including the frequency of intervention in child birth; the provision of medical services to pregnant women in emergency situations when giving birth in a non-hospital setting; and the role and range of duties undertaken by midwives, including the role, training and access to hospital of independent midwives. The Democrats are of the opinion that a woman who chooses to give birth at home should have access to Medicare rebates by being able to claim for the services of a qualified midwife.

I would like to address some remarks to the amendment put forward by Senator Boswell wherein he moved that proposed amendments contained in part 5 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in October 1989. The Democrats strongly support the thrust of the amendments put forward by the Government to part 5 of this legislation, those relating to accommodation for the disabled. But we have some concerns. We believe that integrated accommodation for disabled persons needs both adequate funding and an assurance that the service provisions by the non-government sector are of the highest quality. Senator Boswell's amendment to this part of the legislation would mean that a Senate committee would look into aspects such as these. I point out that in the Australian Capital Territory it costs on average $11,000 per person in integrated housing per annum. It is double that amount in the States because these service provisions are not subsidised by other services as they are in the Australian Capital Territory.

Once disabled persons have been de-institutionalised it is important that there be a close tie-up between home and community care and the attendant care program. There may be problems in instituting these changes, which the Democrats support, because people who are used to institutionalised care may find it difficult to adjust to non-institutionalised care. We find that problem right across the board. It is well known that people who spend a large part of their lives in institutions as children find it hard to cope with life outside an institution upon reaching adulthood. We just have to look at the statistics in our prison system to see how many of those who are, unfortunately, regular clients of that system spent a part of their lives in institutions. There have been criticisms that the Disability Services Act is too inflexible and it is imperative that accommodation choice be individually based. Within the system there must be a choice of bigger homes, although the Democrats believe that there should be no more than 20 persons in each home. This is particularly important in the country and for emergency accommodation where small homes of four persons may not be appropriate. The question must also be asked as to why indexation remains at the discretion of the Minister.

We certainly support this matter being referred to a Senate standing committee, but we believe that it should be sequential and not concurrent. In other words, the Democrats will pass part 5 of the legislation, but will also vote in favour of these matters being referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. The final implementation of this amending legislation will not occur until 1992, so there is just time for considerations at the start of its implementation. Besides which, guidelines will be associated with the legislation and it will be possible for the Committee to assist in setting those guidelines. However, as I understand it, Senator Boswell has agreed to the date being changed. Having spoken with the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Zakharov, I have found that she is of the opinion-and I would agree with her; I cannot speak for the Committee because it has not met to discuss Senator Boswell's amendment-that the Committee could not possibly look at and report on these considerations by the first sitting day in October 1989, so we are seeking to have that date changed to the first sitting day in March 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The current health system into which all Australians have been flung falls a long way short of that which the Government promised to all Australians through Medicare. The Government promised to provide a fair system in which the ability to pay was not to be a major determinant of access to health services and, therefore, changes to our health system are long overdue.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately the legislation which we are debating this evening and that piece of legislation to which I particularly wish to refer in this cognate debate, the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, completely fail to make the correct changes which the health system in Australia requires to make it more responsive to the needs of all Australians. Medicine is undergoing a time of great change in which many patients receive less than the best possible care. Thousands of low income Australians on public hospital waiting lists are the front line casualties of Medicare. This list grows steadily longer with each day that passes. Fears in the community that Medicare has failed to deliver access to hospital care has induced about 22 per cent of Australians on the lowest incomes-those who are health card holders-to take out private hospital insurance at extreme financial hardship to themselves. It is for these very people that the public health system is designed. It is for them and their health care needs that we have a public health system so that they do not need to have private health insurance. Meanwhile we find that many other people on higher incomes who can well afford to take private health insurance are opting out of that expense and taking the risk of their own good health. As I said, this legislation does nothing to improve that situation.

There are several significant elements to this legislation. It involves alterations to the reinsurance arrangements for private health funds, it seeks to establish a private health insurance administration council and it also seeks to introduce a vocational register for general practice medicine. It seeks the promotion of day only hospital treatment, and it seeks to introduce a new pathology services table and to alter the way in which that table can be changed.

Because the Federal Government has removed some $500m of health expenditure from its Budget and loaded it onto the private health care sector since the establishment of Medicare, private health insurance is failing to keep up with costs. This legislation does nothing to remedy that situation. The changes that it proposes with regard to private health insurance are a direct consequence of that fact. The coalition does not oppose those changes but it needs to be recognised that Medicare has failed completely to provide appropriate responses to the deficiencies in our health care system. The Government has failed to protect the interests of the aged and chronically ill by providing sufficient support for the Health Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund. The Hawke Government has provided only $47m to that trust, compared to some $525m provided by the previous coalition Government. The additional injection of some $20m which it is seeking to provide through this legislation is an inadequate response to the needs of the Reinsurance Trust.

The Government's proposals inadequately address the problems which health care funds face as a result of the introduction of Medicare and the significant reductions in Commonwealth contributions to the reinsurance pool. As I said, the Government has ripped some $500m out of the reinsurance pool over the time it has been in office. As a result it is forcing those funds with limited membership to provide the funds which it has ripped out of the system. The result of this will be that any advantage from the changes, in particular to the aged group in our community, will be minimal and likely to be short-term.

The Government claims that it is introducing this aspect of the legislation, this contribution to the Reinsurance Trust Fund and increasing the provision which those limited funds are required to make to the Reinsurance Trust Fund, to ensure the survival of community rating. But community rating cannot survive under the current situation. Only some 46 per cent of the population has private insurance. That percentage is decreasing. That is the rub for this legislation. As I said, the Government claims that it is protecting community rating but it has destroyed community rating by reducing the incentive and the capacity of many people to take out private insurance. Community rating can operate only if a significant proportion of the community has private health insurance. It is meaningless if a relatively small and declining percentage of the community has private health insurance.

The coalition's health policy will demonstrate our commitment to protecting the health care interests of the aged and the future of the private health care sector generally. That is why we are moving that this whole issue and a number of matters with regard to this legislation be referred to a Senate select committee for further investigation.

The legislation also involves changes to the Australian Institute of Health Act which concerns the anxieties of State and Territory governments about the need to make additional provisions to safeguard the handling of information made available to the Australian Institute of Health. We support the passage of these changes but we particularly want to ensure that the handling of confidential health information should be both sensitive and in the interests of vital research work aimed at raising community health standards.

With regard to the changes to pathology services, the legislation provides for regulations under the Health Insurance Act 1973 to govern the operation of the pathology services table. It also repeals the provisions establishing the Pathology Services Advisory Committee and replaces the existing schedule of pathology services with a new schedule. Again, the Opposition will support those sections of the legislation which relate to pathology service delivery. These amendments are very much overdue. The manipulations which occurred in this area in November last year served only to create a totally unworkable pathology services table. It is estimated that the new pathology services table will result in a full year saving of $45m over the estimate based on the August 1987 table. In addition, additional savings of $47m in 1990-91 and $49m in 1991-92 have been identified in attachment F of the Government's economic statement. The Opposition will allow these changes. The unholy mess in which the Government has dumped pathology services and the problems associated with attempts to operate policy decisions via a third party-namely, the Pathology Services Advisory Council-are quite obvious and we will support those changes.

Through this legislation, the Government also proposes changes to encourage day only hospital treatment. Therefore, the legislation permits greater flexibility in the determination of basic hospital benefits for day only treatment in a hospital or day hospital facility. It will make provision for medical practitioners to certify that in special circumstances a patient requiring day only treatment may be eligible for an overnight stay. It will provide different amounts to be payable in respect of different classes of professional attention and treatment in different classes of hospital. In principle, the coalition supports the greater use of day only hospitals. Despite this, we will oppose this aspect of the legislation because we believe that no changes should be implemented without exhaustive discussion with representative organisations of the medical profession and the National Day Surgery Advisory Committee. The extent of consultation in which this Government has been involved is entirely inadequate as a basis for this legislation.

The legislation also seeks to establish a general practitioner vocational register. This creates a new class of general practitioner defined as a `vocationally registered general practitioner'. It empowers the Health Insurance Commission: firstly, to establish and maintain a vocational register of general practitioners; secondly, to add and remove medical practitioners' names from the register; thirdly, to advise the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners of the state of the register; and, finally, to provide the general public with details of those on the list. As was stated earlier by coalition speakers, this section of the legislation will take the control and administration of general practitioners out of the hands of the college and put it into the hands of the Health Insurance Commission. In other words, it will place another section of medical care in the hands of the Government bureaucracy.

We do not oppose, in principle, that there should be incentives for general practitioners to acquire additional skills, to undertake further education and training and to raise the standard of general practice. But we oppose the way in which this legislation seeks to give effect to those objectives. The Government has acted too hastily in seeking to establish this new circumstance, as it did with regard to pathology services, without allowing the fullest consideration of this issue by the medical profession as a whole. We believe that a change such as this requires comprehensive consideration to be given to standards, fees, rebates and accreditation. That is why we are referring this issue to a Senate select committee which will consult widely and report back to the Senate on the legislation before any changes are made.

These days the focus of Australia's health system is primary care, also known as general practice. This is an area which has been particularly neglected under this Government. More than 80 per cent of Australians visit a general practitioner each year. The majority of general practitioners-almost 59 per cent-are in group practice. There are 70 million general practitioner consultations every year in Australia. That is about 192,000 for each day of the entire year. There are some fundamental problems with the operation of the health bureaucracy and the Federal Government now has the opportunity to address and transform the quality of medical care administered through general practice. It is an opportunity which this Government is demonstrably neglecting. It is not repairing that neglect through this legislation.

The health bureaucracy is obsessed with the concern that doctors care more about earning big money than with administering care for the ill in our society. It seems to have forgotten that only a small proportion of people who need medical attention actually have to use hospitals. So general practice is bearing the brunt of the community's dismay with the system as it currently stands. The Government needs to give much greater consideration to this area. Even in small rural environments, let alone urban complexes, there are many ways available for the community to avoid seeing general practitioners. There are hospital casualty departments, family planning clinics and community health centres with their attendant community nurses. General practitioners are competing with greater numbers of their own profession and a variety of allied health professionals for their patients. It would seem that the most cost effective type of doctor, the well trained and well motivated general practitioner, is far too valuable to be replaced by these other agencies; yet, again, the Government is encouraging their replacement. On the one hand the community wants convenient access to the medical care and skills which a general practitioner offers and on the other hand it expresses concern periodically about the level of general practitioners' fees.

Because of the complexities which are now evident in the Government's general administration and funding of our health care system and the way in which the Government is fiddling the system to hide the utter failure of Medicare, the Opposition will seek to refer significant parts of this legislation to a Senate select committee. That inquiry is required urgently to investigate not only the many proposals in this legislation but also the general shortcomings in the health care system. I commend the Opposition's proposed course of action and urge the Senate to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend my motion by altering the terms of reference of the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the proposed amendments to sections 3, 3a, 4, 5, 6, 12 and 36a of the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974, contained in clauses 55 to 61 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in March 1990, with particular reference to the practical implications of the principles of the Disability Services Act 1986, for disabled people, including:

(a) the consequences of the relative degree of incapacity of intellectually disabled people, including the desirability of housing these people in existing-type accommodation, as opposed to the new type proposed;
(b) the difference in capital cost and recurrent funding between the existing and proposed systems;
(c) the optimal degree of care that may be maintained under the new proposals, suitable to the degree of incapacity; and
(d) the benefits or the disadvantages to clients in exposing them to a change of lifestyle if the new guidelines were to be introduced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Government to reply to the debate. I think the Senate will agree that the views of the Opposition, and some views of the Australian Democrats, have been canvassed extensively. Government senators have rebutted some of those views on the Bills before the chamber-the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill 1989, and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Bill 1988. There have been a host of speakers, and a number of amendments have been proposed. A motion has just been amended by Senator Boswell on behalf of the National Party. Notice was given last Thursday morning by Senator Puplick, in anticipation of this debate, of one motion which is before the chamber. The Australian Democrats have moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading. If one listened to the contribution to the debate by honourable senators opposite one would have heard a number of questions foreshadowed for the committee stage. A number of amendments have been foreshadowed also. Having said that, it is true that the Opposition has indicated its support for a number of the Government's proposed measures in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go to the detail of what I wish to put to the chamber, I will sort out the wheat from the chaff. I will pocket the wheat and reply to the chaff. Let me identify that the amendment to the Australian Institute of Health Act 1987 improves the confidentiality provisions of the Act. It is an amendment upon which the States agree. I understand that the Opposition does not oppose it. The amendment is needed for the States to begin to provide statistics to the Commonwealth under these provisions. I understand that that will not be opposed. I acknowledge the support that we have obtained on that measure.

The next is the amendment to the pathology services table. Again, I understand that both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats do not oppose this measure. The pathologists themselves support the change. Therefore, I understand that that is agreed. I thank the Opposition and the Democrats for their support on that score. I could recite the same litany as I have for the previous two amendments on the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill 1989 but I understand that this is also supported. There is no need for me to enter debate on those matters. A number of observations have been made about them in Hansard but I will not delay the Senate by referring to them.

That brings me to the day hospital benefit arrangements for insured patients. This raises an interesting aspect of the debate. From listening to the speakers it is fair to say that there is Opposition support for the concept involved. The argument is not whether the Government is proposing to do the right thing but whether the Government has adequately and exhaustively consulted all of the organisations that one would expect to be consulted on a measure such as this. Indeed, on 25 May in the debate on this Bill in the House of Representatives Mr Shack, the shadow Minister for health, in his address commented that the Government had not had any discussions or consultations on the proposed new day surgery arrangements at that time. I think that was a fair enough comment, given the state of knowledge that Mr Shack had on that occasion.

I note that the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, has taken steps to advise Mr Shack of the detail of the consultation. In a letter dated early June the Minister set that out in detail with a list of the organisations that have been formally consulted. Twenty-three organisations have been consulted. I do not propose to read them into the Hansard. I do not even propose to incorporate them because they have been referred to often enough in the public debate but I do table the document setting out the list of 23 organisations that have been consulted.

Since the 1987 Australian Health Ministers Conference, where it was agreed that the Commonwealth would review day hospital facility benefits, the Department of Community Services and Health has had continuing discussions with State and Territory health authorities, the hospital and insurance industries and peak medical bodies. The discussion paper produced in March this year outlining possible new arrangements was essentially the product of those consultations. This discussion paper has been widely distributed. I refer to the list that I have tabled as part of the distribution. Departmental officers recently held meetings with a number of those organisations and more are planned in the future. To date responses on the paper show general support for the concept and the Department has received many constructive suggestions on the appropriateness of the procedures to be included for day surgery. An extensive consultative process is being carried out by the Department. That extensive consultation procedure will be completed by the Department.

So it is for me in this debate to put, I think fairly, to the Opposition that the Government has demonstrated its bona fides as to consultations. The Opposition may have been seized of a different impression when Mr Shack made those statements. It is my understanding that the Australian Democrats at least understand the extent to which we have attempted to consult honestly and exhaustively and that they do support the Government on this measure. I think it would be appropriate for the Opposition also to recognise that we have done the right thing, and to support this measure. However, I commend it to the Senate. The Government will be looking for a majority vote when this matter is put to the test at the conclusion of the committee stage.

Let me therefore go to another piece, in the sequence in which I have my list of issues before me, of what I initially thought might be described as chaff, but which I am prepared to recognise as wheat. The Australian Democrats have moved the following amendment to the motion for the second reading:
At end of motion, add: `, but the Senate is of the opinion that women who chose to give birth at home are disadvantaged because of their ineligibility . . .'
They are claiming that the Government should take urgent action to remedy the alleged unfairness of that position. At first blush it seems to me--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about second blush?

—I will come to second blush in a minute, because it has a very important role to play in this debate. At first blush I am inclined to support the Democrats' proposal. The Government believes that we can meet the intent of what the Democrats are proposing, but in a more effective way. I make the side comment that for us at least the art of government is making a real change. It seems to me that the motion proposed by the Democrats is to tack their flag to the mast, that they are interested in a symbolistic expression of view by the Senate on this matter. It is in the pursuit of the desirable objective that, if we believe something is worthwhile, we should change the status quo to conform to that-that is, the achievement of real change-that I propose we go a bit further. The Government does not disagree with the intent of the Democrats' amendment, but we would not be in favour of a simple extension of the fee for service arrangements for midwives assisting with home births. The issue of the extension of fee for service to midwives was considered, as honourable senators may know, by the Medicare Benefits Review Committee, chaired by the then Justice Robyn Layton. But that Committee did not favour fee for service arrangements for home births, despite the exhaustive canvassing of the issue before it.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue was again raised extensively during the consultations on the development of the national women's health policy. The Department of Community Services and Health has been considering several options, as indicated by Senator Coulter in his earlier remarks. The Government would like to see a wider range of birthing options available to women, but there are issues other than the simple financial arrangements which must be considered. For example, safety issues must be considered in attending or having home births. There is the question of hospital admitting rights available to midwives. State programs also enter into this consideration. The New South Wales Government, for example, recently released a major report on that subject. So the Government would like to provide financial assistance for those women who choose an appropriate home birth.

I suggest that the wording of the amendment be something along these lines: `but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should take action to provide financial assistance for midwives associated with home births'. The honourable senator might consider those words and give me some sort of indication, before I resume my seat at the end of this address, as to whether she finds them satisfactory. I regret that in the rush to the wire, when we were expecting one or two more speakers to speak, I have not had a chance personally to canvass them with the honourable senator in private prior to dropping them on her in public, but I am sure she will appreciate the circumstances in which I am operating. Where does that lead us to in terms of the issues? I think it leads us to Senator Boswell's--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that wheat or chaff?
—I was just about to turn to Senator Boswell, but before I do so I might turn somewhere else.
—Am I in the wheat category or the chaff category?

—When Senator Boswell's turn comes up he will be chaff: he does not have to worry about that. We do not expect his proposal to germinate into a useful development in this chamber or elsewhere, so he will be in the chaff category. On my shopping list of matters the next is the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act. We understand that there is general agreement but that an amendment may be moved at the committee stage. At the moment I am not aware of the nature of the amendment, so I will reserve my comments until the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to Senator Boswell, who interjected a moment too soon, and to his motion, which he has just amended to substitute-as I took it to be-`March 1990' for `October 1989'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get off his back.

—I am not on his back. It is a very broad back and capable of supporting a lot of weight, but I am not contributing to the weight that is already there. Let me say a number of things about Senator Boswell's motion to refer the matter to a committee. The first is that the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Bill seeks to provide incentives for transfer of nursing homes for disabled persons from the Nursing Homes Assistance Act (NHAA) to the Disability Services Act. The Disability Services Act provides access for people with disabilities to a more appropriate and extensive range of services. I think that that is common ground between us. The nursing homes involved have been advised that once they transfer under the Disability Services Act, additional funding as necessary will be made available to enable them to deliver a less restrictive range of services to people with disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of that, we have to say that Senator Boswell's motion serves no real worthwhile purpose. It would serve only to delay the benefits of the Disability Services Act being extended to people with disabilities in nursing homes. In our view that is not desirable. The handicapped programs review has already dealt with these matters and the Disability Services Act offers the best way of addressing them. The nursing homes and hostels review identified young people in nursing homes as one of the most disadvantaged groups. This Government wants to address that problem through this legislation. The Disability Services Act offers a very flexible range of responses to people with high support needs not limited to the nursing homes option, which is all that is available under the NHAA, and deferral will reduce time available for transition by nursing homes. Any deferral is likely to mean a full year's delay because the homes are funded on an annual budget. I put it to the Senate that that is a backdoor way of attacking the Disability Services Act, which enjoyed all-party support. The current arrangements for nursing homes are the issue.

With those words I have to say that we will not support even Senator Boswell's amended proposal as a motion, and nor, I understand, will the Australian Democrats. We would want the provisions to be carried and then we would support an inquiry into the issues Senator Boswell has raised, and thus there can be an analysis of all those things by the Senate Standing Committee, but it is desirable to get the particular amendments in place and operating. That is my understanding of the support the Government will enjoy in the chamber on the issues that Senator Boswell has canvassed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, may we see your proposed words which you have handed to the Democrats? We are interested.

—I accept the interjection. That is a fair enough request. We are trotting along at some reasonable pace. It is entirely appropriate for the honourable senator to see them. I will try to arrange for them to be passed to the Opposition by the Whip. If there is any doubt, I can go back and explain them. I have a few other remarks to make about the nub of the issues before this chamber and what has excited community debate on the Bills. Senator Puplick is looking expectant, and that brings me to Senator Puplick's--
—You have said quite enough about your alternative birthing arrangements. Just get on with the rest of the debate.

—I thought that what passed across Senator Puplick's countenance was a swift flicker of interest because I might be coming to what he proposed in this chamber by way of a motion last Thursday. If that was an expression of anticipation, let me reward it by coming to Senator Puplick's motion. This motion is not supported by the Government, and we will seek to persuade senators to vote against it. We do so, having weighed the content of the motion, and reached a number of unfortunate-for Senator Puplick-conclusions which, nonetheless, are points I should make.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick's proposal really falls into two categories. It deals with general practitioners and the health insurance amendments which the Government is proposing in this legislation. The section on general practitioners is brief. Senator Puplick is seeking to have it referred to a Senate select committee, which is to present its report on the first sitting day after 1 August. It would be quick work for a Senate select committee to canvass all the issues set out in this section but it is, nonetheless, within the competence of the Senate. The second part of the proposal is extensive in scope. It is proposed that, if this motion is carried, the Senate select committee which would be constituted should report by the first sitting day in March. There are 10 different and distinct points to the terms of reference, and it is proposed that the committee should conduct a review covering almost every aspect of medical health insurance in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cook, the Chair will require a fair copy of the proposed amendment to the amendment, if that can be organised.
—One without a `3' in the middle of `midwife', for example.

—The honourable senator appreciates the circumstances under which I am working. I am sure that the intervention of the Chair has served a very useful purpose in this chamber in that someone other than I heard that intervention, and is no doubt now moving to obtain exactly what we will need before us when I conclude my remarks!

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned the changes concerning general practitioners. The new GP fee arrangements are designed to provide financial incentives for general practitioners to undertake appropriate vocational training and maintain their skills in what is a rapidly changing field. I think most people would agree that vocational training for general practitioners is highly desirable. Indeed, the Australian Medical Association (AMA)-which, I believe, given the comments made by several senators opposite, is properly described as pulling the puppet strings of the Opposition to block this legislation-says almost as much in its own policy platform. Let me quote selectively from the policy platform of the AMA on this point as follows:
Adequate post-graduate training is pre-requisite for unsupervised medical practice.
No medical practitioner should enter unsupervised general practice without having completed such training.
The policy goes on to state:
Regular participation in continuing medical education is essential.

Those policy commitments of the AMA at that point are congruent with what the Government is proposing here. The Government is trying to encourage both vocational training and continuing medical education, and making both a pre-requisite which is what AMA policy requires. Those GPs who have sufficient practice experience, or who complete appropriate postgraduate training and who are prepared to undertake continuing medical education will be eligible to use a new set of Medicare scheduled items with higher Medicare fees and rebates. They will be eligible to enrol on a new vocational register and they will be rewarded for their efforts in undertaking general practice training just as physicians and surgeons are enrolled on vocational registers and receive higher rewards. I believe that the new arrangements will enhance the status of GPs and, more importantly, provide an improved career structure. They will promote better quality patient care, and will provide general practitioners with an opportunity to spend more time with their patients. They should result in reduced requirements for the ordering of expensive diagnostic tests, pharmaceuticals and unnecessary referrals. I stress that the new arrangements are entirely voluntary. For those GPs who are either ineligible or who choose not to enrol, the current items will remain on Medicare so that no-one is disadvantaged and no-one is worse off. The fact is that about 90 per cent of general practitioners, both full time and part time, would be automatically eligible to enrol and thus could be better off.

I think Senator Puplick's motion is rightly seen as a cynical attempt by the Opposition to display mock concern for patients and for the quality of health care. In fact, the motion is nothing short of a political manoeuvre. I think this motion attempts to undermine and discredit what the Government is trying to do and I do not believe that it should be supported in any sense.

I could make many other remarks about this provision but I want now to turn to the health insurance aspects of the motion. As I have said, the health insurance aspects are dealt with in a long explanation in the motion; there are 10 elements to its terms of reference. I stick with my remarks about the Opposition's position on GPs being cynical, but the Opposition's position on health insurance has to be seen as fairly transparent cynicism as well.

These terms of reference will try to put before a Senate select committee a wholesale review of health insurance in Australia and drag evidence from people and organisations around Australia over the next several months in an effort to dramatise what I think the Opposition believes are imperfections in Medicare. These terms of reference would attract argument on that score and provide a forum for organisational representatives to come forward and make allegations which would then attract cheap headlines without full explanations in answer to those allegations appearing-or, if they ever appear, they appear right at the back of the newspaper. These terms of reference would also try to organise or modify public perceptions of health services and the health insurance system in Australia.

If someone were to quiz me on that subject it would be fair to ask: Why would the Opposition do that? I think the real reason the Opposition would do that, and why it is proposing to do that on this occasion, is that it does not have any sort of health policy itself. In order to try to pretend expertise or standing in the field of health insurance and health delivery in Australia, the Opposition has chosen to cover its own lack by turning over to a committee all these issues to attract and generate as much public criticism of the health insurance provisions that the Government supports and, by that means, overcome the weaknesses in its own ranks. The Opposition would serve Australia much better if it were to put clearly and cogently before the community its own proposals in a way in which they can be analysed and properly criticised, rather than go on a head hunting expedition in the form that it does with these proposals.

I recognise that the Australian Democrats are proposing to support Senator Puplick's motion. I am entirely surprised that a political party, which built its reputation years ago on a quip by its then leader, Don Chipp, that its purpose in life was to `keep the bastards honest', is departing from keeping honest the alleged bastards-who I assume are us.

TALK.START.PARA: —They got that right.

—Probably Senator Boswell, too, if he wants me to drive that point home. I do not mind accepting the allegation from the Australian Democrats full on, because I am sure it is meant for the Government. What we have here is a vote grabbing exercise by the Democrats as well in respect of proper and genuine reforms which this Government wants to make and which are necessary for a proper and effective functioning of the health insurance industry in Australia.
—For about a year.
—Twelve months; just beyond the next election.

—I thank honourable senators for those interjections. They are indeed informative. We do not need the assistance of the Australian Democrats to get us beyond the next election. We will get beyond the next election and continue in government after then without the assistance of the Australian Democrats. We do not need their assistance to derail necessary health changes for electoral purposes. It is interesting that Senator Powell and Senator McLean should interject on the basis of the political content of what I am saying rather than try to defend the intention of the Australian Democrats on merit. I make that observation because I do not think it can be said that there is any merit in the proposal as put. I could have made a longer, more beautiful and more elegant speech on the proposal--
—There is not much longer.
—You have exactly one minute.

—But, as Senator Puplick and Senator Walters in concert point out to me, I have not got much longer to go, and that is true. Let me adopt the arguments that have been put in public on this matter by the Minister as if I had been able to present them here in the detail that is necessary to persuade this chamber. None of those arguments would be new to any of the Opposition or the Democrat spokespersons. I, therefore, indicate that they would be part of my reply had I been able to travel the full distance.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, therefore, there are a number of proposals on which we are of the one mind. That is a good thing. It indicates that this Government is moving solidly and deliberately down a course for which there is widespread support. There are a number of proposals, such as the second reading amendment by the Democrats, which we can find a way of supporting. It is intended to shuffle off a number of proposals to a committee, rather than face the hard decisions that governments must make in order to govern a country. It is proposed that we establish yet another endless and purposeless inquiry, which will induce no new evidence. It will serve the political purpose of screening the inadequacies of the Opposition and, maybe, the Democrats, in the health area and will merely delay the effective management by this Government of what is, in terms of Medicare and its relations with the medical profession, an enviable record that any government could aspire to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-If I may pick up the words of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after `opinion', insert: `that the Government should take action to provide financial assistance for midwife associated home births'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should explain to the Senate that there are three substantive questions before the Senate, on one of which the debate has been closed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the revised second reading amendment. In essence the form of words of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) has been picked up by Senator Jenkins. I suspect that the origin of this amendment owes something to the technique known as parthenogenesis on the Minister's part; nevertheless, it causes a degree of confusion as far as the Opposition is concerned in terms of exactly what the second reading amendment now means. We are unsure to whom it is proposed that financial assistance should be provided-in other words, whether it should be to the expectant mother or to the midwife. We are unsure as to the basis upon which it is to be provided and the extent to which it might be provided for the actual act of birth and the attendant presence of the midwife or whether somebody who is planning to have a home birth and wishes to consult the midwife in advance will be provided with some sort of financial assistance. We are unsure whether the amendment proposes a new schedule in terms of establishing a schedule of fees or rebates for midwifery services. We object in principle to the question of this all being taken, as it were, on the run by the Minister in producing a form of words, there being no opportunity to debate the substantive issue of whether or not homebirths should be financially supported through the Medicare system. That has been the subject of ongoing debate in the chamber. It is not as if this is a matter which has not been raised and debated in the chamber in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore I put on record that the Opposition will not specifically support this particular amendment. Nevertheless, given the fact that the Minister and the Australian Democrats have obviously come to an arrangement on the matter, we do not intend to divide on the question. I simply say that I do not believe that the forms of the Senate are particularly well served by adducing second reading amendments in this fashion, which leave a great deal unstated, and deny us the opportunity to explore in some detail precisely what is meant by the second reading amendment. If the amendment were being proposed to the Bill itself, we would have to take a quite different approach. But, on the basis that it is intended to be some sort of commitment-and I take it that it is a commitment, the Minister having offered it up, as it were-we will at some later stage seek avenues to explore precisely what the Government has in mind in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick's final remarks were significant. In a sense, the Government has offered a commitment. The Australian Democrats say that at the moment, prior to, hopefully, the passage of this amendment, there is nothing in place. There is no commitment; there is a vacuum. Senator Jenkins, having participated quite significantly in two homebirths as the birthing parent, has some commitment to this amendment-as do various others of us for other reasons. We do not believe that failure to support this amendment can be excused on the basis that it is a motion developed on the run-if you like, housebirth rather than homebirth.

SPEECH.PARA: If it is an issue which is of concern to the Opposition, equally as it is to the Democrats, the Opposition would be able to understand the process that is at work here. If you like, it is democracy in action. There is a proposal before the Senate to fill a very important vacuum. It is one that ought to be supported on the basis that it fills that vacuum in a significant way. As Senator Puplick has said, it is a commitment. It may not be the commitment which the Democrats sought to get at the beginning but it is certainly one on which we are prepared to build. Indeed, I understand from Senator Puplick's remarks that the Opposition will be prepared to build on it. Therefore, it is a good foundation for the future of homebirths in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the Government's position plain in view of what has been said. I agree with the summary that has been given by Senator Powell. The Government is acknowledging that contained in the original Australian Democrat amendment is an ideal worthy of endorsement. It is to that proposal that we have brought forward this form of words which we believe enables us to do that. We believe there is indeed a need to see a wider range of birthing options for women. That includes the issue of homebirths and that there are a number of elements associated with that other than simply the question of whether the cost of the midwife's attendance can be a Medicare deduction. It is best to deal with all of those things such as safety, admittance to State hospitals and so on comprehensively. It is that proposal we accept and we see the amendment in that light.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick has raised a series of questions which are a detailed examination of a number of elements of how this arrangement would work in practice. He has said that, unless he has an answer to those queries, he cannot be sure what sort of animal he is being asked to buy at the auction here. He therefore declines to bid and will vote against the amendment. I think that is a fair summation of Senator Puplick's position. None of those questions was answered by the amendment which he had full notice of, that is, the Democrats' original amendment. We do not propose to answer those issues here. But we hope to meet Senator Puplick's expectations a little further down the track when we develop the essence of this proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek your guidance, Madam Acting Deputy President. Can you tell me where the appropriate place is that we ask questions of the Minister regarding this amendment?
—It is a Democrat amendment.
—As I understand it, the Minister has given a commitment. At which stage do we ask the Minister what type of commitment he is giving?
—Do you seek leave to do it now?
—I gather I do not need to seek leave. I can just ask the Minister. The words that he has put up state:

SPEECH.PARA: But the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should take action to provide financial assistance to midwife associated homebirths.
As Senator Puplick has rightly said, there is no more detail in that than there is in the rest of the Bill. I have no intention of buying--

TALK.START.PARA: —A pig in a poke.

—A pig in a poke, as Senator Sheil says, or buying a Government commitment to what? Is it a commitment to financial assistance for midwife associated homebirths or, as Senator Puplick has said, a commitment to assist the mother? Is it a commitment to assist the midwife through Medicare, or a commitment to try to encourage private insurance to take it up, which I believe is the rightful place along with some of the other paramedical assistance given in the private schemes? Just what is meant by the Minister's commitment?

—I have answered that question in what I said earlier. I tried to make it clear that the detail is something we will develop a little later. The commitment stands. We have here, across an uncrowded room, a fairly spontaneous joining of minds between the Government and the Australian Democrats on this issue. I would have thought it was fairly narrow and pedantic to raise these trifling questions now when we are agreeing in an expression of view between the Government and the Democrats which is to be appended to the second reading motion.
—How much is it going to cost? Have you costed it or are you just taking it on the run?

—Senator Boswell asks an interesting question about costs. That seems to me to be an appropriate matter to be addressed in detail. I do not propose to go into the essence of it now. If Senator Boswell is unable to join in this spontaneous expression of view I am disappointed and sorry for him. But I hope that he can find the generosity in his soul, a little Vivaldi in his life, to join in on this occasion.
