TALK.START.PARA: —Very little detail. We want to get home tonight.

—I would like to get home, too, but I have a duty and an obligation which I should fulfil. I shall do so as quickly as I can. The draft proposals for these arrangements have been developed by the Government, as I have said, and the RACGP. The audits will be conducted by elected vocationally registered GPs from a region different from that of a doctor being audited.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the Chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —These peer review arrangements will inevitably involve auditors having some access to patient records, as do other peer review processes already operating in hospitals and supported by the Australian Medical Association and other professional medical groups. The proposals provide substantial safeguards to protect patient confidentiality. That is a matter that Senator Patterson raised. Those safeguards include a requirement that the procedures of the IPRO should be acceptable to the profession as a whole. The audit report would remain confidential to the practitioner and to the Independent Peer Review Organisation. Notification of any problems would cover only the broad general cause of concern and not identify specifics. The IPRO would be required to ensure the confidentiality of all patient information. Auditors would be from a different region and would not have ongoing contact with the practice. As I have said, legislation is necessary to implement the proposals and the Parliament would have the opportunity to ensure that it scrutinised that legislation. I hope that answers the question.

—I am sorry to prolong debate on this issue but the Minister has given us quite a bit of detail. It seems to concur with the information I have, but he did not mention the suggested membership of this Review Organisation. If he could tell us a bit about the suggested membership I would appreciate it because that would be useful to have on the public record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Minister is getting that information I draw attention to a couple of matters which arise from his previous answers. I think they reveal the validity of having decided that this matter should be sent to a Senate committee for further investigation. In essence, the Minister has told us that the Government proposes to introduce a scheme the basis of which is a working paper. It is not even a negotiated, concluded formalised agreement; it is a working paper which has allegedly been circulated to all sorts of general practitioners. Needless to say, this chamber, asked to vote on this legislation, has not had the courtesy of being provided with copies of that agreement or working paper. Senator Walters has asked for a copy. Undoubtedly, she will be provided with one, and I hope that courtesy will be extended to all senators who have taken part in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: There is little surprise on this side of the chamber at the enthusiasm with which Senator Cook is commending this closed shop agreement. That is what it amounts to. I understand the warm inner glow which Senator Cook has for closed shop agreements, negotiated with the Government by a particular minority in one field of medicine to the exclusion of other parts of the medical community, to the exclusion of some of the other general practitioners and, of course, to the exclusion of the proper interests of patients. It will be recalled that Senator Cook did not in any sense answer the question which I put to him as to what is the benefit to individual patients. He said that this was a matter of promoting better quality patient care. We do not promote better patient care simply by paying some doctors more than others unless the Government is prepared to accept the corollary of that proposal; namely, that those people who are provided with medical services by people who are not vocationally registered, for whatever reason, should accept that they are being provided with lower quality health care. That is the corollary of the proposition which the Minister has put to us this evening. We have not had an answer to Senator Walters's fundamental question as to why people in the sort of situation she described would bother constituting themselves into a general practice anyway in terms of the arrangements which the Government is now putting before us.

Finally, the Minister has not been prepared to indicate to the chamber the full details of the Independent Peer Review Organisation. We are all in possession of a document entitled `Independent Peer Review Organisation-Operating Principles'. The Minister should either tell us that this is a forgery, a bogus document, a nonsense document, or the basis upon which the auditing and monitoring functions will be carried out. If it is the latter, the Minister should table it and make it part of the formal public record so that we can debate it; otherwise, we will go through the charade of people reading out sections of the document claiming that they represent the concluded agreement or that they are operating principles. The Minister should tell us what it is. We all have the document. There is no great mystery about it. If the Minister is not prepared to table it, we will table it. He should tell us whether the concerns which have been raised about the way in which certain principles will operate are legitimate. He should tell us what the Government says these particular matters are. He should come clean with the answer to the question Senator Patterson has raised so that we will be able to make some progress, otherwise we will go through the process this evening of having a look at these 25 principles. It will be like drawing teeth. The Minister should tell us what they are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last question from Senator Patterson related to the membership of the peer group body. The membership will comprise three vocational registered general practitioners-one vocational registered GP is to be nominated by an appropriate medical organisation in consultation with the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP)--
—The emphasis has changed. The document says `the RACGP'.

—The first three vocational registered GPs are nominated by the College. The fourth person is nominated by an appropriate medical organisation in consultation with the College, one is nominated by the Health Insurance Commission, and one is nominated by the Department of Community Services and Health. Of course, they have the power to coopt as they so decide.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick made a speech in which he said I would find happiness, joy, or some cosiness or whatever, in a closed shop arrangement. I do not accept the allegation that the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners is a minority organisation, which I think was the term used by Senator Puplick. Most specialists in Australia gain recognition for having fellowships in the relevant college. Medical colleges determine the training requirements and examination standards. The RACGP is the appropriate body for the determination of standards for general practitioners. I do not accept that it is a minority body. It is the proper and relevant body.

Senator Puplick referred to a document and foreshadowed a lengthy teeth drawing exercise. If he wants to go on an excursion, we can do so, but I repeat what the Government has said about this document. It is not a final document. It is not a binding document. It is not a document which is intended to constitute a body of law or on which legal principles are drawn. It is a discussion document and, as a discussion document, it sets forward a proposal for discussion. Because it does that the Government intends to continue that discussion and bring it back to the Senate at an appropriate time-I may be wrong in this; the officers in the advisers' box can indicate if I am-possibly around October this year for legislation in the Budget session. It will be dealt with in that way. Here we are, with all due respect, ascribing to a document more than what the document is. To do that would be to commit a grievous sin, albeit we could still go through the teeth drawing exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Minister for Resources agree that if a general practitioner, in the application to the Commission, is not given registration there should be a method of appeal? Similarly, if the general practitioner is to be thrown off the register he should also have a method of appeal. Is this not just normal practice which should apply in any Bill? Does the Minister intend to insert an appeal method so that general practitioners have this right?
—I am advised that the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners will provide appeals and the regulations can be--
—Why isn't it in the Bill?
—It is in the second reading speech.

—For heaven's sake, what are the Minister's bureaucrats telling him-that it is all right if it is in the second reading speech and that we are such nongs over here we are liable to vote for something like that? For heaven's sake, why does the Minister not tell them to prepare a Bill in the correct fashion? If they believe it is common justice to have an appeal situation, then surely to heavens it should be in the Bill. We are not likely to accept that. It is not even in the second reading speech. On what page in the second reading speech are we told we have an appeal mechanism?

—Here we go again. Let me make one final effort. The regulations of which Senator Walters is complaining, and of which she complained at some length in part of her speech, are regulations which, in due course, will come to the Senate to be laid on the table. Senator Walters says, `For heaven's sake, why do you not provide them to the Senate? Why does the Government require the appeals to be there?'. My understanding is that it may well be beyond the legal authority of the Commonwealth to compel the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners to provide that mechanism. I am advised that the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners will provide a form of appeal. If Senator Walters is asking me to compel the College, I raise the defence that maybe it is beyond our legal competence to do that. In any case, proceeding as we have, by way of discussion, we expect that that provision will be there. Senator Walters asks where in the second reading speech--
—Did you say that the College would provide the appeal mechanism? Is that what you really mean?
—Yes.
—From the College to the College?

—No. It will provide within the arrangements an appeal mechanism. I should stress that it will be an independent appeal mechanism. Let me go to the question that the honourable senator asked. Without reading the whole paragraph, the answer appears at the fourth paragraph on page 2390 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 10 May. The paragraph begins with the words `The RACGP'. I think the second reading speech given in this chamber is a duplicate of that speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express to the Minister the unsatisfactory nature of the responses given to the Committee by the departmental officers, through the Minister, in relation to Senator Patterson's questions. I draw his attention to the fact that it is amazing that information can be provided to a general practitioner under the freedom of information legislation, he presumably having paid the necessary fee to obtain that information, yet the Minister is unable to provide the Committee with such information. If the Minister wants us to have a quick whip around to raise the necessary money to lodge a freedom of information application, I am sure we can arrange it. This is one of those occasions on which I believe the Minister has an obligation to indicate to us whether the information can be made available in the way in which Senator Patterson has said it should be made available to this chamber for its consideration. I seek leave to table a document entitled `Independent Peer Review Organisation-Operating Principles'. I am sure the Minister will give me leave as it will be much easier than my reading the 25 points into the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not entered the debate until now, but the last couple of comments of the Minister for Resources interested me. I ask whether he can he tell me that I am correct in thinking that that part of the second reading speech to which he was referring reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The RACGP will provide a review mechanism for its decisions relating to vocational registration, including independent arbitration, to ensure that its assessment processes are fair for all doctors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—There are two problems here. Can we be assured that that will be the independent arbitration of each individual case that might be in dispute rather than some independent assessment of the process as a whole? At one stage in my career I was dependent upon acceptance to enable me to go on a list, and it was very important to me that there should be some appeal mechanism of a quasi-judicial nature available which was not only fair, but which I could feel to be fair and which ideally was quite separate. I had hoped that it would be possible to appeal in this matter through the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act against any decisions that might be taken because of the serious effect such decisions might have for any individual practitioner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hesitate to enter this discussion, but as we are going around in circles I draw the Minister's attention to proposed new section 3g of the Bill, and point out that the words to which he has drawn attention quite clearly refer to what Senator Baume has identified as the general conditions and not the specific conditions with respect to the removal of a name from the register. Proposed new section 3g quite clearly identifies the role of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, which is to advise the General Manager, who is essentially the registrar, who keeps the list. Proposed new section 3g (2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Where the General Manager decides that a medical practitioner's name should be removed from the Register, the General Manager shall give the medical practitioner written notice of the decision.
(3) The decision shall be made in writing and shall specify the day on which the medical practitioner's name is to be removed from the Register.

There is no provision whatsoever in there for an appeal. I am really surprised to hear the Minister say that in some sense, which I completely fail to understand, it is impossible for him to write an appeal mechanism into the legislation. I would have thought that that would have been a very appropriate place for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister referred me to the second reading speech of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). The piece in the second reading speech to which the Minister referred was where it is stated that the College will provide a review mechanism for its decisions relating to vocational registration. It says nothing about decisions on individual applications. Can Senator Cook tell me where in the Minister's second reading speech it is said that the College will provide an appeal mechanism?

—I have not entered the debate until this time, but I think that the Minister has just hit a few rocks. The appeal mechanism is important and should be in the legislation. I say no more than has been said in here tonight. The Minister made light of Senator Patterson's point earlier when she said that the Government was dealing with a minority group. That is perfectly true, but the Minister denied it. There are 3,000 members of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and about 13,000 general practitioners in Australia. By far the greater majority disagree entirely with what the Government is doing here. The Government is putting a lot of emphasis on the fact that it is the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners that will be the authorising body. However, with the stroke of a pen and just by gazetting it, the Government can change the authorising body and go to any other independent body that it chooses. What the Government has put up and what the Minister has said do not fill me with any confidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I should go to the question asked by Senator Peter Baume because I think all other observations sprung from that. I must admit that when Senator Peter Baume asked his question specifically, I thought I would memorise it and answer immediately, but a number of honourable senators who have intervened had an expression of view and embroidered on his question. Let me recall, as best I can, what he asked. Firstly, he asked for verification of the particular paragraph which he read out. I verify that as the paragraph in its entirety that I would refer to as the Minister's reference in the second reading speech.

SPEECH.PARA: As I recall it, the second component of Senator Baume's question was whether the appeal mechanism-since it was not stated there, because it is stated in this sense in general terms-would deal with particular cases or appeals on generalities. I am advised that the answer to that question is yes, it would deal with particular cases.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find disturbing the Minister's failure to come to grips with these issues satisfactorily. The Committee's consideration of the legislation will progress at a fairly tedious pace from this point onwards unless some of those matters are clarified. A number of the questions raised by Senator Patterson need to be clarified. The question of the appeals mechanism as raised by Senator Peter Baume, Senator Walters and Senator Coulter needs to be clarified. We could go on all night until the Opposition is reasonably satisfied about those issues. I think that the best thing to do would be to report progress and to seek the opportunity for the Committee to be given this information when we resume our consideration tomorrow. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That progress be reported.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Senate Attendant-Bruce Stadium-Kakadu National Park-Mr Justice Vasta-Australian National: Bicentennial Celebrations-Environment

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Cook) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not hold up the Senate for long. I rise to extend my sympathy, and that of other senators, to the family of Michael Anderson-his mother, father, brother and two sisters-on the sudden loss of their son. Michael was tragically killed in an accident in Canberra. I do not wish to comment on the circumstances of the accident because charges may be laid and other investigations may take place. Michael was 26 years of age, single and had worked in the Senate as an attendant for only six weeks. Everyone to whom I have spoken, including the officers he served, has said that, during the period he worked here, Michael was outstanding in the way that he carried out his duties. He will surely be missed by the people he served during that short period of six weeks. Michael had previously spent three years in the Royal Australian Navy, had been a member of the Army Reserve and had won an award for the best recruit in 1987. I feel sure that I speak for all senators when I express to his family our deepest sympathy in the loss of their son Michael.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the Government Whip, Senator Jones, in the message of condolence to the parents of Michael Anderson. The matter about which I wish to speak tonight is the future use of the Bruce Stadium. I have spoken on this matter before in this chamber, most recently on 4 May 1989 when I asked a number of questions about the ownership of the Bruce Stadium and in whose custody it presently lies. I have not received any answers to the questions I raised at that time, which is somewhat disappointing. I also point out that at that time I incorporated a statement of the then Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Holding, which indicated that the firm of Price Waterhouse had been engaged to negotiate a financial agreement with the Canberra Raiders. I ask whether the Government has that document, and whether it will be made available.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, the Deputy Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory put out a press statement and held a press conference in which he gave the ACT Government's support for the proposal to redevelop the Bruce Stadium to enable the Raiders to use it as their home ground. I certainly do not oppose the Raiders coming to Canberra but I believe that the people of the ACT are entitled to more information than has been given at the present time about the facility. The Minister said:
The ACT is gaining a $40 million asset which we will develop into a first-class multi-use sporting venue.

The question that now needs to be answered by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) is whether the stadium is a gift to the ACT Government or whether it is an asset being transferred for $40m or for some other amount. If it is not a gift, what are the terms under which it is being transferred?

This afternoon the Deputy Chief Minister apparently indicated that the Australian Institute of Sport would be entering into a lease with the Bruce Stadium Trust, which will be established to manage the stadium. I also ask the Minister for Administrative Services: When was the property transferred to the Australian Institute of Sport and what arrangement does the Australian Institute of Sport, the head lessee, have with the Bruce Stadium Trust?

I wrote to the Minister for Administrative Services on 5 June, as I had received no response to the speech I made on 4 May. I asked him what was happening, what the arrangements were for ownership and whether the stadium was to be transferred to the Australian Capital Territory Government as a gift, an encumbered gift or by way of a sale. I also wrote to the Deputy Chief Minister on 5 June asking him questions about the arrangements. I have not had an answer from him either. It is important for the people of the Australian Capital Territory to fully understand the financial arrangements. The Bruce Stadium will need to bring in a considerable amount of revenue to pay for the money that will be borrowed to redevelop it. As has been indicated by the Deputy Chief Minister, it will be operating on full commercial principles. If it is not able to operate in that fashion, who will make up the shortfall? It seems to me that it would be a fairly expensive facility for any other group to lease, so that will have an impact on the amount of revenue that can be raised.

The other questions which are still outstanding are: What will happen to the Northbourne oval? What arrangements will be made for improving road access to Bruce Stadium and the parking facilities there? I have no doubt that, when the Raiders play there, massive crowds will be wanting to attend, and I will be amongst them. But the present arrangements for parking in that area are putting enormous stress on the facilities when the indoor stadium is crowded with 5,000 spectators watching a Cannons match. The cost of upgrading road access and parking in the area will need to be taken into account sooner or later. Is it being included in the redevelopment costs or is that an additional cost? How much of this will ACT taxpayers be paying?

As I have said-and I stress this-my interest in this matter is in no way concerned with trying to keep out the Raiders as there are significant benefits to Canberra in having them based here. But I think we are entitled to know about these matters. The ACT Government, since it was formed, has frequently stressed that there will be open government and that we will know what is happening. But at present I think both Federal and ACT Ministers have failed to give the people of Canberra the information they are entitled to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some comments in respect of a matter that was raised a few nights ago by Senator Zakharov when she tabled a document entitled On Shaky Ground prepared by David Cooper, an employee-if not an employee, a past employee-of the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority. It is significant that, when Senator Zakharov tabled the document, she overlooked the fact that it was prepared by Mr Cooper and that, by and large, the document is a response by Mr Cooper to criticisms contained in the minority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts of Mr Cooper and the veracity of his evidence. If honourable senators examine the document they will see at the bottom of it that it is written by Mr David Cooper; otherwise they would not know that.

SPEECH.PARA: In large measure the minority report produced Committee evidence which is contradictory to Mr Cooper's views. In my view, the document produced by David Cooper is nothing more than a self-serving instrument designed to vindicate the views he upholds and the evidence that he gave to the Committee. In my view, the document is a distortion of the facts. It reeks of bias, it is riddled with illogical conclusions and it is so confused in its reasoning that it leads one to conclude that it is written without regard for the truth. The first major paragraph states:

As is a common occurrence with standing committee reports, the tabled document included a dissenting report by Senators Crichton-Browne, McGauran and Panizza, which is highly critical of the majority findings of the Committee.
Of course, that is palpable nonsense. The minority report's recommendations are based on the evidence and it is not critical-let alone highly critical-of the majority report.

The document entitled On Shaky Ground, written by David Cooper, is a criticism of the minority report written by Senators Crichton-Browne, McGauran and Panizza in respect of the potential of the Kakadu National Park region. I find remarkable the fact that Cooper supports much of his document by referring to his own evidence or his own writings. I might say that I hardly find that persuasive evidence. For instance, Cooper tells us in 1:

Coronation Hill lies within an area known to the Jawoyn people as the ``Sickness Country''. The Sickness Country derives its significance from an important and dangerous creation Being Buladeno (Bula) whose spiritual essence pervades the landscape. Jawoyn custodians fear that disturbance of Bula by activities such as mining will result in apocolyptic destruction . . .

On that occasion, Cooper refers to his own evidence. I make no particular judgment about the relevance of the sickness country. However, what Mr Cooper does not disclose is that part of that sickness country was subject to a Jawoyn land claim in 1987. Mr Justice Kearney found, and I refer to parts 4 and 5:

The two senior claimants who spoke with knowledge of Areas 4 and 5, Peter Jatbula and Sandy Barraway, did not convey an impression of interest in those areas or of any strong attachment to them. While several sites in the vicinity of Areas 4 and 5 were named and their associated Dreamings identified, no evidence to establish common spiritual affiliations by the claimants of those sites or the performance or spiritual responsibilities for those sites was given in either open or closed sessions of the enquiry.
It goes on to say, inter alia:

However, the traditional evidence put forward in relation to Areas 4 and 5 is insufficient to enable any finding to be made that the members of that group (or any group, for that matter) are the traditional Aboriginal owners of those areas, within the meaning of the Act. While there are sites on both areas and Dreamings to which the Jawoyn have links . . . the existence of common spiritual affiliations to sites on Areas 4 and 5, or to sites which can be linked with those areas, is not established; nor is there evidence of a strong traditional attachment to Areas 4 and 5. Accordingly, the claim to Areas 4 and 5 fails.

That tells us that, in the view of the Land Commissioner, the claims were not of intrinsic value in respect of the criteria set down in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 for them to be granted as traditional land. In the next paragraph of this dissertation, we are told:

In 1985, custodians discovered exploration activity in progress at Coronation Hill, known to the Jawoyn as Guratba. Coronation Hill was subsequently registered as part of a large sacred site complex, the Upper South Alligator Bula Complex.

The truth is that the custodians did not discover exploration activity in progress at Coronation Hill. They were told that exploration activity was taking place by the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority. At this point Mr Cooper neglects to mention, although he did mention it later on because he had no choice, that it was he who was driving the motor vehicle, whose occupants were Larry Ah-Lin and Peter Jatbula, and that he drove them to Coronation Hill. In fact, Mr Cooper drove past an employee of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) down a dead-end road. When he returned, as inevitably he was bound to, he was asked by that employee who he was and the purpose of his business. He was at first reluctant to disclose who he was or the nature of his visit. Mr Jatbula, Mr Cooper and Mr Ah-Lin were subsequently escorted off BHP's property by the employee.

Cooper at that stage having identified himself and the names of the others and said that he was an employee of the Sacred Sites Authority, BHP then contacted the Coronation Hill joint venture operation office in Brisbane, which contacted the Sacred Sites Authority, which in turn advised that Mr Cooper was working in the Eva Valley area and that if he happened to be on Coronation Hill he was surely lost. Of course, the truth is that he had driven directly from Katherine to Coronation Hill. He was lost to the extent that he was driving down a dead-end road, but he certainly knew where he was trying to get to.

I do not suggest that there is anything sinister about that, but let us have the record honestly on the table. Mr Cooper's role in the decisions of the conduct of these matters ought to be seen for what it is. Clearly, Cooper took Jatbula and Ah-Lin out to Coronation Hill to see what exploration and prospecting was taking place. Mr Cooper tells us that the custodians brought exploration activity by BHP to a halt. Mr Cooper neglects to mention in his document that he attended the meeting of the Jawoyn people when they discussed BHP East Coronation Hill exploration on 1 July and that he addressed that meeting for 45 minutes, speaking in the most forceful, powerful and persuasive way that he knew possible, presumably to convince them that they ought not to agree to mining. We are further told in Cooper's document that:

The Dissenting Report, however, lacks any semblance of impartiality. It has been constructed so as to cast doubt on the credibility of the concerns of Jawoyn custodians about Coronation Hill and the Bula Sickness Country. To achieve this end the authors of the Dissenting Report have repeated discredited allegations regarding the views of senior custodians and the role and propriety of those statutory bodies charged with assisting custodians in preserving their traditions and religious beliefs.

There were not organisations; there was one organisation. He was talking about his own, the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority. Although the report does not say so, Mr Cooper's name keeps appearing in footnotes. If Mr Cooper is saying that I personally questioned his propriety, for my part, I have to say frankly that I question his evidence and I find it, by definition on the evidence we have taken, not to be truthful. I will deal with that a little later on. Cooper's main complaint seems to be that the minority report does not take as gospel his word. He finds it offensive that the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts can be inexorably led to a conclusion on the basis of clear and precise evidence given to the Committee by the elders and custodians of the Jawoyn people. He says this about the minority report:
Instead it relies heavily on three controversial and problematic pieces of evidence, namely . . .

He then refers to evidence that was given to us relating to one Steven Davis, which was dealt with some nights ago by Senator Grant Tambling, so I shall not traverse that territory again. He also finds it offensive for us to find compelling evidence given to us, as he describes, `in camera' by the Jawoyn custodians-evidence `taken by the Senate Committee at Barunga on 9 March 1987'. He refers then to what he claims to be hearsay evidence of a meeting that took place at Barunga on 15 August 1988.

In respect of finding it offensive that we took cognisance of and drew conclusions from evidence given by the Jawoyn people to our Committee, I find it an absolute cheek for Mr Cooper to criticise the evidence given to the Committee by the elders simply because it is a piece of evidence that the Committee received first hand that does not agree with a view that he has put. It is not without significance that it contrasts with other material produced which is allegedly a contrary view of the Jawoyn people and which is helped in its preparation by Cooper in the name of the Jawoyn people. In the publication Cooper goes on to say, talking about the Barunga evidence:

The publication of these transcripts is highly prejudicial to the standing and credibility of the Aboriginal custodians concerned, reflecting an opportunistic exploitation of their comments without fair or proper regard for their concerns, or indeed, for the public perception of the veracity of these concerns.
In truth, the publication of the transcripts is prejudicial to Cooper's views, to the evidence that he has given, and to the view that he would have sought the Jawoyn people to give us.

As I said earlier, Senator Grant Tambling dealt with material provided to the Committee by one Steven Davis. I do not want to traverse that ground again, but this whole document is riddled with accusations, criticisms and ridicule of Mr Steven Davis. Mr Cooper does not tell us that in some way, the details of which I am not familiar with, the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority, or the Director, Mr Ellis, with clearly the overt encouragement and support of Mr Cooper, is engaged in some form of litigation with Mr Davis. It seems that this document in some way puts outside the court the views he has. This is what Mr Cooper tells the world in his report:

It is perhaps illustrative of the tension and confusion surrounding these meetings that a rumour circulated amongst Aboriginal custodians, that they would ``be shot'' if they did not give approval for BHP Gold to go ahead at Coronation Hill. This rumour, corroborated by a number of custodians, was voiced by senior custodian, Nipper Brown, during the meeting of 4th July where he is recorded as saying, `` . . . let him. Give it up [Coronation Hill] him. `Nother way you only get a bullet''. Nipper, it should be noted, was one of the principal informants used by Davis to obtain the transcript which was later quoted in the Dissenting Report. It was, in fact, recorded on the day before Nipper made the above statement.

Again Mr Cooper failed to mention his own contribution to that debate and the fact that the NLC came along to a meeting on 4 July and in a very aggressive, verbally bullying way he sought to convince the Jawoyn people that they ought not to agree to mining on Coronation Hill.

To the extent that Mr Cooper is obsessed with Mr Davis's evidence, I will bother to read this section of our report and our treatment of the video transcript. Mr Davis, I might say to enlighten the Senate for those who are riveted to this speech, provided the transcript of a video which he had taken with a number of senior custodians. It was suggested by Mr Cooper that we found this document so compelling that it led us to make the recommendations that we did. Let me make it quite clear that our report says:

Mr Davis states he was asked by Sandy Barraway, Nipper Brown, two senior Jawoyn custodians, to take them to Sleisbeck to see a major Bula site-a Bulalak-which they had identified from photographs taken by Arnott and reproduced in a 1962 edition of Oceania and accompanied by one of his articles. According to Davis, previously Brown and Barraway had been led to believe, by the others (not Aborigines) the major Bula to be located elsewhere, in fact, on Coronation Hill, a confusion caused by a period of loss in living memory . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —What is located on Coronation Hill?
—A Bula. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . not only of the major Bula but of other, sites of significance to the Jawoyn people.

I then go on to explain who attended the visit to Sleisbeck. It was Nipper Brown, Sandy Barraway, Roy Anderson, Queenie Brown, Willy Byer, Rebecca Byer, Rita Anderson and Phyllis Wynjorroc. They are all very senior people in the Jawoyn community. I then went on to repeat the wording of the transcript that was given to us and was incorporated and became part of the evidence. On each occasion I referred to Mr Davis's conclusions and not our own. I concluded by saying:
We agree with the majority report that this evidence seems to cast some doubt on the validity of the original decision to include Coronation Hill within a registered sacred site.

By any measure, any sensible person reading our report would see that we are simply faithfully reporting the evidence that was given to us and reporting the conclusions that Mr Davis has made and not conclusions that we have made.

Mr Cooper went on to make a number of other claims. He suggests in his report that I had received information from the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority and that I had misrepresented what was given to me. Mr Cooper would not be aware of the truth of the matter and I will deal with this later. At the time I spoke to the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority I was faithfully taking down verbatim that which was given to me. I wrote it into the report at that very moment. I was relying neither on memory nor on second-hand evidence.

Perhaps the lowest point of Mr Cooper's self-serving document is his arrogant assertion that evidence given to us by the Jawoyn is wrong. He then produces in his report some obscure conversation he alleges he apparently had with one of them on some unknown occasion. He again expresses real indignation that the minority report relies in part on the evidence of the Jawoyn custodians for its findings rather then his own opinion. He then has the audacity to try to explain that the custodians' evidence was wrong. He offers some drivel about Nipper Brown telling him he did not understand that blasting would take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true. It was very clear on a number of occasions that there was a belief on the part of a number of people.

—Senator Zakharov's interpretation, to be clear to her, was simply pathetic drivel. It is interesting how Mr Cooper's private conversations with the custodians are quite different to the evidence the Committee received from the custodians. However, that notwithstanding, I shall quote the evidence and report of the Committee on the matter of explosives being used following the visit to Groote Eylandt.

SPEECH.PARA: I bother to do that at some considerable pain to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and no doubt to the other honourable senators who are sitting here tolerantly, because it is put by Mr Cooper that Nipper Brown and the other senior custodians of the Jawoyn people, having been to Groote Eylandt, seen the open cut operations and the explosives, had come to some obscure belief that it was possible to extract all the gold, all the silver and all the other minerals and metals from Coronation Hill without using explosives. This would be achieved by some wondrous means of putting into the ground a diamond drill bit which would bring out these minerals. Senator Devlin, the Labor member on the Committee, asked:

If the Jawoyn people are prepared to let exploration go on, knowing full well that there is gold, platinum and everything else at Coronation Hill, are you saying you would not be happy for these minerals to be mined after completion of the exploration.

That is a pretty reasonable question to ask. Exploration permits are not granted if, at the end of the day, it is not intended to let somebody mine the area. Mr Fordimail, one of the elders-somebody who has always taken the view that Coronation Hill is a sacred site and ought not to be mined-responded:
We are quite happy with the way BHP has been doing it because it has agreed to employ the Jawoyn people.
Senator Townley then asked:
So you would most probably be happy if you could get a suitable agreement with the people who might do the mining?
Mr Fordimail responded, `Yes'. Later the chairperson, Senator Zakharov, asked:
Have the BHP people said they would get you money if mining went ahead?
Mr McDonald, one of the Jawoyn elders, said:

They showed us what they were doing at Groote Eylandt. We went to Groote Eylandt and had a look around at what BHP does with them there. They showed us around there and the Aboriginal people were happy with what BHP had done with them. When we came back we had a meeting about that with the Jawoyn mob and they said that if there is mining like that it is alright.
I would have thought that was pretty elementary and something that most honourable senators would be able to interpret at first reading. The Committee's minority report went on to say:

We are advised by BHP that Jawoyn people in inspecting the Groote Eylandt mining operation saw exploration activity, mining activity, the town layout and rehabilitation of the island. They observed blasting, quarrying and all the normal functions of a mining operation. BHP state that they also went to some trouble to explain to the Jawoyn people the difference in the size of the projects and the method of open cut mining.
In other words, BHP was making it clear that Groote Eylandt was a modest operation compared with that which could be expected on Coronation Hill. The minority report also stated:

It is difficult to conclude that Jawoyn custodians, having visited Groote Eylandt and observed mining operations, could have been labouring under the misapprehension that Mr Cooper ascribes to them, particularly given the quite precise and unequivocal statement given by Mr McDonald.

That was not an unreasonable conclusion to draw from the evidence. Mr Cooper made much of the fact that women were present and contributed to the evidence given by the Jawoyn elders at Barunga. However, he conveniently overlooked the fact that the witnesses provided for the hearing were decided by him and the Jawoyn people. I assume that Senator Zakharov may have had some vague involvement in selecting witnesses. Under the circumstances, I would assume that the witnesses representing the Jawoyn people would have been selected by the Jawoyn people and no doubt Mr Cooper and not Senator Zakharov, because to my knowledge neither she nor any of the other Committee members had met them. For Mr Cooper's part, the women's evidence was not a bit helpful to his anti-mining cause. Not only did he claim that they should not have been there but also the thrust of his insinuation was that they would now know what they were talking about.

To refresh the memory of those who are still riveted by this speech, perhaps we should look at the Jawoyn land claim. I am sure I do not need to remind the Senate of the statutory requirements of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 for establishing traditional Aboriginal ownership. They are the local descent group, sites in Jawoyn traditional country, common spiritual affiliations, primary spiritual responsibility and traditional right to forage. They are all matters which go intrinsically to the heart of the claim. I refer the Senate to pages 36 and 56 of the Aboriginal Land Commissioner's report on the Aboriginal land right claim of the Jawoyn people. What they will see, in splendid, sparkling black and white, are photographs of Sarah Flora. The captions of two of the photographs say `Sarah Flora gives evidence at Jurrangluk' and `Sarah Flora gives evidence to the Commissioner on site'. There is another photograph on page 6. Obviously, Sarah Flora had some appeal either to the photographer or to the Commissioner. She appears in the report three times in half-page photographs, as giving evidence, or as doing this or as doing that. The report is riddled with quotes by women cited by the Commissioner as giving evidence which he uses either to dismiss the claim or to accept the claim. But he certainly accepts the evidence from the women as central to the determination he will make regarding the definitions I have just read out.

Now we have this Mr Cooper, a fly-by-night white man, telling us that these people have no right to be at a committee meeting of the Senate-people who were invited by the Committee, the Jawoyn people themselves. And this Mr Cooper has the audacity to say that women should not be there. The women cited in this report are the same women who gave evidence to our Committee. I have no doubt that when they gave their evidence for the purpose of the land claim, Mr Cooper would have embraced with some enthusiasm the evidence they gave, standing by its veracity. When one reads the evidence of the Jawoyn women elders, it is not difficult to understand why Cooper is not pleased with it. I have their evidence. I seek leave to table the evidence that was provided at Barunga.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. This is in camera evidence. Is it in order to table it?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I draw your attention to the document that Senator Zakharov tabled in this chamber on 5 June 1989, pages 9, 10, 11 and 12. It includes extensive quotations of the very in camera evidence that Senator Zakharov is now seeking not to have tabled.

—A point of order has been raised as to whether it is appropriate to table in camera evidence. I, in the Chair-and, I think, other senators-have not seen the material. It may be wise for Senator Crichton-Browne to defer the tabling of the document until he finishes his remarks. Similarly, we can defer the question of leave being granted to table it. Those who are interested may look at the document. It is then up to individual senators as to whether they think there is some reason why it would be inappropriate to give leave. Leave is not granted if one senator is not willing to give leave. Senator Crichton-Browne, I ask you to circulate the material or give it to the Deputy Clerk so that it can be examined and then continue with your remarks.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I thank you for that very wise counsel and guidance. With respect, it would be useful at this point if I were able to quote from the document. The evidence I seek to have tabled is but an extension of that which was tabled by Senator Zakharov herself but a week ago as a result of the release of in camera evidence by Mr Cooper which is contained in the report and which I am now fully able to read out. All I am asking for is leave for the extension of that evidence to be tabled. That is the thrust of it. It is not new material. Senator Zakharov knows the evidence intimately. But, Mr Acting Deputy President, if in spite of that you wish me to proceed, I will so do. I now have three minutes, 180 seconds, in which to speak. I would like to know whether this document is to be tabled. I am not going to be able to complete what I had to say tonight, but I shall not be daunted. I will complete my remarks tomorrow night.

SPEECH.PARA: The thrust of what I am saying is that the Aboriginal women, whose evidence Mr Cooper referred to but which I am not allowed to refer to, gave compelling evidence of a nature which would lead any responsible committee made up of wise counsel to believe it ought to draw certain conclusions. They were conclusions that we ultimately felt compelled to follow. Mr Cooper refers to my questioning of the Jawoyn people as firm, close and improper. If I were able to table this transcript people would be able to read it in the blessed relief of their homes or wherever they choose and see that the evidence was taken with care, sensitivity and due diligence to the responsibilities cast upon me. One of my colleagues, now departed from this chamber, went to some trouble to ask the witnesses before us whether they felt quite comfortable and relaxed and whether they were intimidated in any way. With considerable enthusiasm they all nodded to Senator Townley. I cannot say what they said because I am not allowed to, but they nodded very agreeably that they were not in any way intimidated by the questions put to them. Cooper, referring to the presence of women, states in his report that this information was conveyed to the Committee in submission, but that the dissenting report fails to acknowledge this evidence despite using large extracts of the Barunga transcript obtained in problematic circumstances. Mr Cooper is saying that we have not used his evidence. I seek leave to have the balance of the evidence tabled.
Leave granted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT=m Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a fair, free and humane society people facing serious allegations are given a proper hearing. Whether they be powerful or weak, rich or poor, prominent or obscure, their case is dealt with by due process. Due process requires the body judging a person's conduct to give sufficient thought to the issue. Where it does not, justice is put at risk. Last Wednesday, 7 June 1989, the Queensland Parliament debated the fate of Mr Justice Vasta, as he then was. Some members needed more time to consider the matter. An adjournment for seven days was sought. It was refused. Parliament then removed the judge from the Supreme Court.

SPEECH.PARA: Concern is to be expressed when members are asked to make a grave decision but are denied sufficient time to think about it. A man was stripped of his office, his reputation and his future by a body only part of which felt the matter had been properly considered. It is easy to ensure due process for the good, the beautiful and the supposedly innocent. The test of a fair, free and humane society is the extent to which it ensures due process for the bad, the ugly and the supposedly guilty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to advise the Senate of some obstructionism and petty mindedness by the Australian National Railways Commission (AN), the rail line owned by the Federal Government, which did its best to obstruct an exciting bicentennial project. It is now effectively robbing an eager group of volunteers of $21,000, apart from the group's entirely voluntary contribution to the project, which was a trans-Australia rail journey by hand trike-to be a world record hand trike journey. There is no doubt that the committee which ran this bicentennial project agreed to the mean-minded demand from Australian National for $21,000 in order to get this project approved. It then hoped that it would be able to bring a sense of reality to this obstructionist, bureaucratic and, one would gather from its past activities, fairly incompetent body.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter goes back to May 1987 when the first request was made to Australian National to operate a Sheffield hand-pushed trike from Perth to Sydney via Adelaide as a contribution to Australia's bicentenary celebrations. From May until January 1988, which was the start of the bicentennial year, Australian National obstructed this project by refusing to give its approval. For example, on 15 July in his first response to the May letter of the Across Australia Hand Trike Committee, the Manager of Australian National, Mr D. G. Williams, said:

Although your proposal sounds fascinating and would no doubt create a considerable amount of public interest, I regret to advise that I consider it impractical to allow such a journey over this corridor.

With the extremely high traffic density which exists on this route, Australian National has to work very hard to achieve and maintain its passenger and freight performance goals. A movement of this nature, which would probably take several weeks to complete, has the potential to create a large number of serious problems with our scheduling. There would also be considerable additional costs involved especially if a locomotive (a resource very much in demand due to rationalisation) was to remain captive to a support train.
Therefore although I believe that your idea is certainly a novel one, I am sorry that I am unable to accede to your request.

That was the first shot in a campaign of obstruction. It went on and on. The Across Australia Hand Trike Committee was not disheartened. Mr John Cooper, the project's administrative manager, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 20 July 1987. Mr Cooper is certainly no supporter of our side of politics; he evidenced his support for Mr Hawke in his letter in which he said:

I have been a railwayman for some 30 years and I am proud of the fact. My current position is Chief Train Controller with the State Rail Authority of New South Wales. A group of fellow workers believe that the railway man has played an enormous significance in the development of this great country and thus should be included and saluted during the Bi-Centenary Celebration next year.

Our Committee has put forward a plan to hand operate a Sheffield push trike from Perth to Sydney as the focal point of our salute. The operations of the trike would involved in excess of 1000 people right across Australia. It would be the longest trike journey in the world, and we believe would attract its good share of publicity among a host of other great events planned.
The Australian Bicentennial Authority's Special Director is most enthusiastic and has indicated that it is the type of event which they are in need of as it involves people right across Australia.
That certainly did not do much for Australian National because there was still no joy. On 9 September Mr Cooper wrote again to Australian National asking it to reconsider its obstruction. He said:

I recently read the glowing reports which the Government of South Australia cast on Australian National for its part in that State's 150th Anniversary. What we are seeking is to honour these men and the thousands which passed before them . . . It is not our intention to cause massive disorganisation to your regular operations, but to compile a reasonably workable timetable for the journey around existing services.

The point I make here is that it is good enough for Australian National to participate fully in the 150th anniversary of South Australia but it is not good enough for it to participate in Australia's bicentennial celebrations in any sort of reasonable, coherent, decent or honourable way. That letter received a response on 29 September from Mr Williams, the General Manager, who wrote:

As indicated in previous correspondence a movement of this nature, taking several weeks to complete, has the potential to create serious operating problems and I am not prepared to alter Australian National's stance in this instance.

Once again, it is straightforward, uncomplicated obstructionism. Australian National said that the project `has the potential to create serious operating problems'. In fact, that was all bunkum; it did not. On 27 November, Mr Peter Duncan, who was then the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, wrote back to Mr Cooper and said:
Australian National has advised me that your proposal would involve substantial disruption-
it has gone from a potentially substantial disruption to a substantial disruption-
to train scheduling on a route with extremely high traffic density, and that it is unable to grant your request.
He ends up:
I am sorry I am unable to assist you. I certainly support the recognition of Australia's railway pioneers and hope you can arrange an appropriate salute.

The Government, not being prepared to do anything practical to help, hands out some soft soap, some nonsense words, and does nothing. On 26 December 1987 the Trike Committee again wrote to Mr John Charter, the Assistant General Manager of Australian National, pointing out just how it could do this without disrupting transport and without disrupting schedules. I quote from the letter:
It is now proposed the SHEFFIELD CONQUEST-
that is, Trike-

be worked under perway conditions such as an inspection car checking the line. The trike can be removed . . . by the 4 operators without difficulty. It is anticipated that the average speed of the trike would be approximately 15 kph and this would give as a daily distance of 150 kph based on a 10 hr day spread over twelve hours. This would be the maximum distance proposed and in effect working on siding to siding the distance would be less, example day one of the AN Section would be Kalgoorlie to Karonie, a distance of 131 kms.

So it was established clearly that there would be no disruption to schedules. On 6 January 1988, at last, eight months later, Australian National energetically springs into action. Having delayed this project until the bicentennial year had started, it created immense difficulties for organisers in getting it under way. But on 6 January Australian National wrote to Mr Cooper saying:
. . . we agree, in principle, that the project . . . be approved.

I reiterate the position which Australian National has taken, namely that the project should be at no cost to this System, and secondly the progress should be such as to produce no disruption to our normal commercial traffic.

That is all very well. It need not have taken eight months to work that out. I am interested that it says that the project should be at no cost to the system. But from the bills that have been sent to this volunteer committee, it looks as though there has been some profit to Australian National, unless its costs of doing things are just unbelievable. On 8 July 1988 Australian National again wrote to Mr Cooper outlining what these costs would be:

At this time costs associated with the supply of support staff for safeworking reasons has not been finalised, and you will be advised when to hand. Costs for the haul of the support vehicles between Broken Hill and Kalgoorlie, returning via Adelaide is $2,850.60 per car.
As Australian National's contribution for the Across Australia Sheffield Hand Trike project, I am prepared to make the ABJX-
that is, the particular carriage-
available at no charge for the duration of the project, however, there will be a haulage charge of $2,371.00.

I do not know how Australian National gets that figure; but, if that is its actual cost of operation, I am astounded. It looks very much like its normal charge for commercial users. If that is so, it is an absolute disgrace. On 18 July 1988 the Hand Trike Committee wrote to Mr Bannon to try to get him on side. In fact, it ended up getting the New South Wales Government rail system and the Western Australian rail system on side. Only Australian National insisted on charging it money. The Committee in a letter to Mr Bannon stated:

. . . on 26 December 1987 we submitted an amended application to Australian National based on the use of NSW Rail Transport Museum Locomotive and using enginemen who have volunteered to work the train without receiving payment. This system is widely used by rail societies in NSW and also at Peterborough South Australia on the Steamtown Museum trains. We had men lined up who were ready, willing and able to support this project. However, at the meeting of the Federal Council of the AFULE in Launceston in March this year, a ban was placed on their men participating in our salute.

It is incredible that this one rail union-all the other rail unions have agreed to participate on a voluntary basis-insisted that there should be no volunteer operation, and a ban was placed on its men participating in the salute. The letter continued:

Once again we were forced to go back to Australian National and seek another solution. During negotiations with Australian National we were frequently reminded that Australian National is a commercial operation with little interest in heritage or the past and that they would be making a charge for the service they provided.

Has Australian National never heard of public relations or of the benefit of actually involving itself in a project like this, in the same way as a genuine, fair dinkum commercial operation which knows how to make a quid, rather than lose a quid, which is apparently Australian National's greatest attribute? Surely, a company with commercial wisdom would have been prepared to use this as a promotional activity. After all, it was prepared to do something similar during the South Australian 150th anniversary celebrations. The letter continued:

On 13 July I received a quote for moving the travelling exhibition we have prepared which contains a sales and historical display van; a lounge-dining-shower car; a sleeping car to accommodate 20 people; a service van containing mobile workshop, power generators, spare parts and cooking facilities. All these vehicles have been made available by the State Rail Authority of New South Wales at no cost. The ABJX wagon referred to in the attached letter from Australian National is owned by them and they have made it available, but unlike Westrail or State Rail, they require us to pay for this movement, which in total amounts to over $16,000.
What a great contribution! What a great sense of national pride by Australian National! That is a misplaced title if ever I have heard one. The letter continued:

In addition to this cost, the provision of safe working employees is expected to be in the order of $10,000. This amount of money is beyond our capacity and although we have been busily seeking sponsors it is really difficult to convince railway suppliers and supporters that they should sponsor this event when the organisation which stands to benefit most, that is Australian National, is seeking to make a hefty charge to move the vehicles necessary for the Salute's progress.
Another letter to Mr Hawke in 1988 states in part:
Our biggest section is controlled by Australian National from Kalgoorlie to Broken Hill. Once having obtained approval it was then a matter of costs.

The letter outlines the cost situation and it then outlines also what happened to the Australian Federated Union of Locomotive Enginemen when it withdrew its support and prohibited its members from being involved in the movement of the support unit unless on duty and receiving their full award wage. The letter continues:
All other major rail unions have not only pledged their moral support, but actually made financial donations to the cause.

The letter then appeals for Mr Hawke's assistance in meeting this payment, either by paying Australian National the actual cost it is seeking, or by convincing Australian National management it should support an historic salute to its own history. On 12 September 1988 another letter was written to Mr Hawke outlining what had happened when the salute started at the Perth terminal on Saturday, 3 September. The letter states:

. . . the West Australian Minister for Transport Mr Bob Pearce, and the West Australian Commissioner for Railways, Dr Jim Gill, both offered their sincere congratulations to the team that had orchestrated the salute, saying they believed the railway system had a great future and it was fitting that we salute those who have made this exciting future possible. The West Australian Government supported this salute totally, and Mr Pearce and Dr Gill joined with our Chairman, Ken McCawley, and Executive Officer, John Cooper, and pushed the Sheffield Conquest for the first section of this across Australia push.

The Western Australian Government is doing the right thing, even to the extent of pushing for this. Mr Hawke and Mr Peter Morris were asked whether they would like to get physically involved in this salute by pushing the vehicle at some stage. There are those who say that neither of those people could push anything uphill at the moment, but regrettably they were unavailable and could not participate.

Even Mr Bannon wrote to the Hon. Ralph Willis, the Minister for Transport and Communications, asking him to help out. Mr Bannon was totally on-side. In December 1988 Mr Bob Brown, the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, wrote to Mr Bannon in response, saying:
. . . the charges Australian National proposes would recover only the direct additional costs of having the project on the rail system.

If these were the direct additional costs it is no wonder that Australian National cannot make a quid. The invoice which I have before me shows that it cost $21,584.05. Quite frankly, I am appalled if that is what it cost. I seek leave to table the invoice.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. On 14 March 1989 there was another letter to Bob Brown from the executive officer, which was very disappointing because the committee had had to guarantee that it would personally pay the account from Australian National as it could not get support from the Government and from sponsors who said, `We're not interested in paying Australian National for the right for you people to do something that Australian National should be allowing you to do and should be joining in and helping you do'. After the great farewell given by the Western Australian Government and its Ministers and the Western Australian Rail Commissioner, the letter to Bob Brown noted:

SPEECH.PARA: To arrive in Adelaide and find not one executive officer from Australian National there was not only disappointing but almost devastating.

So not only did Australian National obstruct the thing for months and charge some $21,000 but also it could not even turn up when the bicentennial project arrived in Adelaide-a bicentennial project which was in the main celebrating the Bicentenary of Australia by drawing attention to the contribution to Australia's history of railmen, particularly those involved in that large stretch of rail from Kalgoorlie to Broken Hill. The letter stated:
The whole purpose of visiting Adelaide was because it is Australian National's headquarters and a major keystone in the journey across Australia.
It continued:
I well remember Mr John Charter of Australian National telling me not to arrive or leave Adelaide on Sunday . . .
Presumably that was because it wanted to be involved in this matter. In that letter Mr Cooper, who, as I have said, is an executive of State Rail in New South Wales, said:
The real cost to Australian National of our event would have been less than one tenth the amount charged.

It is noteworthy that everyone else did not charge anything, including Ansett Airlines of Australia, which provided, free of charge, tickets for travel to and from Perth on a space available condition for some members of the crew. I will mention a few more letters briefly because I think this is an absolute disgrace. My friend and colleague from the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales, Mr Stephen Martin, MP, has been involved in this matter and has done his best to try to encourage the Government to do something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the journalist Stephen Martin?

—It is the imitation one; it is the one who, long after I started those columns, succeeded me ultimately in the seat of Macarthur in New South Wales. Steve Martin, who is a decent bloke and who has done his best in this matter, approached all the Ministers involved and I regret that all his efforts came to nothing. Mr Bob Brown, the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, wrote to Mr Martin on 20 May this year saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the circumstances I must rely on AN's commercial judgment in this matter and regretfully advise that no further assistance can be provided.
The last letter is dated 26 May this year, from Bob Brown to Mr Cooper, and it states:

I regret . . . there is nothing I can add to my letter of 13 December 1988 to the Premier of South Australia. As I mentioned to him, the Federal Government requires AN to operate commercially and independently of Ministerial involvement on operational matters. AN clearly set out the conditions under which it was prepared to be involved in the project before it occurred, and did provide considerable assistance to your project though perhaps not all you sought.
I can only reaffirm that under the circumstances no further assistance can be provided.

I understand why the Government felt it could not give any instruction to Australian National. I think it is a pretty wimpish approach. This was the Bicentennial, after all. It would not have hurt the Minister to have asked Australian National to behave in a rational, coherent, decent and honourable way instead of in this petty minded, mean and obstructionist way. I hope that Australian National executives feel proud of their contribution in these monumentally negative terms to Australia's Bicentennial.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Senate to an article by Mr Rowan Greenland entitled, The green vote and what to do about it. This is a very thoughtful and politically incisive analysis of a contemporary political issue in Australia. Certainly, as a senator, I regard this as well worth reading and, of course, the appropriate stewardship of the environment is an issue of which we should all take note. I seek the leave of the Senate to table this five-page article.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Crichton-Browne's speech earlier I want to say that he is reiterating what was in the dissenting report, and taking quotations out of context. I want to make it clear that, once again, Senator Crichton-Browne has quoted very selectively from the evidence, including in camera evidence. I also want to quote from two documents written by the Jawoyn people themselves. One is a report of the Jawoyn Working Party which was presented to a number of people in this Parliament late last year. I quote from the executive summary of that document, which, incidentally, was presented by at least two senior custodians and four other traditional owners. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Jawoyn-the traditional Aboriginal owners of major areas of Stage Three of Kakadu National Park-wish to make it entirely clear to the readers of this document that we reject mining and exploration in the Sickness Country . . . Since the late 1950s our people have attempted to convince non Aboriginal people that the Gimbat region is of great spiritual significance to the Jawoyn. Jawoyn people have always maintained the importance of the Bulademo (Sickness Country). Within the traditional cultural values and beliefs of the Jawoyn, the Bulademo sites complex cannot be disturbed in any way . . . We have come to Canberra to tell the politicians that we do not want mining or exploration in the Sickness Country.

That is a fairly definite statement. Secondly, I would like to quote from a media release dated 13 June, again from the Jawoyn Working Party in response, I understand, to Senator Tambling's press release and speech. It quotes Mr Robert Lee, the Chairman of the Jawoyn Working Party, and states:

Mr Lee said that the report by Mr Cooper, ``On Shaky Ground'', had been tabled with the permission of senior Jawoyn custodians of the Sickness Country, and did not contain material offensive to them. ``Cooper's Report was all about Aboriginal views being misrepresented and distorted,'' Mr Lee said. ``Senator Tambling has shown that he would like our views to continue to be belittled and forgotten.
I had intended to respond to allegations that were made by Senator Tambling both here and in his press release, but I will leave that to another time or another method of doing so.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 12 midnight
