ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telecom Australia and Australia Post:Television Advertising

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 2 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: How much is (a) Telecom and (b) Australia Post spending on television advertising for services which they alone can supply.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Telecom and Australia Post:

ANSWER.PARA: Telecom's and Australia Post's expenditure, for the financial year 1988-89, for television advertising for services which they alone can provide has been:
(a) $7.7 million-The services involved and the reasons for the advertising are as follows:
Network services (STD and 008)-to ensure the community is adequately informed of major changes in telephone call charges.

Commander Telephone Systems, Cardphone-to keep the community informed of the services available from Telecom and, in the case of Commander Systems, to ensure these are properly positioned against the variety of potential substitute services available from other sources and also widely advertised.
White Pages telephone directories-to encourage use of these ahead of the more costly to provide Telecom Directory Assistance Service.

(b) $1 million-the service involved and reason for advertising was to inform the general public of the phasing out of Telecom Australia's telegram service, and its replacement by Australia Post's new Lettergram service and to promote acceptance/patronage of the Lettergram service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 3 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Commonwealth Chief Censor, at the meeting in Darwin on 30 June 1988 of Federal and State Ministers responsible for censorship, undertake that film and videos at the upper end of `M' and `R' classification, would be reclassified.
(2) Could the Attorney-General supply a list of those films and videos that have been reclassified during the period 30 June 1988 to 31 March 1989, in the following categories:
(a) `M' to `R'
(b) `R' to `Refused Classification'
(c) `R' to `M'
(d) `Refused Classification' to `R'; and
(e) `Refused Classification' to `M'.
(3) Were the new censorship guidelines fully explained by the Chief Censor to the Ministerial Council in Darwin in 1988.
(4) Is the Attorney-General aware that realistic sexual violence may, under these revised guidelines, receive an `M' classification, `if contextually justified'.
(5) Is the Attorney-General satisfied that such scenes of sexual violence so classified will not be seen by children under the age of 15.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) Federal, State and the Northern Territory Ministers responsible for censorship matters considered recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material and new guidelines for the classification of films and videos in Darwin on 30 June 1988. Following discussions of the guidelines, Ministers asked the Chief Censor and the Chairman of the Films Board of Review to tighten the application of the guidelines at the top end of the `M' and `R' categories when classifying violent films or videos. There was no question of reclassification and no undertaking to reclassify such material was sought.

On 1 December 1988, the Board was given the power in the Australian Capital Territory to recall for reassessment videos which had been on the market for more than two years and which had caused public disquiet, or where the Board had reason to believe that community standards had changed significantly. The Board has recalled thirteen videos and will be making its decisions public on these videos when complementary State and Northern Territory legislation is in place.

(4) and (5) Material which is considered likely to disturb, harm or offend those under the age of 15 years will be assigned a Mature classification. While most adult themes may be dealt with, the degree of explicitness and intensity of treatment will determine what can be accommodated in this classification. The guidelines approved by the Ministers in Darwin in relation to the `M' category are:
Language: Crude language may be used, but not when it is excessive, unduly assaultive, or sexually explicit.
Sex: Sexual intercourse or other sexual activity may be discreetly implied or simulated.
Violence: Realistic violence of medium intensity may be depicted, but violent depictions with a high degree of realism or impact are acceptable only if contextually justified.
Other: Drug use may be depicted, but not in an advocatory manner. Supernatural and ``horror'' special effects usually warrant an `M' classification.

The guidelines do not indicate that ``realistic sexual violence . . .'' may receive an `M' classification `` . . . if contextually justified''. The whole category is governed by the general principle that ``the degree of explicitness and intensity of treatment will determine what can be accommodated in this category''. Unlike the `R' and `X' categories which have mandatory age proscriptions, the other categories, including the `M' category, are advisory only and responsibility for determining what children under 15 years watch at the cinema or on video rests with parents.
All films and videos classified after 1 May this year will carry consumer advice to assist parents in making decisions about material they consider is suitable for their children to watch.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister in his statement of 10 May 1989 state that the Australian and New Zealand content of the ANZAC Ship should reach 70 per cent and may go to 80 per cent.
(2) What contractual obligation will the Minister propose to ensure that these levels are reached and what indications have the contractors given that they will accept these obligations.
(3) For each of the following areas of shipboard equipment:
(a) propulsion;
(b) shipboard control and navigation;
(c) armaments;
(d) sensors;
(e) electronic warfare equipment;
(f) command and control systems; and
(g) safety and battle damage control systems:
(i) what proportion by value will be imported from overseas;
(ii) what proportion, by type, will be manufactured under licence or sub-assembled in Australia; and
(iii) what is the estimated project cost of each of these areas.
(4) For each of the areas (a) to (g) above, which countries are supplying the items studies by the 2 project development contractors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Statement on Defence Industry of 10 May 1989 did state that with the ANZAC Ships the Australian and New Zealand Content should reach 70 per cent and, with Offsets Work added, could reach 80 per cent, and I confirm that expectation.
(2) In the contract for construction of the ships, there will be an obligation placed on the contractor to meet the agreed levels of Australian and New Zealand content and offsets.

(3) and (4) The Commonwealth is currently negotiating with the two competing tenderers. Probity and commercial sensitivities therefore preclude the provision of any details of the nature or breakdown of the industry programs and equipment on offer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Attorney-General supply the full reasons why the Commonwealth Chief Censor determined on an `R' rating for the film THE ACCUSED, as was gazetted on 11 January 1989.
(2) What reasons were advanced by the Films Board of Review in reclassifying this film to an `M' rating, as was gazetted on 8 February 1989.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Chief Censor has supplied the following extract from the report of the Film Censorship Board on THE ACCUSED:

The Board was unanimous in its opinion that, whilst contextually justified, the re-creation of a brutal rape which reinforces the terror of the victim and the callousness with which she was treated by the males in the room, was sufficiently detailed and impactful to warrant a Restricted Classification.

(2) The Chairman of the Films Board of Review has supplied the following extract from the minutes of its meeting held on 15 December 1988 at which the Review Board considered an application for review of the decision of the Film Censorship Board to classify THE ACCUSED `For Restricted Exhibition'.

The Board of Review was at first equally divided on the merits of the appeal. Three members felt that the scene in question-presented as the recollections of a witness during a trial-was contextually justified; the others agreed with the Censorship Board that the scene went beyond the limits for an `M' rating. All members agreed, however, that the film contained a powerful message, and made a socially significant statement about rape and the degree of complicity of those who might witness crimes of sexual violence. The Board of Review, after prolonged discussion and a careful scrutiny of the guidelines for film classification, agreed by majority that an `M' classification was appropriate. The Board of Review insisted, however, that such a classification should be accompanied by a warning about the subject matter of the film. Accordingly, the Board of Review directed that THE ACCUSED be classified `M' (For Mature Audiences), and that publicity for the film be required to include the following statement: ``CENSORSHIP WARNING: THIS FILM CONTAINS SCENES OF GRAPHIC SEXUAL VIOLENCE''.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Brunette Downs: Living Conditions of Aborigines

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission investigated, or is it at present investigating, living conditions of Aboriginal people residing at Brunette Downs in the Northern Territory, as stated in the Australian of 5 May 1989; if so: (a) under what specific provisions of the Human Rights legislation is the investigation being conducted, or was conducted; (b) when were, or when will the findings of the Commission be issued.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has advised that it has not investigated, and is not at present investigating, the living conditions of Aboriginal people at Brunette Downs. An officer of the Commission travelled to Brunette Downs as a result of representations received by the Commission. However, the Commission has not made and does not propose to make any findings concerning this matter.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Leadership of the Opposition in the Senate

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the President, upon notice, on 30 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: In the event of the positions of Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate being held by 3 different Senators: (a) who would have precedence in the Senate Chamber, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or the Deputy Leader of the Opposition; (b) if the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate has precedence, would the Deputy Leader of the Opposition take precedence over the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; (c) who would sit at the table; (d) would the Leader of the National Party in the Senate take precedence over the Deputy Leader of the Opposition; and (e) would the Deputy Leader of the National Party in the Senate take precedence over the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
The President-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
The practices of the Senate accord recognition to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate in respect of certain matters, for example, giving the call to speak.
I will continue to observe these practices in relation to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate unless otherwise directed by a resolution of the Senate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 May 1989 (Hansard, p. 3105), Senator Calvert asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, this question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health, and relates to the present guidelines issued by the Department of Community Services and Health on the approval of admission to a nursing home. Is the Minister aware that the present guidelines preclude from admission to a nursing home any person who may have been a resident of a state institution for a period which may have been as short as one year preceding the application for approval? Is he further aware that this guideline also applies to persons who may similarly have been residents of state institutions for three years in the past five? Does the Minister acknowledge that such guidelines infer that many elderly persons, who may be required to enter such institutions for treatment of a temporary illness, are precluded from ever returning to the nursing home situation despite a recommendation to the contrary by Commonwealth medical officers? Will he also acknowledge that such guidelines are causing considerable hardship for those who are unable, because of geographical isolation, to relocate their families closer to their homes once treatment has been completed? Finally, could the Minister please advise whether the Department is considering altering the existing guidelines to address some of the issues to which I have previously referred today?
The Minister for Housing and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Section of the ``Guidelines for Approval of Admission to a Nursing home'' relating to residents of State psychiatric institutions was adopted in 1986 following a large number of nursing home admission applications from such residents where the reason for admission was given as ``closure of hospital beds''. This type of application is still being received.

The Commonwealth cannot be expected to bear the cost of savings realised by State Governments when State institutions are closed down and the State fails to make appropriate alternative arrangements for their accommodation and care. It remains the responsibility of State Governments to continue to provide care for long term residents of State psychiatric institutions particularly when those residents are discharged because of closures. Alternative arrangements are the responsibility of the States not the Commonwealth.

For this reason, the Commonwealth guidelines do preclude persons who have been long term residents of State institutions from being approved for nursing home admission. However, the guidelines specifically state that exemptions may occur where the application fulfils the criteria for admission in the National Health Act section 40ab (3) and:
where the application is for admission to a special purpose home related to the person's disability; or

the applicant has been admitted to the State institution for an acute episode while still a nursing home patient, or where admission was for less than twelve months or three years in the last five; and
the applicant suffers a long term physical illness, which overrides any psychiatric disorder or intellectual disability, and
the physical disability cannot be adequately managed in the State institution, and acute hospital care is not appropriate.

These exemptions would cover the case of a nursing home resident being required to have treatment for a temporary illness in a State institution and then wishing to return to a nursing home. There would therefore be nothing to prevent such a person from returning to the nursing home providing his or her physical and mental condition continued to require nursing home care.

In general, nursing homes are neither staffed nor equipped to provide care for people with psychiatric disorders. Most people with psychiatric disorders would not be helped by being admitted to a facility which is intended to provide nursing and personal care mainly for people with physical disabilities.
For these reasons I do not intend altering this section of the guidelines in response to the issues raised in the question.
